speaker: TODD
text: Good evening, and welcome to the MSNBC Democratic candidates debate.

speaker: MADDOW
text: We are super excited to be here at the University of New Hampshire.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Tonight, this is the first time that Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders have squared off exactly like this.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Face-to-face, just one-on-one, just the two of them.

speaker: TODD
text: And neither party has seen this yet.

speaker: TODD
text: These candidates are both running for the Democratic nomination, but they are very different from each other when it comes to what matters most and how they would go about the job of being president.

speaker: TODD
text: Our job tonight is to draw out those differences so you, the voters, can understand them and be fully informed.

speaker: MADDOW
text: And we do hope that the candidates will take this opportunity to show us the distinctions -- show us the differences between them.

speaker: MADDOW
text: That's the whole reason that we're here tonight.

speaker: MADDOW
text: We're not here for talking points.

speaker: MADDOW
text: We're to learn about the difference between the candidates.

speaker: MADDOW
text: And with that, let's get going.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Please join us in welcoming Secretary Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: First, I want to say a special thanks to the New Hampshire union leader for helping make this debate possible, and the readers, who helped provide some of the questions and topics that we'll be addressing tonight.

speaker: TODD
text: The rules tonight, by the way, are simple

speaker: TODD
text: 90 seconds for answers, 30 seconds for follow-ups and rebuttals.

speaker: MADDOW
text: And with that, that's it.

speaker: MADDOW
text: We're going to begin with 60- second opening statements from each of the candidates.

speaker: MADDOW
text: And as agreed to in advance by the two campaigns, we're going to begin tonight with Senator Sanders.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Rachel, thank you very much.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Millions of Americans are giving up on the political process.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And they're giving up on the political process because they understand the economy is rigged.

speaker: SANDERS
text: They are working longer hours for low wages.

speaker: SANDERS
text: They're worried about the future of their kids, and yet almost all new income and wealth is going to the top 1 percent.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Not what America is supposed to be about.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Not the fairness that we grew up believing that America was about.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And then sustaining that rigged economy is a corrupt campaign finance system undermining American democracy, where billionaire, Wall Street, corporate America can contribute unlimited sums of money into super PACs and into candidates.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Our job, together, is to end a rigged economy, create an economy that works for all, and absolutely overturn Citizens United.

speaker: SANDERS
text: One person, one vote.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's what American democracy is about.

speaker: TODD
text: Thank you, Senator.

speaker: TODD
text: Secretary Clinton.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I'm happy to be here in New Hampshire for this debate, as we move toward the primary on Tuesday.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I believe that America has the opportunity to once again live by our values, live up to our values in the 21st century, but I think that America can only do that if Americans can succeed.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And there are lots of reasons why Americans today are feeling left out and left behind.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yes, of course, the economy has not been working for most Americans.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yes, of course, we have special interests that are unfortunately doing too much to rig the game.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But there's also the continuing challenges of racism, of sexism, of discrimination against the LGBT community, of the way that we treat people as opposed to how we want to be treated.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I believe that we can get back on the right track.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to imagine a country where people's wages reflect their hard work, where we have healthcare for everyone, and where every child gets to live up to his or her potential.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm fighting for people who cannot wait for those changes, and I'm not making promises that I cannot keep.

speaker: TODD
text: All right.

speaker: TODD
text: Let's get started.

speaker: TODD
text: Secretary Clinton, last night you cited the Concord Monitor when you said of Senator Sanders that, quote, "It's very hard to see how any of his proposals could ever be achievable."

speaker: TODD
text: So please tell us why you think if he's elected president on a platform of promising things like free public college and universal healthcare, that he cannot achieve those things.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, let me start by saying that Senator Sanders and I share some very big progressive goals.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've been fighting for universal healthcare for many years, and we're now on the path to achieving it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I don't want us to start over again.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think that would be a great mistake, to once again plunge our country into a contentious debate about whether we should have and what kind of system we should have for healthcare.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to build on the progress we've made; got from 90 percent coverage to 100 percent coverage.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I don't want to rip away the security that people finally have; 18 million people now have healthcare; preexisting conditions are no longer a bar.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So we have a difference.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I also believe in affordable college, but I don't believe in free college, because every expert that I have talked to says, look, how will you ever control the costs.

speaker: CLINTON
text: What I want to do is make sure middle class kids, not Donald Trump's kids, get to be able to afford college.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to get the economy going again.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's not just enough about what we're against, as important as that is.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have a plan to create new jobs, manufacturing, infrastructure, clean energy jobs that will make us the 21st century clean energy super power.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I also want to make sure small businesses can start and grow again.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And of course, I believe in raising the minimum wage and equal pay for work.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But the numbers just don't add up, from what Senator Sanders has been proposing.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's why all of the independent experts, all of the editorial boards that have vetted both of us have concluded that it is just not achievable.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Let's go down a path where we can actually tell people what we will do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: A progressive is someone who makes progress.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's what I intend to do.

speaker: TODD
text: Thank you, Secretary.

speaker: TODD
text: Senator Sanders, so just explain how you spent nearly two decades in Congress and haven't gotten any of these things passed.

speaker: TODD
text: Why do you think as president you'll be able to achieve big, big new programs like this?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, I haven't quite run for president before.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let's deal with some of the comments that Secretary Clinton made.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And by the way, you know, sometimes there's a lot of drama here.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I have known Secretary Clinton for 25 years and respect her very much.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Here is the issue.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Every major country on earth, whether it's the U.K., whether it's France, whether it's Canada, has managed to provide healthcare to all people as a right and they are spending significantly less per capita on health care than we are.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So I do not accept the belief that the United States of America can't do that.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I do not accept the belief that the United States of America and our government can't stand up to the ripoffs of the pharmaceutical industry which charge us by far the highest prices in the world for prescription drugs.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Number two, in the economy today, everybody understands that we need a well educated workforce.

speaker: SANDERS
text: This is 2016.

speaker: SANDERS
text: When we talk about public education, it can no longer be K through 12th grade.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I do believe that public colleges and universities should be tuition free.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, how do we pay for that?

speaker: SANDERS
text: It's an expensive proposition.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I do believe that we should substantially lower student debt in this country, which is crushing millions of people.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We pay for it, in my view, by a tax on Wall Street speculation.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The middle class bailed out Wall Street in their time of need.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Now, it is Wall Street's time to help the middle class.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: If I could just follow up on that.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: There is no disagreement between us on universal coverage for health care, the disagreement is where do we start from and where do we end up.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The Republicans want to repeal the Affordable Care Act, I want to improve it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to build on it, get the costs down, get prescription drug costs down.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Senator Sanders wants us to start all over again.

speaker: CLINTON
text: This was a major achievement of President Obama, of our country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It is helping people right now.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I am not going to wait and have us plunge back into a contentious national debate that has very little chance of succeeding.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Let's make the Affordable Care Act work for everybody.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let me...

speaker: TODD
text: Go.

speaker: SANDERS
text: ... this is a good discussion here.

speaker: TODD
text: Yes, go ahead.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And let me just say this.

speaker: SANDERS
text: As Secretary Clinton may know, I am on the Health Education Labor Committee.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That committee wrote the Affordable Care Act.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The idea I would dismantle health care in America while we're waiting to pass a Medicare for all is just not accurate.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The Affordable Care Act has clearly, as Secretary Clinton made the point, done a lot of good things, but, what it has not done is dealt with the fact we have 29 million people today who have zero health insurance, we have even more who are underinsured with large deductibles and copayments and prescription drug prices are off the wall.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So I do believe that in the future, not by dismantling what we have here -- I helped write that bill -- but by moving forward, rallying the American people, I do believe we should have health care for all.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: All right, thank you both.

speaker: TODD
text: Rachel.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Secretary Clinton, Senator Sanders is campaigning against you now, at this point in the campaign, basically arguing that you are not progressive enough to be the Democratic nominee.

speaker: MADDOW
text: He has said that if you voted for the Iraq war, if you are in favor of the death penalty, if you wobbled on things like the Keystone Pipeline or TPP, if you said single payer health care could never happen, then you're too far to the right of the Democratic Party to be the party's standard bearer.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Given those policy positions, why should liberal Democrats support you and not Senator Sanders?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well because I am a progressive who gets things done.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the root of that word, progressive, is progress.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I've heard Senator Sanders comments, and it's really caused me to wonder who's left in the progressive wing of the Democratic Party.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Under his definition, President Obama is not progressive because he took donations from Wall Street; Vice President Biden is not progressive because she supported Keystone; Senator Shaheen is not progressive because she supports the trade pact.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Even the late, great Senator Paul Wellstone would not fit this definition because he voted for DOMA.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, we have differences and, honestly, I think we should be talk about what we want to do for the country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But if we're going to get into labels, I don't think it was particularly progressive to vote against the Brady Bill five times.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: I don't think it was progressive to vote to give gun makers and sellers immunity.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I don't think it was progressive to vote against Ted Kennedy's immigration reform.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So we could go back and forth like this, but the fact is most people watching tonight want to know what we've done and what we will do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's why I am laying out a specific agenda that will make more progress, get more jobs with rising incomes, get us to universal health care coverage, get us to universal pre-k, paid family leave and the other elements of what I think will build a strong economy, that will ensure Americans keep making progress.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's what I'm offering and that's what I will do as president.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MADDOW
text: Senator Sanders, have you established a list of what it means to be a progressive that is unrealistic?

speaker: SANDERS
text: No, not at all.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Here's the reality of American economic life today.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The reality is that we have one of lowest voter turnouts of any major country on earth because so many people have given up on the political process.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The reality is that there has been trillions of dollars of wealth going from the middle class in the last 30 years to the top 1/10th of 1 percent.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The reality is we that have a corrupt campaign finance system which separates the American people's needs and desires from what Congress is doing.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So to my mind, what we have got to do is wage a political revolution where millions of people have given up on the political process, stand up and fight back, demand the government that represents us and not just a handful of campaign contribution -- contributors.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Now all of the ideas that I'm talking about, they are not radical ideas.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Making public colleges and universities tuition free, that exists in countries all over the world, used to exist in the United States.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Rebuilding our crumbling infrastructure, and creating 13 million jobs by doing away with tax loopholes that large corporations now enjoy by putting their money into the Cayman Islands and other tax havens.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That is not a radical idea.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What we need to do is to stand up to the big money interests, and the campaign contributors.

speaker: SANDERS
text: When we do that, we can, in fact, transform America.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Thank you Senator.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: I'd like to follow up on a comment that Secretary Clinton said, Senator.

speaker: TODD
text: President Obama has not called for abolishing the death penalty.

speaker: TODD
text: President Obama is for the big Asian trade deal known as TPP, and just yesterday you said you can't be both a moderate or a progressive, but you can't be both.

speaker: TODD
text: Is President Obama, in your judgment, based on these policies positions, a progressive?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let me just pick up on this point.

speaker: SANDERS
text: This whole discussion began because I commented, not making overall evaluation about the Secretary.

speaker: SANDERS
text: She was in Ohio, I think, in September or November and she got up and said something like, I have been -- I'm paraphrasing, I have been criticized because people think I'm a moderate.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, I am a moderate.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's where this came from.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It wasn't me paraphrasing her.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It is what she said, and all that I said was there's nothing wrong with being a moderate.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But, you can't be a moderate, you can't a progressive.

speaker: SANDERS
text: In terms of President Obama, I think if we remember where this country was seven years ago, 800,000 jobs being lost every month, $1.4 trillion dollar deficit.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The world's financial system on the verge of collapse.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think that President Obama, Vice President Biden, and the Democratic leadership in the House and the Senate have done a fantastic job.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We are in much better shape than we were seven years ago, although my Republican colleagues seem to have forgotten where we were seven years ago.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's the fact, but, we still have a very long way to go.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Do I think President Obama is a progressive?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Yes, I do.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I disagree with him on a number of issues including the trade agreement.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But, yes, I think he has done an excellent job.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, Chuck...

speaker: TODD
text: ... (inaudible) Clinton, go ahead...

speaker: CLINTON
text: If I could, you know, in the very first debate I was asked am I a moderate or a progressive and I said I'm a progressive who likes to get things done.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Cherry picking a quote here or there doesn't change my record of having fought for racial justice, having fought for kids rights, having fought the kind of inequities that fueled my interest in service in the first place going back to my days in the Children's Defense Fund.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It certainly didn't stop me from taking on the drug companies and the insurance companies.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Before it was called Hillarycare -- I mean, before it was called ObamaCare it was called Hillarycare because we took them on, and we weren't successful, but we kept fighting and we got the children's health insurance program.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Every step along the way I have stood up, and fought, and have the scars to prove it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, again...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think it's important that, look, I understand Senator Sanders really trying to distinguish himself.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I understand that, that's what you do in campaigns, but at the same time let's not be -- in, I think an unfair way, making an accusation, or making an attack about where I stand and about where I've always stood.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It is fair to say, Senator, that in your definition, as you being the self-proclaimed gatekeeper for progressivism, I don't know anyone else who fits that definition, but I know a lot of really hard fighting progressives in the Democratic party who have stood up time, and time again against special interests, against the powerful on behalf of those who are left behind and left out.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, that's what we ought to be celebrating.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Let's talk about what we would do as President, and Commander in Chief to make sure the progress continues into the future.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: (inaudible) 30 seconds, and then we'll move.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's right, I mean, instead of arguing about definitions, let's talk about...

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... Well, you began it yesterday with your comments...

speaker: SANDERS
text: ... What we should do, and one of the things we should do is not only talk the talk, but walk the walk.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I am very proud to be the only candidate up here who does not have a Super PAC, who's not raising huge sums of money from Wall Street...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: ... And special interests.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I am enormously proud.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Never believed it would happen that we have raised 3.5 million individual contributions, averaging $27 dollars a piece.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That is what the political revolution means.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: Thank you.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Senator Sanders, as a Vermonter, you have almost a home state advantage here in New Hampshire.

speaker: MADDOW
text: But back home across the border, you also have a long history of running against Democrats as a third-party candidate, for governor, Senate, for Congress.

speaker: MADDOW
text: In 1988 your candidacy as a third-party candidate arguably cost the Democrats a congressional seat and sent a Republican instead.

speaker: MADDOW
text: How can you lead the Democratic Party nationally when you have not been a member of the Democratic Party until very recently?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, Rachel, actually, that wasn't accurate.

speaker: SANDERS
text: In 1988 the Republican did win, I believe, by 3 points.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I came in second.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It was 34-31, I think, 19 for the Democrat.

speaker: SANDERS
text: In that race the Democrat was the spoiler, not me.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And it is true...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: It is true, it's not to be denied, I am the longest- serving independent in the history of the United States Congress.

speaker: SANDERS
text: People of Vermont sent me to Washington as an independent.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That is true.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But on the other hand, I have -- when I was in the House for 16 years, I caucused with the Democrats.

speaker: SANDERS
text: In the Senate for nine years caucused with the Democrats, of course.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And I was elected by the Democrats to be chair of the Veterans Committee three years ago, which I'm very proud of.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And now am the rankings member on the Budget Committee, leader of the Democrats in opposition to the majority Republicans.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I am running for president as a Democrat.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And if elected, not only do I hope to bring forth a major change in national priorities, but let me be frank, I do want to see major changes in the Democratic Party.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I want to see working people and young people come into the party in a way that doesn't exist now.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And you know what, I want a 50-state strategy so the Democratic Party is not just the party of 25 states.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MADDOW
text: Secretary Clinton.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, the person who first put out the idea of a 50-state party strategy is former Governor Howard Dean, who is with us tonight.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I'm very proud and grateful to have the support of so many elected Vermonters and former officials.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Two former governors, the current governor, the current other senator.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I really appreciate that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think it's because they've worked with me, they've seen what I do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They know what kind of a colleague I am.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They want me as their partner in the White House.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And that's exactly what I will do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We'll get things done together.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Democrats, Republicans, independents, we're going to make progress together when I'm president.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MADDOW
text: So, Senator, to that point, Secretary Clinton is raising the issue of endorsements by your home state Democrats.

speaker: MADDOW
text: She's implying that that says something about the people who know you best.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, I don't see it quite like that.

speaker: MADDOW
text: How do you see it?

speaker: SANDERS
text: I am -- will absolutely admit that Secretary Clinton has the support of far more governors, mayors, members of the House.

speaker: SANDERS
text: She has the entire establishment or almost the entire establishment behind her.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's a fact.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I don't deny it.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But I am pretty proud that we have over a million people who have contributed to our campaign averaging 27 bucks apiece.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That we have had meetings where 25,000-30,000 people have come out.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That our campaign is a campaign of the people, by the people, and for the people.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So, Rachel, yes, Secretary Clinton does represent the establishment.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I represent, I hope, ordinary Americans, and by the way, who are not all that enamored with the establishment, but I am very proud to have people like Keith Ellison and Raul Grijalva in the House, the co-chairmen of the House Progressive Caucus.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Secretary.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, look, I've got to just jump in here because, honestly, Senator Sanders is the only person who I think would characterize me, a woman running to be the first woman president, as exemplifying the establishment.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I've got to tell you that it is...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: It is really quite amusing to me.

speaker: CLINTON
text: People support me because they know me.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They know my life's work.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They have worked with me and many have also worked with Senator Sanders.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And at the end of the day they endorse me because they know I can get things done.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: I am not going to make promises I can't keep.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I am not going to talk about big ideas like single-payer and then not level with people about how much it will cost.

speaker: CLINTON
text: A respected health economist said that these plans would cost a trillion dollars more a year.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm not going to tell people that I will raise your incomes and not your taxes, and not mean it, because I don't want to see the kind of struggle that the middle class is going through exemplified by these promises that would raise taxes and make it much more difficult for many, many Americans to get ahead and stay ahead.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That is not my agenda.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MADDOW
text: Senator Sanders, you'll have 30 seconds to respond to that.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What being part of the establishment is, is, in the last quarter, having a super PAC that raised $15 million from Wall Street, that throughout one's life raised a whole lot of money from the drug companies and other special interests.

speaker: SANDERS
text: To my mind, if we do not get a handle on money in politics and the degree to which big money controls the political process in this country, nobody is going to bring about the changes that is needed in this country for the middle class and working families.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yeah, but I -- I think it's fair to really ask what's behind that comment.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, Senator Sanders has said he wants to run a positive campaign.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've tried to keep my disagreements over issues, as it should be.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But time and time again, by innuendo, by insinuation, there is this attack that he is putting forth, which really comes down to -- you know, anybody who ever took donations or speaking fees from any interest group has to be bought.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I just absolutely reject that, Senator.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I really don't think these kinds of attacks by insinuation are worthy of you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And enough is enough.

speaker: CLINTON
text: If you've got something to say, say it directly.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But you will not find that I ever changed a view or a vote because of any donation that I ever received.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I have stood up and I have represented my constituents to the best of my abilities, and I'm very proud of that.

speaker: SANDERS
text: ... you know...

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I think it's time to end the very artful smear that you and your campaign have been carrying out...

speaker: SANDERS
text: (inaudible).

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... in recent weeks, and let's talk...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (BOOING)

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... let's talk about about the issues.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Let's talk about the issues that divide us.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let's talk about -- OK, let's talk...

speaker: CLINTON
text: And let's -- let's...

speaker: SANDERS
text: ... let us talk about issues.

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... we both agree with campaign finance reform.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let's talk about issues.

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let's...

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to reverse Citizens United.

speaker: SANDERS
text: ... let's -- let's -- let's talk about issues.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so -- let's talk about issues.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let's talk -- let's talk about issues, all right?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let's talk about why, in the 1990s, Wall Street got deregulated.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Did it have anything to do with the fact that Wall Street provided -- spent billions of dollars on lobbying and campaign contributions?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, some people might think, yeah, that had some influence.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let's ask why it is that we pay, by far, the highest prices in the world for prescription drugs, and your medicine can be doubled tomorrow, and there's nothing that the government can do to stop it.

speaker: SANDERS
text: You think it has anything to do with the huge amounts of campaign contributions and lobbying from the fossil fuel industry?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let's talk about climate change.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Do you think there's a reason why not one Republican has the guts to recognize that climate change is real, and that we need to transform our energy system?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Do you think it has anything to do with the Koch brothers and ExxonMobil pouring huge amounts of money into the political system?

speaker: SANDERS
text: That is what goes on in America.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I am not -- I like...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: ... there is a reason.

speaker: SANDERS
text: You know, there is a reason why these people are putting huge amounts of money into our political system.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And in my view, it is undermining American democracy and it is allowing Congress to represent wealthy campaign contributors and not the working families of this country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, you know, Senator, I don't think -- I don't...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: ... Secretary, we're gonna...

speaker: CLINTON
text: I don't think you could find any person in political life today who has been subjected to more attacks and had more money spent against her by special interests, among whom you have named a few, than I.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I'm proud of that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, when I took on the drug companies and the insurance companies for universal health care coverage, they went after me with a vengeance.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Today, you've got hedge fund billionaires aligned with Karl Rove, running ads against me to try to get Democrats to vote for you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I know this game.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm going to stop this game.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But while we're talking about votes, you're the one who voted to deregulate swaps and derivatives in 2000, which contributed to the over-leveraging of Lehman Brothers, which was one of the culprits that brought down the economy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I don't know -- I'm not impugning your motive because you voted to deregulate swaps and derivatives.

speaker: CLINTON
text: People make mistakes and I'm certainly not saying you did it for any kind of financial advantage.

speaker: CLINTON
text: What we've got to do as Democrats -- what we've got to do as Democrats is to be united to actually solve these problems.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And what I believe is that I have a better track record and a better opportunity to actually get that job done.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's what this election should be about.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: Thirty seconds.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think as Secretary Clinton knows, there is nobody who fought harder.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I was on the House Financial Committee at that time.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I heard the arguments coming from Democrats and Republicans -- Robert Rubin, Alan Greenspan -- about great an idea it would be if we did away with Glass-Steagall and if we allowed investor banks and commercial banks and big insurance companies to merge.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Go to YouTube today.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Look up Greenspan-Sanders.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Listen to what I told them then.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I helped lead the effort against deregulation.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Unfortunately, we lost that.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The result is -- was the worst financial disaster since the Great Depression.

speaker: TODD
text: Thank you both.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Senator Sanders, Secretary Clinton, obviously we've touched a nerve.

speaker: MADDOW
text: We're going to be back with more on this subject, and much more, right after this.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Stay with us.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: All right, welcome back.

speaker: TODD
text: Let's get right to it.

speaker: TODD
text: Senator Sanders, you were talking about all of your campaign contributions and campaign finance reform.

speaker: TODD
text: You rail against big money in politics.

speaker: TODD
text: But do you realize there is one public financing system that we do have in place, and it is -- it is in place to run for president.

speaker: TODD
text: Why aren't you walking the walk on that?

speaker: TODD
text: Why aren't you participating in the presidential public financing system which is designed to essentially keep big money out of presidential politics?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Chuck, actually we looked at it, but it turns out to be a disaster.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The way it is structured right now, if you make it all the way to California, you could do pretty well.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But in terms of the early states -- Iowa, New Hampshire, the other states -- it just doesn't work.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Your point is well taken.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I believe in public funding of elections, absolutely.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But this system is -- I don't know if the secretary would agree -- is currently very antiquated and no longer applies to modern day politics.

speaker: TODD
text: Well, going on that then, why criticize her on Super PACs, and you got -- and all this when it is -- you know, that's the system?

speaker: TODD
text: I mean, you could be participating in a publicly-financing -- public financing system...

speaker: SANDERS
text: But if the...

speaker: TODD
text: ... and being able to set -- being able to set an example.

speaker: SANDERS
text: -- but Chuck, it is a public financing system that everybody knows is antiquated.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It no longer works.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Nobody can become president based on that system.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So what's the alternative?

speaker: SANDERS
text: There are two alternatives.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And, you know, we looked at it.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, should we do a Super PAC, but I concluded, honestly, I don't represent Corporate America or billionaires, I didn't want it.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So the other alternative was to ask working families and the middle class to help out in a transformational campaign.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And you know what?

speaker: SANDERS
text: We got 3.5 million individual contributions, $27 a piece.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think that's pretty good.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MADDOW
text: Secretary Clinton, on the issue of Wall Street...

speaker: CLINTON
text: On the issue of Wall Street.

speaker: MADDOW
text: ... on the issue of Wall Street, when our reporters go out and talk to people on the ground in the early states, what they tell us over and over again when they find voters who are leaning toward Senator Sanders rather than yourself is that the most frequent area of concern that they hear from those voters is the issue of Wall Street and whether or not you are too close to Wall Street.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Last night, when you were asked about speaking fees and the amount of speaking fees you got from Goldman Sachs speeches, you said that's what they offered.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Have you been too dismissive of voters' concerns about this issue in your own campaign and your own career?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well you know, Rachel, I think I may not have done the job I should in explaining my record.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, I did -- when I left the secretary of State's office, like so many former officials, military leaders, journalists, others, I did go on the speaking circuit.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I spoke to heart doctors, I spoke to the American Camping Association, I spoke to auto dealers, and yes, I spoke to firms on Wall Street.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They wanted me to talk about the world, what my experience had been as secretary of State.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But what I want people to know is I went to Wall Street before the crash.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I was the one saying you're going to wreck the economy because of these shenanigans with mortgages.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I called to end the carried interest loophole that hedge fund managers enjoy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I proposed changes in CEO compensation.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I called for a consumer protection financial bureau before it was created.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think the best evidence that the Wall Street people at least know where I stand and where I have always stood is because they are trying to beat me in this primary.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They have collected and spent as much as $6 million on these ads.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Hedge fund billionaires, Karl Rove, another billionaire, jumped in.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And why are they doing that?

speaker: CLINTON
text: These are guys who try to make smart investments.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They know my record, they know me, they know that I say what I believe and I will do it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I also have a pretty good understanding about how to stop them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I do want people to know that, and I think it's important for everybody to understand I have a record, I have stood firm and I will be the person who prevents them from ever wrecking the economy again.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MADDOW
text: Senator Sanders, you have been a critic of Secretary Clinton taking those speaking fees and having donations from Wall Street.

speaker: MADDOW
text: What about her defense of her record?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let me just say this.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Wall Street is perhaps the most powerful economic and political force in this country.

speaker: SANDERS
text: You have companies like Goldman Sachs, who just recently paid a settlement fine with the federal government for $5 billion for defrauding investors.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Goldman Sachs was one of those companies whose illegal activity helped destroy our economy and ruin the lives of millions of Americans.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But this is what a rigged economy and a corrupt campaign finance system and a broken criminal justice is about.

speaker: SANDERS
text: These guys are so powerful that not one of the executives on Wall Street has been charged with anything after paying, in this case of Goldman Sachs, a $5 billion fine.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Kid gets caught with marijuana, that kid has a police record.

speaker: SANDERS
text: A Wall Street executive destroys the economy, $5 billion settlement with the government, no criminal record.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That is what power is about.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That is what corruption is about.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And that is what has to change in the United States of America.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: CLINTON
text: If I could, let me just say that of course it has to change.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It has to change.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And that's why I have put forward a plan to do just that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And it's been judged to be the toughest, most effective and comprehensive one.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have great respect for Senator Sanders's commitment to try to restore Glass-Steagall.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I do not believe that that is enough.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And in fact, I don't believe it really addresses a lot of the biggest issues we have.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, we now have power under the Dodd-Frank legislation to break up banks.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I've said I will use that power if they pose a systemic risk.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I want to go further, because it was investment banks, it was insurance companies, it was mortgage companies, all of which contributed.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So let's not just be narrowly focused on one part of the problem.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have a lot of issues with corporate power that have to be addressed.

speaker: CLINTON
text: My plan takes us further and it would do the job.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: I would say that -- that folks who have looked at this issue for a long time, whether it's Elizabeth Warren or many other economists, will tell you that right now, yes, we do need a 21st century Glass-Steagall legislation.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And I would tell you also that when you have three out of the four largest banks in America today, bigger than they were -- significantly bigger than when we bailed them out because they were too big to fail, I think if Teddy Roosevelt were alive today, a good Republican by the way, what he would say is: Break them up; they are too powerful economically; they are too powerful politically.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And that is what I believe and many economists believe.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Time to break them up.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Look we have a law -- look, you know, I -- I appreciate the senator's advocacy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have a law.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It was passed.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It was signed by President Obama.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It lays out a process that you go through to determine whether a systemic risk is posed.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And by the way, President Obama signed that, pushed it through, even though he took donations from Wall Street, because he's a responsible president.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So we have a law in place.

speaker: CLINTON
text: If the circumstances warrant it, I will certainly use it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And from what you say, I know you will as well.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But that is not enough.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I keep going back to this because part of the reason the Wall Street guys are trying so hard to stop me -- the hedge fund guys, the shadow banking guys -- is because I've got their number on all of that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And my plan goes so much further to try to prevent the problems of the future.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, we can't just fight the last war.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've got to be prepared to stop these guys if they ever try to use their economic power once again, to hurt the economy, and to hurt so many Americans.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And my plan, Paul Krugman, Barney Frank, a lot of experts who understand what the new challenges might be, have said I am exactly on point, and the Wall Street guys actually know that.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: TODD
text: ... she has had more people praise her plan than yours.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, we've had a number of economists supporting our legislation.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And here's where we are.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The American people can judge.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Six largest financial institutions in America today have assets of roughly $10 trillion; equivalent to 58 percent of the GDP of the United States of America.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That is a lot of money.

speaker: SANDERS
text: They issue two thirds of the credit cards, and by the way they're ripping off a whole lot of people with high interest rates on the credit cards, and they write about one third of the mortgages.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That is a lot of power for six financial institutions.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's it.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think it is too much power.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Too much economic power, too much political power, and the economists that I talk to say we should break them up.

speaker: TODD
text: Thank you both.

speaker: TODD
text: Let me move on to our next question here, and in fact it comes to us through New England Cable News.

speaker: TODD
text: Secretary Clinton, it's addressed to you, and it's about this issue of the speeches, particularly to Goldman Sachs.

speaker: TODD
text: This is what the questioner wrote verbatim.

speaker: TODD
text: I am concerned with the abuses of Wall Street has taken with the American taxpayers money, and then she asks whether you would release the transcripts of your Goldman Sachs speeches, and then added, "Don't you think the voting public has a right to know what was said?"

speaker: TODD
text: But, let's make that bigger.

speaker: TODD
text: Are you willing to release the transcripts of all your paid speeches?

speaker: TODD
text: We do know through reporting that there were transcription services for all of those paid speeches.

speaker: TODD
text: In full disclosure, would you release all of them?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I will look into it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I don't know the status, but I will certainly look into it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But, I can only repeat what is the fact that I spoke to a lot of different groups with a lot of different constituents, a lot of different kinds of members about issues that had to do with world affairs.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I probably described more times than I can remember how stressful it was advising the President about going after Bin Laden.

speaker: CLINTON
text: My view on this is look at my record.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Look at what I am proposing, and -- we have a vigorous agreement here.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We both want to reign in the excesses of Wall Street.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I also want to reign in the excesses of Johnson Controls that we bailed out when they were an autoparts company, and we saved the auto industry, and now they want to avoid paying taxes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to go after the pharmaceutical companies like Valeant, and Turns that are increasing prices without any regard to the impact on people's health.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now, if all we're going to talk about is one part of our economy, and indeed one streak in our economy, we're missing the big oil companies.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We're missing other big energy companies.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We're missing the big picture, and I have a record of trying to go at the problems that actually exist, and I will continue to do that.

speaker: TODD
text: Senator, you sound like you want to respond.

speaker: TODD
text: Go ahead.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Yeah, I do.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I agree with much of what the Secretary said, but, madam Secretary, it is not one streak.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Wall Street is an entity of unbelievable economic and political power.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's a fact.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And, I want to say something, and it may sound harsh, not to you, but to the American people.

speaker: SANDERS
text: In a sense, in my view, the business model of Wall Street is fraud.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It's fraud.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I believe that corruption is rampant, and the fact that major bank after major bank has reached multi billion dollar settlements with the United States government when we have a weak regulator system tells me that not only did we have to bail them out once, if we don't start breaking them up, we're going to have to bail them out again, and I do not want to see that happen...

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... Well, Senator, no one wants to see that happen.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I mean, look, I care deeply about this because just like you I have met so many people who had their life savings wiped out, who lost their homes, who are barely back with their heads above water.

speaker: CLINTON
text: This was a disaster for our country, and we can never let that happen again.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have no disagreement about this.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But, I think it's a broader target list than just Wall Street, and I believe that we have to be very focused on how we try to take back the power and increase the empowerment of the American people.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, I think I have that kind of experience, maybe because they've beat me up for so many years, and I know exactly how to handle them because I've been in the arena with them time and time again.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Senator Sanders, let me turn to, I think, where this direction is heading anyway, which is the broader issue of big business and power in our political system.

speaker: MADDOW
text: You on the campaign trail have railed against big name American corporations like Boeing, and General Electric, and Wal Mart.

speaker: MADDOW
text: But, some big businesses in this country have also been part of advancing progressive goals like that nationwide initiative to expand employment opportunities for veterans.

speaker: MADDOW
text: That was all about cooperation between the Obama administration and some very big business.

speaker: MADDOW
text: The Affordable Care Act, some of the thorniest problems in that bill were worked out in cooperation with big business in order to accomplish progressive goals.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Could you work with them, or have you made enemies of big business in this country with the way you've approached them in this campaign?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Of course I can work with them, but let's be clear.

speaker: SANDERS
text: When I talked about Boeing and I talked about General Electric, what I was referring to is an outrage.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I suspect the secretary agrees request me.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Right now you have a loophole such that these guys are putting their profits, multi-billion dollar profitable corporations putting billions of dollars into the Cayman Islands, Bermuda, and other tax havens.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And in a given year, Rachel, after making billions of dollars in profit, do you know how much they're paying in taxes to the United States government in a given year?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Zero.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Now explain to me how that makes any sense at all.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So what I have said with regard to Boeing and GE and other multinationals that pay zero taxes, you know what we're going to do?

speaker: SANDERS
text: We're going to end that loophole.

speaker: SANDERS
text: They are going to pay their fair share of taxes.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We're going to use that money to rebuild our infrastructure and create up to 13 million jobs.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Can I work with corporations?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Are there good corporations doing incredible cutting edge research and development?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Absolutely they are.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And we should be proud of them.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But on the other hand, there are many corporations who have turned their backs on the American worker, who have said, if I can make another nickel in profit by going to China and shutting down in the United States of America, that's what I will do.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I will do my best to transform our trade policy and take on these corporations who want to invest in low-income countries around the world rather than in the United States of America.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MADDOW
text: Senator Sanders, thank you.

speaker: MADDOW
text: And with that, we're going to take a break.

speaker: TODD
text: We'll be right back.

speaker: TODD
text: And we're going to get to trade and a lot of other issues.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

speaker: MADDOW
text: Welcome back -- welcome back to the Democratic candidates' debate.

speaker: MADDOW
text: We're going to be talking about America in the world, both in terms of some trade issues, but also national security.

speaker: MADDOW
text: And Secretary Clinton, we're going to start with you.

speaker: MADDOW
text: There are more than 4,000 American troops back in Iraq right now as part of the fight against ISIS.

speaker: MADDOW
text: It has been 15 straight years of wars and multiple deployments for America's military families, who have borne such a disproportionate burden.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Is President Obama right to keep escalating the number of U.S. troops that's fighting ISIS right now?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I think what the president understands, and what he's trying to do, is that we have to support the Arab and Kurdish fighters on the ground who are actually doing the fighting.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I agree with the president.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've said myself, we will not send American combat troops back to either Syria or Iraq -- that is off the table.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we do have special forces, we do have trainers, we do have the military personnel who are helping with the airstrikes that the United States is leading so that we can try to take out ISIS infrastructure, take out their leadership.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think that, given the threat that ISIS poses to the region and beyond, as we have sadly seen in our own country, it is important to keep the Iraqi army on a path where they can actually take back territory, to work with the Sunni tribes in Anbar province and elsewhere so that their fighters can be also deployed, to work with the Kurds to provide them the support, but they're doing the fighting.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We're doing the support and enabling.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I also think we've got to do more to stop foreign fighters, foreign funding and take ISIS on online, as well as doing everything necessary to keep us safe at home.

speaker: So as I look at what the president it doing, it adds up to me. We just have to keep -- try to get more support for those people on the ground in Syria and Iraq who have to actually physically take the territory back. MADDOW
text: To be clear, to the specific question, if that strategic goal that you're describing requires considerably more of Americans -- an ever-increasing number of Americans in Iraq and maybe in Syria, are you OK with the numbers increasing?

speaker: CLINTON
text: No.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I mean, of course that's a theoretical question, and we don't know what it would be for, and we don't know how many numbers there are.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I am against American combat troops being in Syria and Iraq.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I support special forces.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I support trainers.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I support the air campaign.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think we're making some progress.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to continue to intensify that, and that's exactly what the president is doing.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Thank you, Madam Secretary.

speaker: TODD
text: Go ahead, Senator Sanders -- 30 seconds, your response.

speaker: SANDERS
text: OK. Let me agree with much of what the secretary said, but where we have a different background on this issue is we differ on the war in Iraq, which created barbaric organizations like ISIS.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Not only did I vote against that war, I helped lead the opposition, and if you go to my website, berniesanders.com, you will see the statement that I made in 2002.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And it gives me no pleasure to tell you that much of what I feared would happen the day after Saddam Hussein was overthrown, in fact, did happen.

speaker: TODD
text: All right.

speaker: TODD
text: Senator, I want to stay, though...

speaker: CLINTON
text: If I could -- if I could...

speaker: TODD
text: Go ahead.

speaker: TODD
text: 30 seconds.

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... respectfully add -- look, we did differ.

speaker: CLINTON
text: A vote in 2002 is not a plan to defeat ISIS.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to look at the threats that we face right now...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... and we have to be prepared to take them on and defeat them.

speaker: TODD
text: Let me -- let -- we're gonna -- we're staying -- we're staying basically on this topic.

speaker: TODD
text: Obviously you've been emphasizing this difference on the Iraq war, but one place where you do agree, and one place where you voted to authorize the use of force, was in favor of the war in Afghanistan.

speaker: TODD
text: Right now, it is possible President Obama is going to be leaving the next president, perhaps President Sanders, at least 10,000 troops in Afghanistan.

speaker: TODD
text: How long will those troops be in Afghanistan under President Sanders?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, I think our great task is to make certain that our young men and women in the military do not get sucked into never- ending, perpetual warfare within the quagmire of Syria and Iraq.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And I will do my very best to make sure that that doesn't happen.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I agree with the secretary that I think what has to happen -- and let me just mention what King Abdullah of Jordan said.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think he hit the nail on the head.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And what he said is essentially the war against ISIS is a war for the soul of Islam.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And it must be Muslim troops on the ground that will destroy ISIS, with the support of a coalition of major powers -- U.S., U.K., France, Germany and Russia.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So our job is to provide them the military equipment that they need; the air support they need; special forces when appropriate.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But at the end of the day for a dozen different reasons, not the least of which is that ISIS would like American combat troops on the ground so they could reach out to the Muslim world and say, "Look, we're taking on those terrible Americans."

speaker: SANDERS
text: The combat on the ground must be done by Muslim troops with our support.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We must not get involved in perpetual warfare in the Middle East.

speaker: TODD
text: Can you address a question on Afghanistan?

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: TODD
text: How long are these troops going to be there?

speaker: TODD
text: If President Obama leaves you 10,000 troops, how long do you think they're going to be there?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, you can't simply withdraw tomorrow.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Wish we could, and allow, you know, the Taliban or anybody else to reclaim that country.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But what we must do, and what we have seen in recent months, is some progress in Iraq, where finally the Iraqi army, which has not been a particularly effective fighting force, retook Ramadi.

speaker: SANDERS
text: ISIS has lost I think 40 percent of the territory that it held in the last year.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Hopefully, and you know, one can't predict the future, that maybe our training and their fighting capabilities are improving and we are going to make some progress in destroying ISIS.

speaker: TODD
text: Secretary Clinton, 30 seconds: How long are these troops going to be in Afghanistan?

speaker: TODD
text: We have more American troops in Afghanistan than what we were talking about with Iraq.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Oh, absolutely.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The president decided to leave more troops than he had originally planned in Afghanistan.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have a very cooperative government there, with Ashraf Ghani and his top -- his top partner, Abdullah.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And they are doing their very best.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the Afghan army is actually fighting.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The Afghan army is taking heavy losses defending Afghan territory.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I would have to make an evaluation based on the circumstances at the time I took office as to how much help they continue to need.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Because it's not just the Taliban.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We now are seeing outposts of, you know, fighters claiming to be affiliated with ISIS.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, we've got this arc of instability from North Africa to South Asia, and we have to pay close attention to it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we have to build coalitions, something that I did to take on the Iranian nuclear program, and what I will do as president to make sure that we defeat these terrorist networks.

speaker: TODD
text: You know, Senator Sanders, nobody knows who your foreign policy advisers are.

speaker: TODD
text: You haven't given a major foreign policy speech.

speaker: TODD
text: And it doesn't sound like all the time that foreign policy is a priority, other than when you're asked about it, and you say you're going to crush ISIS, as you said last night and earlier.

speaker: TODD
text: You have not proactively laid out a foreign policy doctrine yet.

speaker: TODD
text: Why?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, that's not quite accurate.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I did give a speech at Georgetown where I talked about democratic socialism and foreign policy.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Maybe I shouldn't have combined the two in the same speech, because the foreign policy part of it didn't get much attention.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So, let me take this opportunity to give you a very short speech here on the issue.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think, while it is true that the secretary and I voted differently on the war in Iraq, what is important is that we learn the lesson of the war in Iraq.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And that lesson is intrinsic to my foreign policy if elected president, is the United States cannot do it alone.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We cannot be the policeman of the world.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We are now spending more I believe than the next eight countries on defense.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We have got to work in strong coalition with the major powers of the world and with those Muslim countries that are prepared to stand up and take on terrorism.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So I would say that the key doctrine of the Sanders administration would be no, we cannot continue to do it alone; we need to work in coalition.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: CLINTON
text: A group of national security experts, military intelligence experts, issued a very concerning statement about Senator Sanders's views on foreign policy and national security, pointing out some of the comments he has made on these issues, such as inviting Iranian troops into Syria to try to resolve the conflict there; putting them right at the doorstep of Israel.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Asking Saudi Arabia and Iran to work together, when they can't stand each other and are engaged in a proxy battle right at this moment.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I do think questions have been raised and questions have to be answered because when New Hampshire voters go on Tuesday to cast your vote, you are voting both for a president and a commander in chief.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And there is no way to predict what comes in the door of that White House from day to day that can pose a threat to the United States or one of our friends and allies, and I think this is a big part of the job interview that we are all conducting with the voters here.

speaker: TODD
text: All right, Senator, 30 seconds.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: (OFF-MIKE) I fully, fully concede that Secretary Clinton, who was secretary of State for four years, has more experience -- hat is not arguable -- in foreign affairs.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But experience is not the only point, judgment is.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And once again, back in 2002, when we both looked at the same evidence about the wisdom of the war in Iraq, one of us voted the right way and one of us didn't.

speaker: SANDERS
text: In terms of Iran and in terms of Saudi Arabia, of course they hate each other.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's no great secret.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But John Kerry, who is I think doing a very good job, has tried to at least get these people in the room together because both of them are being threatened by ISIS.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, let me just add that, you know, I've said this before and I'm very proud of it, that when it comes to judgment, having run a hard race against Senator Obama at the time, he turned to me to be secretary of State.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And when it comes to the biggest counterterrorism issues that we faced in this administration, namely whether or not to go after bin Laden, I was at that table, I was exercising my judgment to advise the president on what to do, on that, on Iran, on Russia on China, on a whole raft of issues.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Because I know from my own experience that you've got to be ready on day one.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There is just too much unpredictable threat and danger in the world today, you know, to try to just say wait, I'll get to that when I can.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That is just not an acceptable approach.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well...

speaker: MADDOW
text: Secretary Clinton, at the -- at the last Democratic debate in Charleston -- I want to get specific here -- Senator Sanders called for moving as aggressively as we can to normalize relations with Iran.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Your campaign has criticized him for saying that.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Now that he's standing next to you here on this stage, can you explain why the U.S. shouldn't try to normalize relations in Iran in your view?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Absolutely.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, I did put together the coalition to impose sanctions.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I actually started the negotiations that led to the nuclear agreement, sending some much my closest aides to begin the conversations with the Iranians.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm very pleased we got that nuclear agreement.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It puts a lid on the nuclear weapons program.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to enforce it, there have to be consequences attached to it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But that is not our only problem with Iran.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to figure out how to deal with Iran as the principal state sponsor of terrorism in the world.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They are destabilizing governments in the region.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They continue to support Hezbollah and Hamas in Lebanon against Israel.

speaker: CLINTON
text: A lot of work that we have do is going to be incredibly hard.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm prepared to do that work, but I believe, just as I did with imposing the sanctions, you have to get action for action.

speaker: CLINTON
text: If we were to normalize relations right now, we would remove one of the biggest pieces of leverage we have to try to influence and change Iranian behavior.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The president doesn't think we should.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I certainly don't think we should.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I believe we have to take this step by step to try to reign in Iranian aggression, their support for terrorism and the other bad behavior that can come back and haunt us.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Who said That think we should normalize relations with Iran tomorrow?

speaker: SANDERS
text: I never said that.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think we should move forward as quickly as we can.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And you're right.

speaker: SANDERS
text: They are a sponsor of terrorism around the world and we have to address that.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But you know, a number of years ago, people were saying normal relationship with Cuba, what a bad and silly idea.

speaker: SANDERS
text: They're Communists, they are our enemy.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well guess what?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Change has come.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So please don't suggest that I think we normalize relations with Tehran tomorrow.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We don't.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But I would like to see us move forward, and hopefully some day that will happen.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And I would say if I might, Madam Secretary -- and you can correct me if I'm wrong.

speaker: SANDERS
text: When you ran against Senator Obama you thought him naive because he thought it was a good idea to talk to our enemies.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think those are exactly the people you have to talk to and you have to negotiate with.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well Senator, let me just correct the record if I can.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know -- let me correct the record.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: TODD
text: 30 seconds, madam secretary.

speaker: CLINTON
text: As I -- as I certainly recall, the question was to meet with without conditions.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And you're right, I was against that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I was against it then I would be against it now.

speaker: SANDERS
text: OK.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Part of diplomacy, the hard work of diplomacy is trying to extract whatever concessions you can get, and giving something the other side wants.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Of course you've got to try to make peace with, and work with those who are your adversaries, but you don't just rush in, open the door, and say, "Here I am. Let's talk and make a deal."

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's not the way it works.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think President Obama had the right idea, and the bottom line is that of course there have to be conditions.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But, of course it doesn't do us any good to not talk with our adversaries...

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... Well, we set conditions on Iran.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We worked hard to get them established, and to be enforced, and then we talked.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's exactly the right...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... And, that's what I did with the President, so he and I are on the very same page.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Just to set the record straight, I very strongly supported the agreement which makes certain that Iran does not get a nuclear weapon.

speaker: TODD
text: Alright, as Commander in Chief, Senator Sanders, you've got to prioritize potential threats to the United States.

speaker: TODD
text: Three countries, North Korea, Iran, Russia.

speaker: TODD
text: How would you rank them in order of their threat to America's security right now...

speaker: SANDERS
text: ... ISIS...

speaker: TODD
text: Starting with the biggest threat.

speaker: SANDERS
text: ISIS, you forgot one...

speaker: TODD
text: I didn't say that...

speaker: SANDERS
text: ... ISIS would be ...

speaker: TODD
text: ... We already had that.

speaker: TODD
text: I'm talking about these three countries.

speaker: TODD
text: How would you orient our national security, our national defense posture.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Clearly North Korea is a very strange situation because it is such an isolated country run by a handful of dictators, or maybe just one, who seems to be somewhat paranoid.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And, who had nuclear weapons.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And, our goal there, in my view, is to work and lean strongly on China to put as much pressure.

speaker: SANDERS
text: China is one of the few major countries in the world that has significant support for North Korea, and I think we got to do everything we can to put pressure on China.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I worry very much about an isolated, paranoid country with atomic bombs.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think, clearly, we got to work closely with China to resolve the serious problems we have, and I worry about Putin and his military adventurism in the Crimea and the Ukraine.

speaker: TODD
text: Secretary of Defense Ash Carter this week picked one of those three, and he has said Russia is, basically, the most important national security threat.

speaker: TODD
text: Sort of reorienting the defense and the challenges to that.

speaker: TODD
text: Do you agree with his decisions...

speaker: SANDERS
text: ... No, I don't.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I worry very, very much about an isolated country.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's what makes me nervous.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Russia lives in the world.

speaker: SANDERS
text: China lives in the world.

speaker: SANDERS
text: North Korea is a very, very strange country because it is so isolated, and I do feel that a nation with nuclear weapons, they have got to be dealt with.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Dealt with effectively.

speaker: TODD
text: Secretary Clinton, what do you think of Secretary of Defense Ash Carter.

speaker: TODD
text: He's basically putting Russia above Iran, above North Korea, as sort of the chief national security challenge right now.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I haven't talked to Secretary Carter, but here's what I would think he's planning.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We do have the nuclear weapons agreement with Iran, that's an enforcement consequence, action for action, follow on.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have a plan, we will watch them, we will be vigilant.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We do have to worry about North Korea.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They continue to develop their nuclear weapons capability, and they're working very hard on their ballistic missile capability.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, I know that some of those plans could very well lead to a missile that might reach Hawaii, if not the West Coast.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We do have to try to get the countries in the region to work with us to do everything we can to confine, and constrain them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But, what Secretary Carter is looking at is the constant pressure that Russia's putting on our European allies.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The way that Russia is trying to move the boundaries of the post-World War II Europe.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The way that he is trying to set European countries against one another, seizing territory, holding it in Crimea.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Beginning to explore whether they could make some inroads in the Baltics.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We know that they are deeply engaged in supporting Assad because they want to have a place in the Middle East.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They have a naval base, they have an air base in Syria.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They want to hang on to that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think what Secretary Carter is seeing, and I'm glad he is, is that we got to get NATO back working for the common defense.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've got to do more to support our partners in NATO, and we have to send a very clear message to Putin that this kind of belligerence, that this kind of testing of boundaries will have to be responded to.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The best way to do that is to put more armor in, put more money from the Europeans in so they're actually contributing more to their own defense.

speaker: TODD
text: Thank you both, Rachel?

speaker: MADDOW
text: Secretary Clinton, I want to ask you about a national security issue that is closer to home.

speaker: MADDOW
text: There are thousands of veterans, over 100,000 veterans living in the state of New Hampshire.

speaker: MADDOW
text: If either one of you is nominated as the Democratic Party's nominee, you will likely face a Republican opponent in the general election who wants to privatize or even abolish big parts of the V.A.

speaker: MADDOW
text: It's a newly popular idea in conservative politics.

speaker: MADDOW
text: How will you win the argument on that issue given the problems that have been exposed at the V.A.

speaker: MADDOW
text: in the last few years?

speaker: MADDOW
text: What's your argument that the V.A.

speaker: MADDOW
text: should still exist and should not be privatized?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, first of all, I'm absolutely against privatizing the V.A.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I am going do everything I can to build on the reforms that Senator Sanders and others in Congress have passed to try to fix what's wrong with the V.A.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There are a lot of issues about wait times and services that have to be fixed because our veterans deserve nothing but the best.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But you're absolutely right, you know, Rachel, this is another part of the Koch brothers agenda.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They've actually formed an organization to try to begin to convince Americans we should no longer have guaranteed health care, specialized care for our veterans.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I will fight that as hard as I can.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think there's where we can enlist the veterans service organizations, the veterans of America, because, yes, let's fix the V.A., but we will never let it be privatized, and that is a promise.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MADDOW
