text: Senator Sanders, you, as a congressional leader on veterans issues and the Veterans Committee, you've worked in a very bipartisan way with Senator John McCain and others on veterans issues.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Is the right contour of the fight, the way she's talking about this issue?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let me agree.

speaker: SANDERS
text: You know, as the secretary knows, I chaired -- I had the privilege and the honor of chairing the Senate Committee on Veterans' Affairs.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And it is interesting to me, you know, Republicans give a lot of speeches about how much they love veterans.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I work with the American Legion, the VFW, the DAV, the Vietnam Vets, and virtually every veterans organization to put together the most comprehensive piece of the veterans legislation in the modern history of America.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's what I did.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And I brought it to the floor of the Senate.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Every Democrat voted for it, I got two Republicans.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We ended up with 56 votes and I couldn't get the 60 votes that I needed.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That is pathetic.

speaker: SANDERS
text: This was legislation supported by all of the veterans organizations, addressing many of the serious problems that veterans face in health care and in how we deliver benefits to them.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So Republicans talk a good game about veterans, but when it came to put money on the line to protect our veterans, frankly, they were not there.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What I did next, Rachel, is I had to retreat a little bit, I had to compromise.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I did work with John McCain.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I did work with Jeff Miller over in the House.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And we put together not the bill that I wanted, but probably the most comprehensive V.A.

speaker: SANDERS
text: health care bill in the modern history of this country.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Secretary Clinton is absolutely right, there are people, Koch brothers among others, who have a group called Concerned Veterans of America, funded by the Koch brothers.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The Koch brothers, by the way, want to destroy Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, every governmental program passed since the 1930s.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Yes, there are people out there who want to privatize it.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The last point that I'd make.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I had a hearing.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I had all of the veterans groups in front of me.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And I said to them, tell me when a veteran gets in to the V.A., understanding there are waiting lines and real problems, when a veteran gets into the system, is the quality of care good?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Without exception, what they said, good, excellent, very good.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We've got to strengthen the V.A.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We do not privatize the V.A.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MADDOW
text: Thank you, Senator.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Senator Sanders, Secretary Clinton, we're going to take another break.

speaker: MADDOW
text: We'll be talking about Social Security and some of those other issues when we come back.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: And we are back.

speaker: TODD
text: We're gonna get into a little bit of election politics, electability, in a little bit.

speaker: TODD
text: Senator Sanders, The Iowa Democratic Party has declared Hillary Clinton the winner of Monday's Iowa caucuses -- narrowest of margins.

speaker: TODD
text: Today, the Des Moines Register has an editorial that calls for the audit of the results, saying, quote, "what happened Monday night at the Democratic caucuses was a debacle, period. The results were too close not to do a complete audit."

speaker: TODD
text: Senator Sanders, do you accept the idea that Hillary Clinton won Iowa?

speaker: TODD
text: And do you -- or do you believe the caucuses are still an open question?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, I agree with the Des Moines Register, but let's not blow this out of proportion.

speaker: SANDERS
text: This is not a -- this is not, like, a winner-take-all thing.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think where we now stand -- correct me if I'm wrong -- you have 22 delegates, I have 20 delegates.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We need 2,500 delegates to win the nomination.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: SANDERS
text: You know, so this is not -- this is not the biggest deal in the world.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We think, by the way, based on talking to our precinct captains, we may have at least two more delegates.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What the Des Moines Register said -- you know, there were coin -- I think there were half a dozen coin flips -- a fairly chaotic type situation.

speaker: SANDERS
text: At the end of the day, no matter how it's recounted, it will break roughly even.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And by the way, I love and respect the caucus process in Iowa.

speaker: SANDERS
text: See, and I don't have to say it, because they voted already.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: SANDERS
text: And I love New Hampshire, too, because you haven't voted, but...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: ... but, look, I think people are blowing this up out of proportion.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But I think we need improvements in the process by which results are determined.

speaker: TODD
text: Secretary Clinton, will you participate in some sort of audit, if that's what the party wants to do?

speaker: TODD
text: You good with that?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Whatever they decide to do, that's fine.

speaker: TODD
text: That's fair enough.

speaker: TODD
text: OK.

speaker: CLINTON
text: All right.

speaker: TODD
text: Good, we move on.

speaker: TODD
text: We're happy with that.

speaker: TODD
text: We have more questions.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Senator -- Senator Sanders, in 1964...

speaker: SANDERS
text: Oh (inaudible).

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: SANDERS
text: See, when you are old, then they go back all these years.

speaker: SANDERS
text: All right.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What have you got?

speaker: MADDOW
text: In 1964, I heard that the Republicans nominated Barry Goldwater, who was the hero of the conservative movement.

speaker: MADDOW
text: He was, however, far to the right of most of that party.

speaker: MADDOW
text: In 1972, the Democrats nominated George McGovern, who was a hero of liberals in the antiwar movement, but he was to the left of his party's mainstream.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Both of those nominees made activists very excited, and they both got destroyed in the general election.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Even Democrats who love you worry about your fate in a general election.

speaker: MADDOW
text: And I know you have good head-to-head polling numbers against Republican frontrunners right now.

speaker: MADDOW
text: We know that.

speaker: MADDOW
text: But do you have a general election strategy that is different than the way you're running right now to try to get the nomination?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, you know, a general election is different than a primary and caucus process.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But let me just say this.

speaker: SANDERS
text: In terms of where we are right now, as you mention, Rachel, in a number of national and state, including New Hampshire.

speaker: SANDERS
text: For example, the last poll I saw -- there may have been a new one -- last one I saw here in New Hampshire, a battleground state, had me defeating Trump by 19; the secretary defeating him by one.

speaker: SANDERS
text: There were also pretty large margins in Iowa and Wisconsin.

speaker: SANDERS
text: These are polls.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Polls go up.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Polls go down.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But here's why I think I will be, if nominated, the strongest candidate.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Democrats win when there is a large voter turnout; when people are excited; when working people, middle class people and young people are prepared to engage in the political process.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Republicans win when people are demoralized and you have a small voter turnout, which by the way is why they love voter suppression.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I believe that our campaign up to now has shown that we can create an enormous amount of enthusiasm from working people, from young people, who will get involved in the political process and which will drive us to a very large voter turnout.

speaker: SANDERS
text: If there is a large voter turnout, not only do we retain the White House, but I think we regain the Senate.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We win governors' chairs up and down the line.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So I believe if you want to retain the White House, if you want to see Democrats do well across the board, I think our campaign is the one that creates the large voter turnout and helps us win.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MADDOW
text: Secretary Clinton, your campaign surrogates, and people who have endorsed you, have suggested that or even said that if Senator Sanders is the nominee, that Democrats will suffer nationwide and the chances will go down of Democrats holding onto the White House.

speaker: MADDOW
text: With him here standing next to you, can you tell us whether or not you believe he would win the general election if he were nominated?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I can only tell you what I believe, and that is that I am the strongest candidate to take it to the Republicans and win in November.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I say that with great -- with great respect for the campaign that Senator Sanders has been running.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I personally am thrilled at the numbers of people, and particularly young people who are coming to support your campaign.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I hope that I will be able to earn their support.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They may not support me now, but I support them and we'll work together.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But what I'm concerned about is the views of many Democrats who know their states, who know how hard it is to win a general election.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And it also will push whoever the nominee is into the spotlight.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've been vetted.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There's hardly anything you don't know about me.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think it's fair to say that whoever is in that position, Senator Sanders or anyone else who might have run, will face the most withering onslaught.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, I think that I am the person who can do all aspects of the job.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think I'm the person best prepared to take the case to the Republicans.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think that at the end of the day, it's not so much electability.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It is who the American people can believe can keep them safe, can get the economy moving again, can get incomes rising, can build on the progressive accomplishments of President Obama.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think that the coalition that President Obama put together to win twice is a coalition that I can put together and add to.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And that's what I'm prepared to...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: TODD
text: We'll stay on this issue.

speaker: TODD
text: We'll stay on this topic.

speaker: TODD
text: Secretary Clinton, just like there are some Democrats that question Senator Sanders' ability in the general election, many Democratic voters that our reporters have been running into in Iowa and New Hampshire, they tell our reporters over and over again they're worried about the emails issue, not because they don't believe your explanation, but because it's a drip-drip, because the cloud is hanging over your head and that it will impact the general election.

speaker: TODD
text: They see your numbers right now and they think it's the email issue as to why you're not polling very well.

speaker: TODD
text: So can you reassure these Democrats that somehow the email issue isn't going to blow up your candidacy if you're the nominee?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Absolutely I can.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, before it was emails, it was Benghazi, and the Republicans were stirring up so much controversy about that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I testified for 11 hours, answered their questions.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They basically said yeah, didn't get her.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We tried.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That was all a political ploy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now, we had a development in the email matter today when it came out that Secretary Powell and close aides to Former Secretary Rice used private e-mail accounts.

speaker: CLINTON
text: and now you have these people in the government who are doing the same thing to Secretary Powell and Secretary Rice's aide they've been doing to me, which is that I never sent or received any classified material.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They are retroactively classifying it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I agree completely with Secretary Powell, who said today this is an absurdity.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so I think the American people will know it's an absurdity.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have absolutely no concerns about it whatsoever.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: All right, Madam Secretary, there is an open -- there is an open FBI investigation into this matter about how you may have handled classified material.

speaker: TODD
text: Are you 100 percent confident that nothing is going to come of this FBI investigation?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I am 100 percent confident.

speaker: CLINTON
text: This is a security review that was requested.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It is being carried out.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It will be resolved.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I have to add if there's going to be a security review about me, there's going to have to be security reviews about a lot of other people, including Republican office holders, because we've got this absurd situation of retroactive classifications.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Honest to goodness, this is -- this just beggars the imagination.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I have absolutely no concerns about it, but we've got to get to the bottom of what's really going on here, and I hope that will happen.

speaker: TODD
text: Well, Senator sanders, you famously at the first debate said you didn't give a darn about her emails; I think you used another (inaudible).

speaker: SANDERS
text: (OFF-MIKE)

speaker: TODD
text: You're right.

speaker: TODD
text: I'm trying to -- it's a -- it's a family hour still right now.

speaker: TODD
text: After 11:00, I'll say it the other way.

speaker: TODD
text: And you mostly have refrained from commenting on it, but recently you called it a very serious issue, and then the other day you said well she's getting slapped with the email controversy.

speaker: TODD
text: Are you -- how are you feeling about these darn emails now?

speaker: SANDERS
text: I am feeling exactly the way I felt at the first debate.

speaker: SANDERS
text: There's a process under way.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I will not politicize it.

speaker: TODD
text: OK.

speaker: TODD
text: Senator Sanders, thank you.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: And by the way -- and by the way, if I may, the secretary probably doesn't know that there's not a day that goes by when I am not asked to attack her on that issue, and I have refrained from doing that and I will continue to refrain from doing that.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MADDOW
text: Senator Sanders, thank you.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Senator, in December, one of your campaign staffers was fired from your campaign for taking voter data essentially from the Clinton campaign.

speaker: MADDOW
text: You apologized for that when the incident was made public.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Your campaign has now been criticized for its operatives essentially impersonating culinary union members wearing union pins in Nevada, and the Nashua Telegraph has complained recently that you falsely implied in an advertisement that they had endorsed you when they did not.

speaker: MADDOW
text: None of these issues obviously is the end of the world, but they all are of a piece.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Are you in some sense losing control of your campaign?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Not losing control of our campaign.

speaker: SANDERS
text: You know, we have hired a whole lot of people in a rapid way and I am familiar with the first two instances and they are unacceptable, and we have apologized and dealt with that.

speaker: SANDERS
text: In terms of the last one, as I understand it, we did not suggest that we had the endorsement of a newspaper.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Newspapers who make endorsements also say positive things about other candidates, and to the best of my knowledge, that is what we did.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So we never said, never said that somebody, a newspaper endorsed us that did not.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What we did say is blah blah blah blah was said by the newspaper.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Just to follow up on that, the title of the ad in question was Endorsement.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But that was only for -- that was not to be on television.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's an important point.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That was just something -- as the secretary knows, you put titles on ads and you send them out, but there was no word in that ad, none, that said that those newspapers had endorsed us.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Secretary Clinton, do you want 30 seconds on that issue?

speaker: CLINTON
text: No.

speaker: MADDOW
text: And with that, we will (inaudible).

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

speaker: MADDOW
text: Welcome back to the University of New Hampshire, and the Democratic candidates' debate.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Secretary Clinton, on the issue of the death penalty, here in New Hampshire, the one person who is on death row is there for killing a police officer.

speaker: MADDOW
text: It's a crime that has caused anguish in this state, both among death penalty opponents and death penalty supporters.

speaker: MADDOW
text: The last time I had the chance to talk with you on this issue, on the death penalty, you said that capital punishment has a place in a very few federal cases, but you also said you would breathe a sigh of relief if the Supreme Court abolished the death penalty nationwide.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Tonight, do you still support capital punishment, even if you do so reluctantly?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yes, I do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And -- you know, what I hope the Supreme Court will do is make it absolutely clear that any state that continues capital punishment either must meet the highest standards of evidentiary (ph) proof of effective assistance of counsel or they cannot continue it because that, to me, is the real dividing line.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have much more confidence in the federal system, and I do reserve it for particularly heinous crimes in the federal system, like terrorism.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have strong feelings about that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I thought it was appropriate after a very thorough trial that Timothy McVeigh received the death penalty for blowing up the Federal Building in Oklahoma City, killing 168 people, including 19 children in a daycare center.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I do for very limited, particularly heinous crimes believe it is an appropriate punishment, but I deeply disagree with the way that too many states are still implementing it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: If it were possible to separate the federal from the state system by the Supreme Court, that would, I think, be an appropriate outcome.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Senator Sanders, you have singled out the death penalty, and Senator Clinton's support for the death penalty, as an issue that makes it hard to consider as progressive in your mind...

speaker: SANDERS
text: ... Look, I hear what the Secretary said, and I understand, but look, there are -- all of us know that we have seen in recent years horrible, horrible crimes.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It's hard to imagine how people can do, bomb, and kill 168 people in Oklahoma City, or do the Boston Marathon bombing, but this is what I believe, and for a couple of reasons.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Number one, too many innocent people, including minorities, African Americans, have been executed when they were not guilty.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's number one.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We have to be very careful about making sure about that.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But, second of all, and maybe, in a deeper reason, of course there are barbaric acts out there.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But, in a world of so much violence and killing, I just don't believe that government itself should be part of the killing.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So, when somebody commits...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: ... Somebody commits any of these terrible crimes that we have seen, you lock them up, and you toss away the key.

speaker: SANDERS
text: They're never going to get out.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But, I just don't' want to see government be part of killing.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's all.

speaker: SANDERS
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MADDOW
text: Another issue related to the proper role of government, and in this case, specifically the role of government between the federal government and the states.

speaker: MADDOW
text: I want to talk for a moment about the issue of Flint, Michigan.

speaker: MADDOW
text: On the Flint lead poisoning disaster, you have both been highly critical of Governor Rick Snyder of Michigan, and how the state in Michigan both caused the lead poisoning problem, and has not acted fast enough to fix it.

speaker: MADDOW
text: You have both been outspoken on that.

speaker: MADDOW
text: The fact is that Michigan though has not fixed it.

speaker: MADDOW
text: There is no door to door delivery of clean water in Flint even today.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Not a single lead pipe has been replaced in Flint, even today.

speaker: MADDOW
text: If the state is failing, would you, Secretary Clinton, would you as President order a federal response to get it right over and above the wishes of the state?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Absolutely.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Absolutely.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, Rachel, you and I have talked about this before.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I thank you for going to Flint to hold that town hall.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I will be in Flint at the Mayor's invitation on Sunday to get an in depth briefing about what is, and is not happening.

speaker: CLINTON
text: This is an emergency.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Everyday that goes by that these people, particularly the children, are not tested so we can know what steps must be taken to try to remediate the effects of the poisoning that they have been living with is a day lost in a child's life.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I know from the work that I've done over so many years, lead, the toxic nature of lead can affect you brain development, your body development, your behavior.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I absolutely believe that what is being done is not sufficient.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We need to be absolutely clear about everything that should be done from today to tomorrow, into the future to try to remedy the terrible burden that the people of Flint are bearing.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That includes fixing their pipes, it includes guaranteeing whatever healthcare and educational embellishments they may need going forward, and I think the federal government has way where it can bill the state of Michigan.

speaker: CLINTON
text: If Michigan won't do it, there have to be ways that we can begin to move, and then make them pay for it, and hold them accountable.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MADDOW
text: Senator Sanders are there things the President could be doing?

speaker: MADDOW
text: President Obama could be ordering, done, right now, in Flint, Michigan that are not being done that you as President would do?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Absolutely.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think the Secretary described the situation appropriately.

speaker: SANDERS
text: You know, I don't go around asking for governor's resignations every day.

speaker: SANDERS
text: In fact, I think I never have in my life.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But I did ask for the resignation of Governor Snyder because his irresponsibility...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: ... was so outrageous.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What we are talking about are children being poisoned.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's what we're talking about.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We don't know, no one knows for sure because they haven't done the appropriate studies, but there's no question that kids' intellectual development may have been impacted.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We don't know how many thousands.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The idea that there has not been a dramatic response is beyond comprehension.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And when you have one of the, I think, significant public health crises of recent years, of course the federal government comes in.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And of course the federal government says, you're not going to be poisoning little kids and impacting their entire lives.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Last point on this.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And I suspect the secretary agrees.

speaker: SANDERS
text: One wonders if this were a white suburban community what kind of response there would have been.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Flint, Michigan, is a poor community.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It is disproportionately African-American and minority.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And what has happened there is absolutely unacceptable.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Senator, thank you.

speaker: TODD
text: Secretary Clinton, let me turn to the issue of trade.

speaker: TODD
text: In the '90s you supported NAFTA.

speaker: TODD
text: But you opposed it when you ran for the president in 2008.

speaker: TODD
text: As secretary of state, you supported TPP, and then -- which, of course, is that trade agreement with a lot of Asian countries, but you now oppose it as you make your second bid for president.

speaker: TODD
text: If elected, should Democrats expect that once you're in office you will then become supportive of these trade agreements again?

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, Chuck, I've only had responsibility for voting for trade agreements as a senator.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I voted a multinational trade agreement when I was senator, the CAFTA agreement, because I did not believe it was in the best interests of the workers of America, of our incomes, and I opposed it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I did hope that the TPP, negotiated by this administration, would put to rest a lot of the concerns that many people have expressed about trade agreements.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I said that I was holding out that hope that it would be the kind of trade agreement that I was looking for.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I waited until it had actually been negotiated because I did want to give the benefit of the doubt to the administration.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Once I saw what the outcome was, I opposed it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now I have a very clear view about this.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to trade with the rest of the world.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We are 5 percent of the world's population.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to trade with the other 95 percent.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And trade has to be reciprocal.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's the way the global economy works.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we have failed to provide the basic safety net support that American workers need in order to be able to compete and win in the global economy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So it's not just what's in the trade agreement that I'm interested in.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I did help to renegotiate the trade agreement that we inherited from President Bush with Korea.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We go the UAW on board because of changes we made.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So there are changes that I believe would make a real difference if they could be achieved, but I do not currently support it as it is written.

speaker: TODD
text: Well, Senator Sanders, I know you want to respond on this, you have never supported a trade deal since you've been in Congress.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Absolutely right.

speaker: TODD
text: But if you do that as president...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: If you do that as president, how are you not essentially letting China, who will do all of these deals around the world, how are you going to prevent China from essentially setting the rules of trade for the world?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Chuck, I believe in trade, but I do not believe in unfettered free trade.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I believe in fair trade which works for the middle class and working families of this country and not just large multinational corporations.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I was not only in opposition to NAFTA -- and this is an area where the secretary and I have disagreements.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I was not only in opposition to NAFTA, I was on the picket line in opposition to NAFTA because I understood -- I don't think this is really rocket science.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We heard all of the people tell us how many great jobs would be created.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I didn't believe that for a second because I understood what the function of NAFTA, CAFTA, PNTR with China, and the TPP is, it's to say to American workers, hey, you are now competing against people in Vietnam who make 56 cents an hour minimum wage.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I don't want American workers to compete against people making 56 cents an hour.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I don't want companies shutting down in America, throwing people out on the street, moving to China, and bringing their products back into this country.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So, do I believe in trade?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Of course, I believe in trade.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But the current trade agreements over the last 30 years were written by corporate America, for corporate America, resulted in the loss of millions of decent-paying jobs, 60,000 factories in America lost since 2001, millions of decent-paying jobs; and also a downward spiral, a race to the bottom where employers say, "Hey, you don't want to take a cut in pay? We're going to China."

speaker: SANDERS
text: Workers today are working longer hours for lower wages.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Trade is one of the reasons for that.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: All right.

speaker: TODD
text: Thank you both.

speaker: TODD
text: We're going to sneak in one more break here, and when we come back we'll squeeze as many questions as we can before we end this thing.

speaker: TODD
text: We'll be right back.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: All right.

speaker: TODD
text: Welcome back here in the final minutes.

speaker: MADDOW
text: The home stretch.

speaker: TODD
text: The home stretch of this only Democratic debate in the final week before the primary.

speaker: TODD
text: Let me start with you, Secretary Clinton, on this question.

speaker: TODD
text: Obviously, President Obama got a lot of ambitious stuff done in his first year and a half.

speaker: TODD
text: You're going to have to make choices.

speaker: TODD
text: And there's a lot of heavy lifts.

speaker: TODD
text: And he made choices.

speaker: TODD
text: He did healthcare and it came at the expense, arguably, of immigration reform.

speaker: TODD
text: Had he put immigration reform first, perhaps that gets done and healthcare doesn't.

speaker: TODD
text: So there are three big lifts that you've talked about: immigration, gun reform, climate change.

speaker: TODD
text: What do you do first?

speaker: TODD
text: Because you know the first one is the one you have the best shot at getting done.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I -- I don't accept that premise, Chuck.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think that we've got so much business we have to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've talked a lot tonight about what we're against -- we're against income inequality.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We're against the abuses of powerful interests.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We're against a lot of things.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm for a lot of things.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I don't want to just stop bad things from happening, I want to start good things from happening.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I believe, if I'm so fortunate to get the nomination, I will begin to work immediately on putting together an agenda, beginning to talk with members of Congress and others about how we can push forward.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to have half a billion more solar panels deployed, the first four years.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to have enough clean energy to power every home the next four years.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want us to keep working on the Affordable Care Act, to get not only to 100 percent coverage, but bring down the costs of prescription drugs and out-of-pocket costs.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to move forward on paid family leave, on early childhood education, I want us to do more for small businesses.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Small businesses have to create most of the jobs, and we're not creating and growing small businesses.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think, if you have a smart agenda, you pick the committees that you know have to begin to work on these various pieces -- because that's the way Congress is set up.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You go through different committees, and you really make a big push in the beginning.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Immigration reform, economic revitalization with manufacturing, with infrastructure -- we put it out there, and we begin to work on an ambitious, big, bold agenda that will actually produce the results that I want to see for our country.

speaker: TODD
text: All right, but Senator Sanders...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TODD
text: ... you've still got to do something first.

speaker: TODD
text: As you know, history said -- shows what you pick first is your best shot at getting, and how you prioritize things.

speaker: SANDERS
text: No, let...

speaker: TODD
text: Immigration reform, for instance, fell by the wayside in the first term because of this.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I am absolutely supportive of comprehensive immigration reform and a path towards citizenship for 11 million people today who are living in the shadows.

speaker: SANDERS
text: All right?

speaker: SANDERS
text: We got to do that.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: But you miss -- when you looked at the issues, you missed two of the most important.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And that is you're not going to accomplish what has to be done for working families and the middle class unless there is campaign finance reform.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: So long as big money interests control the United States Congress, it is gonna be very hard to do what has to be done for working families.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So let me be very clear.

speaker: SANDERS
text: No nominee of mine, if I'm elected president, to the United States Supreme Court will get that nomination unless he or she is loud and clear, and says they will vote to overturn Citizens United.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Secretary Clinton, Republicans, particularly in campaign years, often talk about which departments of government -- which agencies of government they would get rid of if they were elected president.

speaker: MADDOW
text: The EPA, the Department of Education, the Commerce Department, oops -- is -- is there a department of government that you would get rid of?

speaker: MADDOW
text: Or is there a whole new one that you would create?

speaker: CLINTON
text: The answer to both of those is no.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm interested in making what we have work better.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to streamline programs that are duplicative and redundant.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to have a top-to-bottom review about what works and what doesn't work, and be absolutely clear we're getting rid of what doesn't work.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have had the opportunity to run a big agency.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I was very flattered when Henry Kissinger said I ran the State Department better -- better than anybody had run it in a long time.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I have an idea of what it's going to take to make our government work more efficiently.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And when you put together a budget, you have to make a lot of hard decisions, but I think it's not appropriate to say "I'm going to get rid of this, get rid of that" until you have a very good process that gives you the information about what to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I want to add something else, you know, because look, we have so much work to do in our country, and I think it's the greatest work that Americans will be called to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And of course, we have to have people in every community involved in it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to have the political voice, the political grassroots speaking up and speaking out about what we have to try to accomplish in Washington.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we also need to have a very clear set of goals that we are going to achieve, and we need to level with the American people about what they are, what they will cost, what will be expected of our citizenry.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I see as president having a constant dialogue with Americans here's what we're trying to get done, here's why I need your help, here's why you may think comprehensive immigration reform with a path to citizenship isn't something you care about, but I'm telling you it will help fix the labor market, it will bring people out of the shadows --

speaker: MADDOW
text: Thank you, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: CLINTON
text: -- it will actually raise wages.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You have to make all those connections so that you've got people with you every step of the way.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's what I want to do.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Thank you very much.

speaker: MADDOW
text: Thank you.

text: You know, I would note that a lot of folks in the media have a definition of hispanics that you can only be hispanic if you're liberal.

text: That makes sense in the media, but I gotta tell you, one of the things I was most proud of when I ran for Senate here in Texas, I earned 40 percent of the hispanic vote here in Texas.

speaker: CRUZ
text: At the same time, Mitt Romney was getting clobbered with 27 percent of the hispanic vote nationwide.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And, the reason is, as you know, you look at the value sin the hispanic community.

speaker: CRUZ
text: The values in our community are faith, family, patriotism.

speaker: CRUZ
text: You know, we've got the highest rate of military enlistment among hispanics in any demographic in this country.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And, when I campaigned, and I campaigned the same here in Houston or Dallas as I did in the Rio Grande Valley, defending conservative principles, defending judeo- Christian principals, telling my father's story.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Telling my Dad's story of coming to America with $100 dollars in his underwear, not speaking English, washing dishes, having hopes and dreams for the American dream.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And, the truth is the Obama-Clinton economy has done enormous damage to the hispanic community.

speaker: CRUZ
text: It is not working in the hispanic community, and I...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (BELL RINGING)

speaker: CRUZ
text: ... fighting so that everyone who is struggling in the hispanic community and beyond will have a fair and even shake at the American dream.

speaker: RUBIO
text: I'm sorry I was mentioned...

speaker: CELESTE
text: Governor Kasich.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Maria I was mentioned in that.

speaker: RUBIO
text: I was mentioned in that statement.

speaker: CELESTE
text: Governor Kasich, after the...

speaker: RUBIO
text: I was mentioned -- just because of the hispanic -- and I'll be brief.

speaker: RUBIO
text: A couple points, number one, I do think it's amazing that on this stage tonight there are two descendants of Cuban origin, and an African American.

speaker: RUBIO
text: We are the party of diversity, not the Democratic party.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CHEERING)

speaker: RUBIO
text: And, the second point I would make is that we have to move past this idea that somehow the hispanic community only cares about immigration.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Yes, it's an important issue because we know and love people that have been impacted by it.

speaker: RUBIO
text: But, I'm going to tell you that the most powerful sentiment in the hispanic community, as it is in every immigrant community, is the burning desire to leave your children better off than yourself...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (BELL RINGING)

speaker: RUBIO
text: ... and, you can only do that through free enterprise.

speaker: RUBIO
text: That's what we stand for, not socialism like Bernie Sanders, and increasingly Hillary Clinton.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CELESTE
text: Governor Kasich, after the last presidential election the Republican party realized that in order to win the presidency it needed the support of latinos.

speaker: CELESTE
text: Guidelines as to how to accomplish that were spelled out in an autopsy (ph) report that concluded, and I'm going to quote it, "if hispanic Americans hear that the GOP doesn't want them in the United States they won't pay attention to our next sentence."

speaker: CELESTE
text: So, do you think that your fellow Republican candidates get it?

speaker: KASICH
text: Well, I'm not going to talk about that.

speaker: KASICH
text: I mean, I've got to tell you, I was with this little 12-year-old girl, was at a town hall meeting, and she said, you know, I don't like all this yelling and screaming at the debates.

speaker: KASICH
text: My mother's thinking I might not be able to watch the thing anymore.

speaker: KASICH
text: I think we ought to move beyond that, about what they think.

speaker: KASICH
text: I'm going to tell you what I think.

speaker: KASICH
text: My position on this whole immigration issue has been clear from the beginning.

speaker: KASICH
text: I haven't changed anything with it.

speaker: KASICH
text: And, look, my view is, we need economic growth.

speaker: KASICH
text: Everything starts with economic growth.

speaker: KASICH
text: And how do you get it?

speaker: KASICH
text: Common sense regulations, lower taxes for both business and individuals, and, of course, a fiscal plan that balances the budget.

speaker: KASICH
text: That gives you economic growth.

speaker: KASICH
text: I did it when I was in Washington, as the Budget Committee chairman, negotiating actually with Democrats, that gave us surpluses, economic growth, and the same thing in Ohio.

speaker: KASICH
text: But here's the thing that I believe.

speaker: KASICH
text: Economic growth is not an end unto itself.

speaker: KASICH
text: We have to make sure that everybody has a sense that they can rise.

speaker: KASICH
text: Of course, our friends in the Hispanic community, our friends in the African-American community, the promise of America is that our system, when we follow the right formula, is going to give opportunity for everyone.

speaker: KASICH
text: It's what Jack Kemp used to say.

speaker: KASICH
text: A rising tide lifts all boats, not just some boats, but all boats.

speaker: KASICH
text: And you know what?

speaker: KASICH
text: With me and the Hispanic community, I think they like me.

speaker: KASICH
text: And I appreciate that, because I want them to have the same opportunity that I and my children and my wife and the people we love have had in this country.

speaker: KASICH
text: It's time to solve problems.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CELESTE
text: Dr. Carson, concerning this recommendation of the report, are you, as a candidate, getting it?

speaker: CARSON
text: I didn't hear the first part of the question?

speaker: CELESTE
text: The first part of the question is, there was a report that recommended that in order to approach Hispanics and bring them to vote for the Republican Party, certain things needed to happen.

speaker: CELESTE
text: And one of them was that they shouldn't feel like they were going to get kicked out of the United States, otherwise they wouldn't pay attention to one more sentence from candidates.

speaker: CARSON
text: OK, well, first of all, let me just mention that last year at the NALEO, the National Association for Latino Elected Officials, I was the only one of 17 Republican candidates to go there.

speaker: CARSON
text: And the reason that I don't fear going to an organization like that is because the message that I give is the same message to every group.

speaker: CARSON
text: You know, this is America.

speaker: CARSON
text: And we need to have policies that are -- that give liberty and justice to all people.

speaker: CARSON
text: And that's the way that I have fashioned virtually every policy, looking at that.

speaker: CARSON
text: And I think that's the way the Republican Party generally thinks.

speaker: CARSON
text: We don't pick and choose winners and losers.

speaker: CARSON
text: We are compassionate.

speaker: CARSON
text: But real compassion is providing people with a ladder of opportunity to climb up from a state of dependence and become part of the fabric of America.

speaker: CARSON
text: When we begin to emphasize that, I think we will attract everybody.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TRUMP
text: No.

speaker: CELESTE

text: First of all, I don't believe anything Telemundo says.

speaker: CELESTE
text: You used to say that you love...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Number one.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Number two, I currently employ thousands of Hispanics, and over the years, I've employed tens of thousands of Hispanics.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're incredible people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They know, and the reason I won in Nevada, not only won the big one, but I also won subs, like, as an example, I won with women.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I won with every single category.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I won with men, I won with high-income, low-income, I won with Hispanics.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I got 46 percent.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Nobody else was close.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because they know I'm going to bring jobs back from China, from Japan, from so many other places.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They get it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're incredible people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're incredible workers.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They get it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I've won many of the polls with Hispanics.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I didn't maybe win the Telemundo poll.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But one thing I'm also going to do, I'm going to be getting -- bringing a lot of people in who are Democrats, who are independents, and you're seeing that with the polls, because if you look at anywhere, look at any of the elections, every single election, it has been record-setting.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And the good news is, for the Republican Party, the Democrats are getting very poor numbers in terms of bringing them in.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're getting record-setting numbers.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think I have something to do with that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're getting record-setting numbers.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I won every one -- the three of them that I won, I won with record-setting numbers.

speaker: TRUMP
text: New people are coming into the Republican Party.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We are building a new Republican Party, a lot of new people are coming in.

text: (APPLAUSE)

text: For the record, you have said publicly that you loved Telemundo in the past.

speaker: CELESTE

speaker: CELESTE
text: We have...

speaker: TRUMP
text: I love them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I love them.

speaker: TRUMP

text: We're good friends now.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It was all settled up.

speaker: SYSTEM

speaker: TRUMP
text: Very happy, very happy.

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: BLITZER
text: Mr. Trump, thank you.

speaker: BLITZER
text: I want to turn our attention now to another critically important issue for the American people, the United States Supreme Court, where filling the vacancy left by the late Justice Antonin Scalia has become a major campaign issue.

speaker: BLITZER
text: I want to bring in Salem Radio Network host, Hugh Hewitt.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Hugh?

speaker: HEWITT
text: Thank you, Wolf.

speaker: HEWITT
text: To me, it's the most important issue.

speaker: HEWITT
text: I'll start with you, Senator Cruz.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Do you trust Mr. Trump to nominate conservative justices?

speaker: CRUZ
text: Well, Hugh, I agree with you that it -- Justice Scalia's passing underscores the enormous gravity of this election.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Justice Scalia was someone I knew personally for 20 years; was privileged to be at his funeral this weekend.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And with his passing, the court is now hanging in the balance.

speaker: CRUZ
text: We are one liberal justice away from a five-justice radical leftist majority that would undermine our religious liberty; that would undermine the right to life; and that would fundamentally erase the Second Amendment right to keep and bear arms from the Constitution.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Now, I think the voters of Texas, the voters across Super Tuesday are assessing everyone standing on this -- this stage.

speaker: CRUZ
text: In the past, Republican presidents always promise to nominate strict constitutionalists.

speaker: CRUZ
text: So I'm certain if you took a survey, everyone would say they would do that.

speaker: CRUZ
text: But the reality is, Democrats bat about 1,000.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Just about everyone they put on the court votes exactly as they want.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Republicans have batted worse than 500, more than half of the people we put on the court have been a disaster.

speaker: CRUZ
text: I've spent my whole life fighting to defend the Bill of Rights and the Constitution. I can tell you, for voters that care about life or marriage or religious liberty or the Second Amendment, they're asking the question "Who do you know, beyond a shadow of a doubt, who do you know will nominate principled constitutionalists to the court?"

speaker: CRUZ
text: I give you my word, every justice I nominate will vigorously defend the Bill of Rights for my children and for yours.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: HEWITT
text: Mr. Trump, Senator Cruz mentioned the issue that keeps me up at night, which is religious liberty.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Churches, Catholic and Christian colleges, Catholic adoption agencies -- all sorts of religious institutions fear that Hobby Lobby, if it's repealed, it was a five-four decision, they're going to have to bend their knee and provide morning-after pills.

speaker: HEWITT
text: They fear that if Bob Jones is expanded, they will lose their tax exemption.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Will you commit to voters tonight that religious liberty will be an absolute litmus test for anyone you appoint, not just to the Supreme Court, but to all courts?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Yes, I would.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I've been there.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I've been there very strongly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I do have to say something, and this is interesting and it's not anybody's fault.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's not Ted's fault.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Justice Roberts was strongly recommended and pushed by Ted.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Justice Roberts gave us Obamacare.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Might as well be called Roberts-care.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Two times of the Supreme Court, Justice Roberts approved something that he should have never raised his hand to approve.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we ended up with Obamacare.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That is a rough thing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I know Ted feels badly about it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I think he probably still respects the judge.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But that judge has been a disaster in terms of everything we stand for because there is no way -- no way that he should have approved Obamacare.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, with that being said, these are the things that happen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But Ted very, very strongly pushed Judge Roberts, and Justice Roberts gave us something that we don't want.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Ted Cruz, Senator, the chief justice got Hobby Lobby right, but what do you make of Mr. Cruz's criticism?

speaker: CRUZ
text: Well, listen -- Donald knows that it was George W. Bush who appointed John Roberts.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Yes, it's true, I supported the Republican nominee once he was made.

speaker: CRUZ
text: But I would not have nominated John Roberts.

speaker: CRUZ
text: I would have nominated my former boss, Mike Luttig, who was the strongest proven conservative on the court of appeals.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And I'll tell you, Hugh...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CRUZ
text: ... you know, it's interesting now that Donald promises that he will appoint justices who -- who will defend religious liberty, but this is a man who, for 40 years, has given money to Jimmy Carter, to Joe Biden, to Hillary Clinton, to Chuck Schumer, to Harry Reid.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Nobody who supports far-left liberal Democrats who are fighting for judicial activists can possibly care about having principled constitutionalists on the court.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And what Donald has told us is he will go to Washington...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (BELL RINGS)

speaker: CRUZ
text: ... and cut a deal.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Mr. Trump...

speaker: CRUZ
text: So that means on Supreme Court...

speaker: HEWITT
text: ... can I...

speaker: CRUZ
text: ... he's going to look to cut a deal, rather than fight for someone who won't cut a deal on the Constitution, but will defend it faithfully.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: HEWITT
text: Can I trust you on religious liberty?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, let -- let me -- let me just say -- let me just say this.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look, I watched Ted -- and I respected it, but he gets nowhere -- stand on the Senate floor for a day or two days, and talk and talk and talk.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I watched the other senators laughing and smiling.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And when Ted was totally exhausted, he left the Senate floor, and they went back to work.

speaker: TRUMP
text: OK?

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to have somebody that's going to make deals.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's wonderful to stand up for two days and do that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, Ted's been very critical -- I have a sister who's a brilliant...

speaker: HEWITT
text: Mr. Cruz, will you make a deal about religious liberty?

speaker: TRUMP
text: ... excuse me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's a brilliant judge.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He's been criticizing -- he's been criticizing my sister for signing a certain bill.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know who else signed that bill?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Justice Samuel Alito, a very conservative member of the Supreme Court, with my sister, signed that bill.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So I think that maybe we should get a little bit of an apology from Ted.

speaker: TRUMP
text: What do you think?

speaker: HEWITT
text: Let me -- Senator.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Let me tell you right now, Donald, I will not apologize for a minute for defending the Constitution.

speaker: CRUZ
text: I will not apologize for defending the Bill of Rights.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CRUZ
text: And I find it amazing that your answer to Hugh and to the American people is, on religious liberty, you can't have one of the these crazy zealots that actually believes in it.

speaker: CRUZ
text: You've got to be willing to cut a deal.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And you know, there is a reason why, when Harry Reid was asked, of all the people on this stage, who does he want the most, who does he like the most, Harry Reid said Donald -- Donald Trump.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Why?

speaker: CRUZ
text: Because Donald has supported him in the past, and he knows he can cut a deal with him.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (BELL RINGS)

speaker: CRUZ
text: You know what, Donald...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: HEWITT
text: Senator Rubio.

speaker: CRUZ
text: I don't want a Supreme Court justice that you cut a deal with Harry Reid to undermine religious liberty, because that same justice will also erase the Second Amendment from the Bill of Rights.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TRUMP
text: When you say crazy zealot, are you talking about you?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Crazy zealot -- give me a break.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Senator Rubio, you've heard this exchange on religious liberty.

speaker: HEWITT
text: You have said that religious liberty will trump even the ability of people to stay away from same-sex marriages, not provide flowers, not provide baked goods, et cetera.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Are you satisfied with this exchange on religious liberty?

speaker: RUBIO
text: Well, I think you ask a very important question, because the issue here -- the next president of the United States has to fill this vacancy.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Justice Scalia -- in the history of the republic, there has never been anyone better than him at standing for the principle that the Constitution is not a living and breathing document -- it is supposed to be applied as originally meant.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And the next president of the United States has to be someone that you can trust and believe in to appoint someone just as good as Scalia -- plus there may be at least two other vacancies.

speaker: RUBIO
text: So you ask Mr. Trump to respond and say that he would, and he says that he would.

speaker: RUBIO
text: But the bottom line is, if you look at his record over the last 25 or 30 years, on issue after issue, he has not been on our side.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Now, if he's changed, we're always looking for converts into the conservative movement.

speaker: RUBIO
text: But the bottom line is that, if (ph) you don't have a record there to look at and say, "I feel at peace that when Donald Trump is president of the United States, he's going to be firmly on our side on these issues."

speaker: RUBIO
text: In fact, very recently, he was still defending Planned Parenthood.

speaker: RUBIO
text: He says he's not going to take sides in the Palestinians versus Israel.

speaker: RUBIO
text: These are concerning things.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And so, yes, I have a doubt about whether Donald Trump, if he becomes president, will replace Justice Scalia with someone just like Justice Scalia.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Mr. Trump?

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, let -- let me just say -- let me just say, first of all, I have great respect for Justice Scalia.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I thought he was terrific.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And if you talk about evolving, Ronald Reagan was a somewhat liberal Democrat.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Ronald Reagan evolved into a somewhat strong conservative -- more importantly, he was a great president.

speaker: TRUMP
text: A great president.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As far as Planned Parenthood is concerned, I'm pro-life.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm totally against abortion, having to do with Planned Parenthood.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But millions and millions of women -- cervical cancer, breast cancer -- are helped by Planned Parenthood.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So you can say whatever you want, but they have millions of women going through Planned Parenthood that are helped greatly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I wouldn't fund it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I would defund it because of the abortion factor, which they say is 3 percent.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't know what percentage it is.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They say it's 3 percent.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I would defund it, because I'm pro-life.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But millions of women are helped by Planned Parenthood.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: HEWITT
text: Governor Kasich, back to religious liberty.

speaker: HEWITT
text: You've been a little bit less emphatic.

speaker: HEWITT
text: You've said, same-sex couple approaches a cupcake maker, sell them a cupcake.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Can we trust you as much on religious liberty as the rest of these people?

speaker: KASICH
text: Well, you know, of course.

speaker: KASICH
text: I mean, if -- look, I was involved in just being a pioneer in a new church.

speaker: KASICH
text: Religious institutions should be able to practice the religion that they believe in.

speaker: KASICH
text: No question and no doubt about it.

speaker: KASICH
text: Now, in regard to same-sex marriage, I don't favor it.

speaker: KASICH
text: I've always favored traditional marriage, but, look, the court has ruled and I've moved on.

speaker: KASICH
text: And what I've said, Hugh, is that, look, where does it end?

speaker: KASICH
text: If you're in the business of selling things, if you're not going to sell to somebody you don't agree with, OK, today I'm not going to sell to somebody who's gay, and tomorrow maybe I won't sell to somebody who's divorced.

speaker: KASICH
text: I mean, if you're in the business of commerce, conduct commerce.

speaker: KASICH
text: That's my view.

speaker: KASICH
text: And if you don't agree with their lifestyle, say a prayer for them when they leave and hope they change their behavior.

speaker: KASICH
text: But when it comes to the religious institutions, they are in inviolate in my mind, and I would fight for those religious institutions.

speaker: KASICH
text: And look, I've appointed over a hundred judges as governor.

speaker: KASICH
text: I even appointed adjudge to the Ohio Supreme Court.

speaker: KASICH
text: And you know what they are?

speaker: KASICH
text: They're conservatives.

speaker: KASICH
text: Go check it out.

speaker: KASICH
text: They are conservatives.

speaker: KASICH
text: They don't make the law.

speaker: KASICH
text: They interpret the law.

speaker: KASICH
text: That's all they do.

speaker: KASICH
text: And they stick by the Constitution.

speaker: KASICH
text: So I will do that.

speaker: KASICH
text: But let's just not get so narrow here as to gotcha this or that.

speaker: KASICH
text: I think my position is clear.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Dr. Carson, let me wrap it up with you.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Are their positions clear?

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: HEWITT
text: Are the positions you've heard clear about the First Amendment and the first freedom?

speaker: CARSON
text: Well, first of all, let me just add my praise to Justice Scalia.

speaker: CARSON
text: I first met him when we got an honorary degree together a long time ago.

speaker: CARSON
text: A tremendous wit and intellect.

speaker: CARSON
text: As far as religious freedom is concerned, one of the basic tenets of this nation, and I believe that the Constitution protects all of our rights.

speaker: CARSON
text: And it gives people who believe in same-sex marriage the same rights as everybody else.

speaker: CARSON
text: But what we have to remember is even though everybody has the same rights, nobody get extra rights.

speaker: CARSON
text: So nobody gets to redefine things for everybody else and then have them have to conform to it.

speaker: CARSON
text: That's unfair.

speaker: CARSON
text: And this is the responsibility of Congress to come back and correct what the Supreme Court has done.

speaker: CARSON
text: That's why we have divided government.

speaker: CARSON
text: And we're going to have to encourage them to act in an appropriate way, or we will lose our religious freedom.

speaker: CARSON
text: And as president, I would go through and I would look at what a person's life has been.

speaker: CARSON
text: What have they done in the past?

speaker: CARSON
text: What kind of judgments have they made?

speaker: CARSON
text: What kind of associations do they have?

speaker: CARSON
text: That will tell you a lot more than an interview will tell you.

speaker: CARSON
text: The fruit salad of their life is what I will look at.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you, Dr. Carson.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: All of you want to repeal and replace Obamacare, so let's talk about your plans, specific plans to replace it.

speaker: BLITZER
text: I want to bring in our chief political correspondent, Dana Bash.

speaker: BASH
text: Senator Rubio, you said yesterday, right here in Houston, that Mr. Trump thinks part of Obamacare is pretty good.

speaker: BASH
text: So, he says he is going to repeal Obamacare.

speaker: BASH
text: Are you saying that you're worried he won't?

speaker: RUBIO
text: The individual mandate.

speaker: RUBIO
text: He said he likes the individual mandate portion of it, which I don't believe that should be part of it.

speaker: RUBIO
text: That should not remain there.

speaker: RUBIO
text: I think here's what we need to replace it with.

speaker: RUBIO
text: We need to repeal Obamacare completely and replace it with a system that puts Americans in charge of their health care money again.

speaker: RUBIO
text: If your employer wants to buy health insurance for you, they can continue to do so from any company in America they want to buy it from.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Otherwise, your employers can provide you health care money, tax- free, not treated as income, and you can use that money only for health care, but you can use it to fund health care any way you want, fully fund a health savings account, the combination of a health savings account or a private plan from any company in any state in the country.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And if you don't have that, then you will have a refundable tax credit that provides you health care money to buy your own health care coverage.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And that, I think, is a much better approach than Obamacare, which, by the way, isn't just bad for health care, it's bad for our economy.

speaker: RUBIO
text: It is a health care law that is basically forcing companies to lay people off, cut people's hours, move people to part-time.

speaker: RUBIO
text: It is not just a bad health care law, it is a job-killing law.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And I will repeal it as president and we will replace it with something substantially better for all Americans.

speaker: BASH
text: Governor Kasich, you've said it is, quote, "Un American to deny someone health insurance if they have a preexisting condition."

speaker: BASH
text: Would you leave the individual mandate in place requiring all Americans to purchase insurance?

speaker: KASICH
text: No, I wouldn't.

speaker: KASICH
text: And -- but that doesn't matter when it comes to the issue of preexisting conditions.

speaker: KASICH
text: You don't want any American to lose their house, everything they've saved, because they get sick.

speaker: KASICH
text: Now, I think it is more complicated than what we've heard here tonight.

speaker: KASICH
text: We're actually running significant health reform in my state.

speaker: KASICH
text: I would repeal Obamacare for a variety of reasons.

speaker: KASICH
text: I would take some of the federal resources, combine it with the freed-up Medicaid program, which I would send back to the states, and cover the people who are currently the working poor because we don't want to have tens of millions of Americans losing their health insurance.

speaker: KASICH
text: And then we're driving towards total transparency.

speaker: KASICH
text: If any of you here ever get a hospital bill, it's easier to interpret the Dead Sea scrolls than to understand your hospital bill.

speaker: KASICH
text: The fact is what we need is transparency with hospitals and with the providers.

speaker: KASICH
text: And I'll tell you what we will do.

speaker: KASICH
text: We are actually going to make payments to physicians and to hospitals who actually deliver healthcare with great quality at low prices.

speaker: KASICH
text: We actually are going to make the market work.

speaker: BASH
text: Governor, let me just go back to the original question about the individual mandate.

speaker: BASH
text: In 1994 when you were in Congress, you proposed a plan requiring an individual mandate.

speaker: BASH
text: So what changed?

speaker: KASICH
text: Well, Dana, the Heritage Foundation had this position as well.

speaker: KASICH
text: And when I look at it, I don't think it's tenable.

speaker: KASICH
text: And we don't need to do that.

speaker: KASICH
text: Again, I'm telling you that we are going to -- we have a proposal, a plan that we're enacting now that says if you are a hospital or a doctor and you're providing very high quality at lower prices, below the midpoint -- some charge high, some charge low.

speaker: KASICH
text: If you are below the midpoint, we are going to give you a financial reward for allowing you to provide services that result in high quality for our people at lower pricess.

speaker: KASICH
text: That is the way in which we are going to damp down the rising costs of healthcare.

speaker: KASICH
text: Because if you think about your own deductibles today, they're going higher, higher and higher.

speaker: KASICH
text: And you know what?

speaker: KASICH
text: At some point, people can't afford it.

speaker: KASICH
text: Our plan will work.

speaker: KASICH
text: It uses the market.

speaker: KASICH
text: It uses transparency.

speaker: KASICH
text: It gets the patient in the middle.

speaker: KASICH
text: And guess what?

speaker: KASICH
text: We're actually doing it in my state, the seventh-largest state in the country.

speaker: KASICH
text: And if this will go -- this will go national, we will get our hands on healthcare where you will know what's going on.

speaker: KASICH
text: We will pay for quality, lower prices, and we will begin to see healthcare become affordable in America and where people will also be able to have health insurance, even if they have a preexisting condition.

speaker: KASICH
text: We don't want to throw millions of people out into the cold and not have the health insurance, Dana.

speaker: KASICH
text: So that's really what we're doing.

speaker: KASICH
text: This is not a theory.

speaker: KASICH
text: This is what we are actually doing in our state.

speaker: KASICH
text: We will begin payments next year based on episodes that we have in our lives.

speaker: KASICH
text: If our primary care physicians keep us healthy for a year, with really high quality, guess what?

speaker: KASICH
text: They will get a financial reward.

speaker: KASICH
text: Our primary care physicians need help.

speaker: KASICH
text: They need support.

speaker: KASICH
text: We're losing them.

speaker: KASICH
text: This will allow them to get a reward for doing a great job.

speaker: BASH
text: Governor Kasich, thank you.

speaker: KASICH
text: Thank you.

speaker: BASH
text: Dr. Carson, you have dealt with the sickest of patients.

speaker: BASH

speaker: BASH
text: How would you change Obamacare, but maintain that coverage?

speaker: CARSON
text: Well, first of all, healthcare is not a right.

speaker: CARSON
text: But I do believe it is a responsibility for a responsible society, and we are that.

speaker: CARSON
text: We spend almost twice as much per capita on healthcare as many other nations who have actually much better access than we do.

speaker: CARSON
text: I propose a system in which we use health empowerment accounts, which are like a health savings account with no bureaucrats.

speaker: CARSON
text: And we give it to everybody from birth until death.

speaker: CARSON
text: They can pass it on when they die.

speaker: CARSON
text: We pay for it with the same dollars that we pay for traditional healthcare with.

speaker: CARSON
text: We give people the ability to shift money within their health empowerment account within their family.

speaker: CARSON
text: So dad's $500 short, mom can give it to him or a cousin or uncle.

speaker: CARSON
text: And it makes every family their own insurance carrier with no middle man.

speaker: CARSON
text: It gives you enormous flexibility.

speaker: CARSON
text: And also, you know, if Uncle Joe is smoking like a chimney, everybody's going to hide his cigarettes because they're all interested in what's going on there.

speaker: CARSON
text: Also, the -- your catastrophic healthcare is going to cost a lot less money now because the only thing coming out of that is catastrophic healthcare.

speaker: CARSON
text: So, it's like a homeowners policy with a large deductible, versus a homeowners policy where you want every scratch covered.

speaker: CARSON
text: One costs $1,500 a year; one costs $10,000 a year.

speaker: CARSON
text: You can buy the $1,500 one.

speaker: CARSON
text: That will take care of 75 percent of the people.

speaker: CARSON
text: The people who are indigent, how do we take care of them now?

speaker: CARSON
text: Medicaid.

speaker: CARSON
text: What's the Medicaid budget?

speaker: CARSON
text: Almost $500 billion; almost 80 million people participate, which is way too many, and that will get a lot better when we fix the economy, which I hope we get a chance to talk about.

speaker: CARSON
text: But do the math.

speaker: CARSON
text: Over $5,000 for each man, woman and child, and all -- they will have a lot more flexibility.

speaker: CARSON
text: What could you buy with that?

speaker: CARSON
text: A concierge practice.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you.

speaker: CARSON

speaker: CARSON
text: And let me just finish, because I don't get to talk that much.

speaker: CARSON
text: And, you know, let's...

speaker: SYSTEM

speaker: CARSON

speaker: CARSON

speaker: CARSON
text: It will be such a good program that nobody will want Obamacare after that, and that's probably the best way do it, although if anybody still did, I would still de-fund it.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Mr. Trump, you want to cut taxes more than President Ronald Reagan did, more than President George W. Bush did.

speaker: BLITZER
text: The Independent Tax Foundation says the cost to the country of your proposal would be about $10 trillion, and that takes into account the economic growth that would emerge from your proposed tax cuts.

text: How would you cut $10 trillion over 10 years, but make sure the country isn't saddled with even more debt?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because the country will become a dynamic economy.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We'll be dynamic again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If you look at what's going on, we have the highest taxes anywhere in the world.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We pay more business tax, we pay more personal tax.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have the highest taxes in the world.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's shutting off our economy.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's shutting off our country.

speaker: KASICH
text: Well, I think it takes three things, Wolf.

speaker: KASICH
text: And I've done it.

speaker: KASICH
text: I mean, I -- we got the budget balanced.

speaker: KASICH
text: We cut the capital gains tax.

speaker: KASICH
text: You see, in order to get this economy moving again, you have to grow the economy, and you have to restrain the spending.

speaker: KASICH
text: And when I was chairman, we cut that capital gains tax and we instituted a significant program to get to balance.

speaker: KASICH
text: We had a balanced budget four years in a row, had to take on every interest group in Washington -- every single one of them -- and we paid down a half a trillion of the national debt.

speaker: KASICH
text: And why do you do it?

speaker: KASICH
text: Because you want job growth.

speaker: KASICH
text: If you don't have regulatory reform, common-sense regulations, reasonable tax cuts, which I have, and a fiscal plan, you won't get there.

text: Now, I -- I inherited an an $8 billion hole in Ohio, I have common-sense regulations, I have tax cuts -- the biggest of any governor in the country -- and we have a fiscal plan.

speaker: KASICH

speaker: KASICH
text: It's innovating -- it's producing a better product at, frankly, a lower price.

speaker: KASICH

speaker: KASICH

speaker: KASICH
text: And, look -- I've got a plan to take to Washington, and I will have it there in the first hundred days, and it will include shifting welfare, education, transportation, Medicaid and job training back to us, so we can begin, in the states, to be the laboratories of innovation.

speaker: KASICH

speaker: KASICH

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I can't do that as well -- as a negotiator, I cannot do that as well if I'm taking big, big sides.

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: KASICH
text: Our allies are not sure what to make of us, and our enemies are moving.

speaker: KASICH

speaker: KASICH

speaker: KASICH

speaker: KASICH

speaker: BLITZER
text: But Senator Rubio, what's wrong with the U.S. being an honest broker in a negotiation, as Mr. Trump is proposing?

text: But, look, here's what I think we ought to do -- like, immediately.

text: And, we've been kicking the can down the road on this for, I don't know, 15 years.

text: We should be intercepting the ships that are leaving North Korea so they're not selling this material, or this technology, or giving it to someone else.

speaker: KASICH
text: They are the key to being able to settle this situation.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So It's a meaningless ceasefire.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I love the idea of a ceasefire.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I love the idea of -- with a total cessation.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But it's not working, as you know very well.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's not working.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If -- we can do what we want with Russia but nobody else is adhering to it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So I certainly support it, I would certainly love it, but all parties have to be part of it.

text: Senator Cruz, your opinion on the ceasefire.

text: We're certainly hopeful that the violence will cease, but there's reason to be highly skeptical.

text: Russia has enhanced its position because of Obama's weakness in the Middle East, weakness in Syria.

text: And you know, as we're headed to November, we need no nominate a Republican candidate that can lay out a clear difference with both Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton on foreign policy.

text: One of the real challenges with both Donald and Senator Rubio is that they have agreed over and over again with both Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama.

text: So for example, in Libya, both of them agreed with the Obama/Clinton policy of toppling the government in Libya.
