text: That was a disaster.

text: It gave the country over to radical Islamic terrorism and it endangered America.

text: Another example is John Kerry.

text: John Kerry -- Senator Rubio voted to confirm John Kerry as secretary of State.

text: I voted against him.

text: And John Kerry has been the most anti-Israel secretary of State this country has ever seen.

speaker: CRUZ
text: His diplomacy has been a disaster.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And if we nominate someone who agreed with John Kerry, Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton on foreign policy, we're not in a strong position to win the general election.

text: Number one, on the Libya situation, we didn't topple Gadhafi, the Libyan people toppled Gadhafi.

text: And I argued if it takes a long time, you're going to have rebel forces emerge like these radical Islamists to take advantage of the vacuum.

text: Donald is asking to be commander-in-chief.

text: South Korea contributes $800 million a year to that effort.

text: And Japan contributes as well.

text: And here's why our commitment to that regional security is so critical, Donald, because if we walk away from them, both Japan and South Korea will become nuclear weapons powers.

text: They can do that very quickly.

text: And I assume when he sees that interview, maybe he forgot about it, but I assume Donald will apologize where he sees that he said exactly that.

text: With regard to John Kerry, I will say John Kerry's foreign policy has been a disaster for decades.

text: When the Obama administration canceled civilian air flights into the national of Israel, when Hamas was raining rockets down on them, I publicly asked, is this an economic boycott against Israel?

text: The next day Michael Bloomberg, another New York billionaire, got on a plane, a commercial flight, and flew to Israel from London.

text: Together the heat and light that was put on the State Department was so great that within 36 hours they lifted the ban on air flights into Israel.

text: During that entire battle, and indeed during every battle on Israel the natural question is, where was Donald?

text: If this is something he cares about, why has he supported anti-Israel politicians from Jimmy Carter to Hillary Clinton to John Kerry for four decades?

speaker: CRUZ
text: If you care about Israel, you don't write checks to politicians who are undermining Israel.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Instead you stand and support the national security of America and the alliance with Israel.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: KASICH
text: There's a critical point that needs to be made here.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Governor, Governor, Governor, he attacked Mr. Trump.

text: Mr. Trump has a right to respond.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, look, my response is very simple.

speaker: BLITZER
text: I want to talk -- I want to talk about ISIS right now, and the federal government -- how much best to keep Americans safe from ISIS.

speaker: BLITZER
text: There's a huge battle underway right now between the tech giant Apple and the federal government.

speaker: BLITZER
text: The federal government wants Apple to unlock the phone used by that San Bernardino terrorist to prevent future attacks.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Apple has refused, saying it would compromise the security of all of its customers.

speaker: BLITZER
text: And just this afternoon, they went to court to block the judge's order.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Dana Bash, pick up the questioning.

speaker: BASH
text: Senator Rubio, you say it's complicated, and that, quote, "Apple isn't necessarily wrong to refuse the court order."

speaker: BASH
text: Why shouldn't investigators have everything at their disposal?

speaker: RUBIO
text: No, in fact what I have said is the only thing -- the FBI made this very clear 48 hours ago -- the only thing they are asking of Apple is that Apple allow them to use their own systems in the FBI to try to guess the password of the San Bernardino killer.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Apple initially came out saying, "We're being ordered to create a back door to an encryption device."

speaker: RUBIO
text: That is not accurate.

speaker: RUBIO
text: The only thing they're being asked to do, and the FBI made this very clear about 48 hours ago, is allow us to disable the self- destruct mode that's in the Apple phone so that we can try to guess using our own systems what the password of this killer was.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And I think they should comply with that.

speaker: RUBIO
text: If that's all they're asking for, they are not asking for Apple to create a back door to encryption.

speaker: BASH
text: So just to be clear, you did say on CNN a couple of weeks ago this is a complicated issue; Apple is not necessarily wrong here.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Because at the time, Apple was portraying that the court order was to create a back door to an encryption device.

speaker: BASH
text: But just to be clear -- just to be clear, if you are president, would you instruct your Justice Department to force Apple to comply or not?

speaker: RUBIO
text: To comply with an order that says that they have to allow the FBI the opportunity to try to guess the password?

speaker: BASH
text: Correct.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Absolutely.

speaker: RUBIO
text: That Apple phone didn't even belong to the killer.

speaker: RUBIO
text: It belonged to the killer's employee (sic) who have agreed to allow him to try to do this.

speaker: RUBIO
text: That is all they're asking them to do is to disable the self-destruct mode or the auto-erase mode on one phone in the entire world.

speaker: RUBIO
text: But Apple doesn't want to do it because they think it hurts their brand.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Well, let me tell you, their brand is not superior to the national security of the United States of America.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BASH
text: Senator Cruz, Apple CEO Tim Cook says this would be bad for America.

speaker: BASH

speaker: CRUZ

speaker: CRUZ

speaker: CRUZ
text: In this instance, the order is not put a back door in everyone's cell phone.

speaker: CRUZ
text: If that was the order, that order would be problematic because it would compromise security and safety for everyone.

speaker: CRUZ
text: I would agree with Apple on that broad policy question.

speaker: CRUZ

speaker: CRUZ

speaker: TRUMP

speaker: CELESTE
text: I want to talk to you, Senator Rubio, about Puerto Rico.

speaker: CELESTE
text: As you know, Puerto Rico's in the midst of financial collapse, unable to pay it's debt of $72 billion dollars.

speaker: CELESTE
text: Puerto Rico is asking for bankruptcy protection which would give Puerto Rico, and Puerto Ricans, which are U.S. citizens, you know that -- the tools to restructure the debt.

speaker: CELESTE
text: That is the same debt the other 50 states have.

speaker: CELESTE
text: You oppose granting Puerto Rico that bankruptcy protection.

speaker: CELESTE
text: You say that it is only a last resort measure, but the government of Puerto Rico has said that bankruptcy is it's last resort.

speaker: CELESTE
text: That that's where they are now.

speaker: CELESTE
text: How do you explain this very strong stance to the hundreds of thousands of Puerto Ricans that vote across the U.S. , and particularly in your state of Florida?

speaker: RUBIO
text: Sure, because bankruptcy doesn't work unless you change the way you're operating, or you're going to be bankrupt again.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And, the problem with Puerto Rico is it's economy is not growing.

speaker: RUBIO
text: It has a massive exodus of professionals and others that are leaving to my home state of Florida, and all over the country.

speaker: RUBIO
text: They're coming to the mainland from Puerto Rico because the economy there is not growing, it's too expensive to do business there.

speaker: RUBIO
text: The tax rate is too high.

speaker: RUBIO
text: The government regulations are too extensive.

speaker: RUBIO
text: This year alone, with all the problems they're having, they barely cut their budget from one year to the next.

speaker: RUBIO
text: So, I think the leadership on the island has to show their willingness to get their house in order and put in place measures allow the economy there to grow again.

speaker: RUBIO
text: If the economy of Puerto Rico does not grow they will never generate the revenue to pay this debt, or the billions of dollars in unfunded liabilities that they have on their books of promises they've made to future generations to make payments.

speaker: RUBIO
text: So, yes, if they do all of those things then we can explore the use of bankruptcy protection, but not as the first resort, which is what they're asking for, because it will not solve the problems on the island and you're going to continue to see hundreds of thousands of people leave that beautiful place, and coming to the mainland.

speaker: RUBIO
text: They're United States citizens, they're obviously entitled to do so, and we welcome them, but we would also prefer to see a Puerto Rico that once again is growing economically, and is robust.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And, the leaders in charge there now are doing a terrible job.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Their previous governor, Louis Fortuno was doing a great job until he barely lost that election to...

text: Senator Cruz.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Washington deals are bankrupting this country.

speaker: CRUZ
text: There are several deal-makers on this stage but there is only one person who has consistently stood up to both parties, fighting for the American people against the Washington deals.

speaker: CRUZ
text: If I'm elected president, on the first day in office I will rescind every single illegal and unconstitutional executive action.

speaker: CRUZ
text: I will instruct the Department of Justice to open an investigation into Planned Parenthood and prosecute any criminal violations.

speaker: CRUZ
text: I will instruct every federal agency that the persecution of religious liberty ends today.

speaker: CRUZ
text: I will rip to shreds the Iranian -- catastrophic Iranian nuclear deal.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And I will begin the process of moving the American embassy in Israel to Jerusalem.

speaker: CRUZ
text: We will repeal Obamacare, abolish of IRS, secure the border, and bring back jobs.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Mr. Trump.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Thank you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Nobody knows politicians better than I do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're all talk, they're no action, nothing gets done.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I've watched it for years.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Take a look at what's happening to our country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: All of the things that I've been talking about, whether it's trade, whether it's building up our depleted military, whether it's taking care of our vets, whether it's getting rid of Common Core, which is a disaster, or knocking out Obamacare and coming up with something so much better, I will get it done.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Politicians will never, ever get it done.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we will make America great again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Thank you.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Mr. Trump, thank you.

speaker: BLITZER
text: And thanks to each of the candidates, on behalf of everyone here at CNN and Telemundo.

speaker: BLITZER
text: We also want to thank the Republican National Committee and the University of Houston.

speaker: BLITZER
text: My thanks also to Hugh Hewitt, Maria Celeste, and Dana Bash.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Super Tuesday is only five days away.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Secretary Clinton and Senator Sanders, you can now move to your lecterns while I explain a few ground rules.

speaker: BLITZER
text: As moderator, I'll guide the discussion, asking questions and follow-ups.

speaker: BLITZER
text: You'll also get questions from Dana Bash and Errol Louis.

speaker: BLITZER
text: You'll each have one minute and 15 seconds to answer questions, 30 seconds for follow- ups.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Timing lights will signal when your time is up.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Both candidates have agreed to these rules now.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Opening statements, you'll each have two minutes.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Let's begin with Senator Sanders.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS

text: When we began this campaign almost a year ago, we started off at 3 percent in the polls.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We were about 70 points behind Secretary Clinton.

speaker: SANDERS
text: In the last couple of weeks, there were two polls out there that had us ahead.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

text: Of the last nine caucuses and primaries, we have won eight of them, many of them by landslide victories.

text: Over the last year, we have received almost 7 million individual campaign contributions, averaging -- guess what -- $27 apiece, more individual campaign contributions than any candidate in American history at this point in a campaign.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The reason that our campaign has done so well is because we're doing something very radical: We're telling the American people the truth.

speaker: SANDERS

speaker: SYSTEM

text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: SYSTEM

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS (D-VT), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS (D-VT), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS (D-VT), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

speaker: BASH
text: Secretary Clint, the government announced yesterday that five of the biggest banks on Wall Street have failed to develop plans to dismantle themselves in the event of another financial crisis.

speaker: BASH
text: This is the second time in two years those banks neglected to come up with credible plans.

speaker: BASH
text: So, as president, would you call on regulators to start the process of breaking up these banks?

speaker: BASH
text: Something that the law not only allows, but actually explicitly encourages?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Absolutely.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, this is what I've saying for the past year.

speaker: CLINTON
text: No bank is too big to fail, no executive too powerful to jail.

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm glad that Senator Sanders is now joining in talking about Dodd-Frank, because Dodd-Frank sets forth the approach that needs to be taken.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I believe, and I will appoint regulators who are tough enough and ready enough to break up any bank that fails the test under Dodd-Frank.

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: CLINTON

text: The big insurance companies, the hedge funds, something that I have been arguing for now a long time...

text: A few days ago Goldman Sachs formally reached a settlement with the United States government for $5 billion dollars.

text: Because I'm not sure that the government should say is you are too big to fail.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator, Senator, you've slammed companies like General Electric and Verizon for moving jobs outside of the United States.

speaker: BLITZER
text: He says you are, quote, "uninformed on this issue" and disconnected from reality.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Given your obvious contempt for large American corporations, how would you as president of the United States be able to effectively promote American businesses around the world?

speaker: SANDERS

text: We're going to turn to another critically important issue right now, guns in America.

speaker: BLITZER
text: But only 1.2 percent of the guns recovered in New York in 2014 were from Vermont.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Are you seriously blaming Vermont, and implicitly Senator Sanders, for New York's gun violence?

speaker: CLINTON
text: No, of course not.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Of course not.

speaker: CLINTON
text: This is -- this is a serious difference between us.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: CLINTON
text: And what I want to start by saying -- it's not a laughing matter -- 90 people on average a day are killed or commit suicide or die in accidents from guns, 33,000 people a year.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I take it really seriously, because I have spent more time than I care to remember being with people who have lost their loved ones.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, yes, we have a problem in America.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We need a president who will stand up against the gun lobby.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We need a president who will fight for commonsense gun safety reforms.

text: Then he doubled down on that in the New York Daily News interview, when asked whether he would support the Sandy Hook parents suing to try to do something to rein in the advertising of the AR-15, which is advertised to young people as being a combat weapon, killing on the battlefield.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He said they didn't deserve their day in court.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I could not disagree more.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, finally, this is the only industry in America, the only one.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That has this kind of special protection.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We hear a lot from Senator Sanders about the greed and recklessness of Wall Street, and I agree.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've got to hold Wall Street accountable...

speaker: BLITZER
text: ... Thank you...

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... Well, what about the greed and recklessness of gun manufacturers and dealers in America?

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE) (CHEERING)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator?

text: Well, the only problem is, Wolf, she didn't answer your question.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Please, go ahead sir.

speaker: SANDERS
text: A statement that was refuted by the governor of the state of Vermont, who was a supporter of hers, who said, yeah, in campaigns people tend to exaggerate.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Here is the fact on guns.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let's talk about guns.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That horrible, horrible Sandy Hook -- what's the word we want to use, murder, assault, slaughter, unspeakable act.

text: Back in 1988, I ran for the United States Congress one seat in the state of Vermont.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I probably lost that election, which I lost by three points, because I was the only candidate running who said, you know what?

speaker: SANDERS
text: We should ban assault weapons, not seen them sold or distributed in the United States of America.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I've got a D-minus voting record from the NRA.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: And, in fact, because I come from a state which has virtually no gun control, I believe that I am the best qualified candidate to bring back together that consensus that is desperately needed in this country.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you, Senator.

speaker: BLITZER

speaker: BLITZER
text: Secretary Clinton, I want you to respond to that, but why did you put out that statement blaming Vermont and its gun policy for some of the death of -- by guns in New York?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, the facts are that most of the guns that end up committing crimes in New York come from out of state.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They come from the states that don't have kind of serious efforts to control guns that we do in New York.

text: But let me say this -- in 1988, as we've heard on every debate occasion, Senator Sanders did run for the Congress and he lost.

text: He came back in 1990 and he won, and during that campaign he made a commitment to the NRA that he would be against waiting periods.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, in fact, in his own book, he talks about his 1990 campaign, and here's what he said.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He clearly was helped by the NRA, because they ran ads against his opponent.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, then he went to the Congress, where he has been a largely very reliable supporter of the NRA.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Voting -- he kept his word to the NRA, he voted against the Brady Bill five times because it had waiting periods in it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Thankfully, enough people finally voted for it to keep guns out of the hands of who should not have them.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator, I want you to respond, but I also want you to respond to this.

text: You recently said you do not think crime victims should be able to sue gun makers for damages.

text: Now, I voted against this gun liability law because I was concerned that in rural areas all over this country, if a gun shop owner sells a weapon legally to somebody, and that person then goes out and kills somebody, I don't believe it is appropriate that that gun shop owner who just sold a legal weapon to be held accountable and be sued.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But, what I do believe is when gun shop owners and others knowingly are selling weapons to people who should not have them -- somebody walks in.

speaker: SANDERS
text: They want thousands of rounds of ammunition, or they want a whole lot of guns, yes, that gun shop owner or that gun manufacturer should be held liable.

speaker: BLITZER
text: So, Senator, do you owe the Sandy Hook families an apology?

speaker: SANDERS

speaker: SANDERS
text: They have the right to sue, and I support them and anyone else who wants the right to sue.

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: CLINTON
text: This is a -- this is a unique gift given to only one industry in the world by the United States Congress, as Senator Murphy from Connecticut said, we have tougher standards holding toy gun manufacturers and sellers to account than we do for real guns.

speaker: CLINTON

text: And if he can point to any, any incident where that happened, I would love to hear about it.

text: What was really going on, I'll tell you, because it has a lot to do with New York City.

speaker: CLINTON
text: New York City was on the brink of being able to hold manufacturers and dealers accountable through a very carefully crafted legal strategy.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The NRA came to their supporters in the Congress and said, stop it, stop it now, and Senator Sanders joined those who did.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you, Secretary.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator, go ahead.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let me just reiterate -- just reiterate so there is no confusion, decades ago, before it was popular, in a rural state with no gun control, Bernie Sanders said, let's ban assault weapons, not see them distributed in the United States of America.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you, Senator.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Let's turn it over to Errol Lewis, of New York 1 Time Warner Cable News.

speaker: LOUIS
text: Secretary Clinton, the 1994 crime bill that you supported added 100,000 police officers across the country and banned certain assault weapons.

speaker: LOUIS
text: It also imposed tougher prison sentences and eliminated federal funding for inmate education.

speaker: LOUIS
text: Looking at the bill as a whole, do you believe it was a net positive or do you think it was a mistake?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I think that it had some positive aspects to it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And you mentioned some of them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The Violence Against Women Act, which has been a very important piece of legislation, in my opinion.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: And it also did some things which were to provide more opportunities for young people.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So if we were to have the balance sheet on one side, there are some positive actions and changes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: On the other side, there were decisions that were made that now we must revisit and we have to correct.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think that sentences got much too long.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The original idea was not that we would increase sentences for non-violent low-level offenders, but once the federal government did what it did, states piled on.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So we have a problem.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the very first speech I gave in this campaign was about what I will do to reform the criminal justice system and end the over-mass incarceration.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I think that if all of us go and look back at where we were, Senator Sanders voted for the crime bill, and he says the same thing, there were some good things, and things that we have to change and learn from.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So that's how I see it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think we ought to be putting our attention on forging a consensus to make the changes that will divert more people from the criminal justice system to start.

speaker: LOUIS
text: Thank you, Secretary.

speaker: CLINTON
text: To tackle systemic racism and divert people in the beginning.

speaker: LOUIS
text: Now earlier this year, a South Carolina voter told your daughter Chelsea, quote, "I think a lot of African-Americans want to hear, you know what, we made a mistake."

speaker: LOUIS
text: Chelsea said she has heard you apologize, but went on to say that if the voter hadn't heard it then, quote, "it's clearly insufficient."

speaker: LOUIS
text: Do you regret your advocacy for the crime bill?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, look, I supported the crime bill.

speaker: CLINTON
text: My husband has apologized.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He was the president who actually signed it, Senator Sanders...

speaker: LOUIS
text: But what about you, Senator?

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... voted for it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm sorry for the consequences that were unintended and that have had a very unfortunate impact on people's lives.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've seen the results of what has happened in families and in communities.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's why I chose to make my very first speech a year ago on this issue, Errol, because I want to focus the attention of our country and to make the changes we need to make.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I also want people...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... especially I want -- I want white people -- I want white people to recognize that there is systemic racism.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's also in employment, it's in housing, but it is in the criminal justice system, as well.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: LOUIS
text: Senator Sanders, earlier this week at the Apollo Theater in Harlem, you called out President Clinton for defending Secretary Clinton's use of the term super-predator back in the '90s when she supported the crime bill.

speaker: LOUIS
text: Why did you call him out?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Because it was a racist term, and everybody knew it was a racist term.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Look, much of what Secretary Clinton said was right.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We had a crime bill.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I voted for it.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It had the Violence Against Women Act in it.

speaker: SANDERS
text: When as mayor of Burlington, we worked very hard to try to eliminate domestic violence.

speaker: SANDERS
text: This took us a good step forward.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We're talking about the weapon that killed the children in Sandy Hook.

speaker: SANDERS
text: This banned assault weapons, not insignificant.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But where we are today is we have a broken criminal justice system.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We have more people in jail than any other country on Earth.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And in my view, what we have got to do is rethink the system from the bottom on up.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And that means, for a start -- and we don't talk about this.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The media doesn't talk about it -- you got 51 percent of African-American kids today who graduated high school who are unemployed or underemployed.

speaker: SANDERS
text: You know what I think?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Maybe we invest in jobs and education for those kids, not jails and incarceration.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: And I'll tell you what else.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And I'll tell you what else I think.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And that is, we have got -- and this is the difference between the secretary and myself as I understand it.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We have got to have the guts to rethink the so-called war on drugs.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Too many lives... BLITZER: Thank you, Senator.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Too many lives have been destroyed because people possessed marijuana, millions over a 30-year period.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And that is why I believe we should take marijuana out of the federal Controlled Substance Act.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: LOUIS
text: Thank you.

speaker: LOUIS
text: Thank you.

speaker: LOUIS
text: Let's -- let's get Secretary Clinton's response.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, look, I think that, as Senator Sanders said about what I said, I will say about what he said.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think that we recognize that we have a set of problems that we cannot ignore and we must address.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And that is why I have been promoting for my entire adult life, I think, the idea of investing early in kids, early childhood education, universal pre-K, like what Mayor de Blasio brought to New York.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have got to help more kids get off to a good start.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's why I want a good teacher in a good school for every child, regardless of the ZIP Code that child lives in...

speaker: LOUIS
text: Thank you.

speaker: LOUIS
text: Thank you, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... and to be really focused on how we build ladders of opportunity and tear down these barriers that stand in the way of people getting ahead.

speaker: LOUIS
text: Your time's up, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: LOUIS
text: Senator Sanders, I have a question for you related to this.

speaker: LOUIS
text: So you've said that by the end of your first term as president, the U.S. will no longer lead the world in mass incarceration.

speaker: LOUIS
text: To fulfill that promise, you'd have to release roughly half a million prisoners.

speaker: LOUIS
text: How are you going to do that, since the vast majority of American prisoners are not under federal jurisdiction?

speaker: SANDERS
text: We're going to work with state governments all over this country.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And you know what?

speaker: SANDERS
text: In a very divided Congress, and a very divided politics in America, actually the one area where there is some common ground is conservatives understand that it's insane to be spending $80 billion a year locking up 2.2 million people.

speaker: SANDERS
text: With federal and presidential leadership, we will work with state governments to make sure that people are released from jail under strong supervision, that they get the kind of job training and education they need so they can return to their communities.

speaker: SANDERS
text: On this one, Errol, actually I think you're going to see progressive and conservative support.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We can do it, if we're prepared to be bold.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you, Senator.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you, Secretary.

speaker: BLITZER
text: We have to take a quick commercial break.

speaker: BLITZER
text: We have a lot more questions for Secretary Clinton and Senator Sanders right after this.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Welcome back.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Let's turn to another critically important issue.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator, Secretary, the issue of energy and the environment.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Secretary Clinton, Senator Sanders has said you are in the pocket of the fossil fuel industry.

speaker: BLITZER
text: You say you're sick and tired of him lying about your record.

speaker: BLITZER
text: What are his lies?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, let me start by saying we need to talk about this issue and we should talk about it in terms of the extraordinary threats that climate change pose to our country and our world.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And that's why for the last many years, both in the Senate and as secretary of State, it's been a big part of my commitment to see what could be done.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But there has never been any doubt that when I was a senator, I tried -- I joined with others to try to get rid of the subsidies for big oil.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I have proposed that again, because that's what I think needs to be done as we transition from fossil fuels to clean energy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And everyone who's looked at this independently, "The Washington Post" and others, who give us both hard times when called for on facts, have said that this is absolutely an incorrect false charge.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, we both have relatively small amounts of contributions from people who work for fossil fuel companies.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Best we can tell from the reports that are done.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But, that is not being supported by big oil, and I think it's important to distinguish that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, let's talk about what each of us has proposed to try to combat greenhouse gas emissions and put us on the fastest track possible to clean energy.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you.

speaker: BLITZER
text: We're going to get to that to, but I want you to respond, Senator.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It is one thing, as the Secretary indicated, to talk about workers.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I'm sure I have contributions, you have contributions from workers in every industry in the country.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But, as I understand it, 43 lobbyists for the fossil fuel industry maxed out, gave the maximum amount of money to Secretary Clinton's campaign.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Now, that's not saying -- and, then some people say, well, given the hundreds of millions of dollars she raises it's a small amount.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's true.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But, that does not mean to say that the lobbyists thought she was a pretty good bet on this issue.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Now, what I think is when we look at climate change now, we have got to realize that this is a global environmental crisis of unprecedented urgency.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE) (CHEERING)

speaker: SANDERS
text: And, it is not good enough.

speaker: SANDERS
text: You know, if we, God forbid, were attacked tomorrow the whole country would rise up and say we got an enemy out there and we got to do something about it.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That was what 9/11 was about.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We have an enemy out there, and that enemy is going to cause drought and floods and extreme weather disturbances.

speaker: SANDERS
text: There's going to be international conflict.

speaker: SANDERS
text: (APPLAUSE) I am proud, Wolf, that I have introduced the most comprehensive climate change legislation...

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you...

speaker: SANDERS
text: ... Including a tax on carbon.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Something I don't believe Secretary Clinton supports.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE) (CHEERING)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Secretary Clinton, go ahead and respond.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, let's talk about the global environmental crisis.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Starting in 2009 as your Secretary of State, I worked with President Obama to bring China and India to the table for the very first time, to get a commitment out of them that they would begin to address their own greenhouse gas emissions.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: I continued to work on that throughout the four years as Secretary of State, and I was very proud that President Obama and America led the way to the agreement that was finally reached in Paris with 195 nations committing to take steps to actually make a difference in climate change.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, I was surprised and disappointed when Senator Sanders attacked the agreement, said it was not enough, it didn't go far enough.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, at some point putting together 195 countries, I know a little bit about that, was a major accomplishment...

speaker: BLITZER
text: ... Thank you...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE CHEERING)

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... And, our President led the effort to protect our world and he deserve our appreciation, not our criticism...

speaker: BLITZER
text: ... Go ahead, Senator...

speaker: SANDERS
text: ... Let's talk about that.

speaker: SANDERS
text: When you were Secretary of State, you also worked hard to expand fracking to countries all over the world.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CHEERING)

speaker: SANDERS
text: The issue here -- of course the agreement is a step forward, but you know agreements and I know agreements, there's a lot of paper there.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We've got to get beyond paper right now.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We have got to lead the world in transforming our energy system, not tomorrow, but yesterday.

speaker: SANDERS
text: (APPLAUSE) And, what that means, Wolf, it means having the guts to take on the fossil fuel industry.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Now, I am on board legislation that says, you know what, we ain't going to excavate for fossil fuel on public land.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's not Secretary Clinton's position.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Let us support a tax on carbon...

speaker: BLITZER
text: ... Secretary Clinton...

speaker: SANDERS
text: ... Not Secretary Clinton's position.

speaker: BLITZER
text: ... Go ahead and respond.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I'm a little bewildered about how to respond when you have an agreement which gives you the framework to actually take the action that would have only come about because under the Obama administration in the face of implacable hostility from the Republicans in Congress, President Obama moved forward on gas mileage, he moved forward on the clean power plant.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He has moved forward on so many of the fronts that he could given the executive actions that he was able to take.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, you know, I am getting a little bit -- I'm getting a little bit concerned here because, you know, I really believe that the President has done an incredible job against great odds and deserves to be supported.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE) (CHEERING)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now, it's easy -- it's easy to diagnose the problem.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's harder to do something about the problem.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you, Secretary.

speaker: BLITZER
text: We'll continue on this.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Errol -- Errol Louis, go ahead with your question.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Wolf.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Wolf.

speaker: BLITZER
text: We're going to continue on this.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Errol, go ahead.

speaker: LOUIS
text: OK. Secretary Clinton, as secretary of state, you also pioneered a program to promote fracking around the world, as you described.

speaker: LOUIS
text: Fracking, of course, a way of extracting natural gas.

speaker: LOUIS
text: Now as a candidate for president, you say that by the time you're done with all your rules and regulations, fracking will be restricted in many places around the country.

speaker: LOUIS
text: Why have you changed your view on fracking?

speaker: CLINTON
text: No, well, I don't think I've changed my view on what we need to do to go from where we are, where the world is heavily dependent on coal and oil, but principally coal, to where we need to be, which is clean renewable energy, and one of the bridge fuels is natural gas.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so for both economic and environmental and strategic reasons, it was American policy to try to help countries get out from under the constant use of coal, building coal plants all the time, also to get out from under, especially if they were in Europe, the pressure from Russia, which has been incredibly intense.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So we did say natural gas is a bridge.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We want to cross that bridge as quickly as possible, because in order to deal with climate change, we have got to move as rapidly as we can.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's why I've set big goals.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to see us deploy a half a billion more solar panels by the end of my first term and enough clean energy to provide electricity to every home in America within 10 years.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I have big, bold goals, but I know in order to get from where we are, where the world is still burning way too much coal, where the world is still too intimidated by countries and providers like Russia, we have got to make a very firm but decisive move in the direction of clean energy.

speaker: LOUIS
text: Thank you, Secretary.

speaker: LOUIS
text: All right, Senator?

speaker: SANDERS
text: All right, here is -- here is a real difference.

speaker: SANDERS
text: This is a difference between understanding that we have a crisis of historical consequence here, and incrementalism and those little steps are not enough.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Not right now.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Not on climate change.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Now, the truth is, as secretary of state, Secretary Clinton actively supported fracking technology around the world.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Second of all, right now, we have got to tell the fossil fuel industry that their short-term profits are not more important than the future of this planet.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: And that means -- and I would ask you to respond.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Are you in favor of a tax on carbon so that we can transit away from fossil fuel to energy efficiency and sustainable energy at the level and speed we need to do?

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, I have laid out a set of actions that build on what President Obama was able to accomplish, building on the clean power plan, which is currently under attack by fossil fuels and the right in the Supreme Court, which is one of the reasons why we need to get the Supreme Court justice that President Obama has nominated to be confirmed so that we can actually continue to make progress.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I don't take a back seat to your legislation that you've introduced that you haven't been able to get passed.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to do what we can do to actually make progress in dealing with the crisis.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's exactly what I have proposed.

speaker: LOUIS
text: OK, thank you, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And my approach I think is going to get us there faster without tying us up into political knots with a Congress that still would not support what you are proposing.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: LOUIS
text: Senator Sanders, you've said that climate change is the greatest change to our nation's security.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Secretary Clinton did not answer one simple question.

speaker: LOUIS
text: Excuse me, Senator, Senator, Senator, Senator, Senator...

speaker: SANDERS
text: Are you for a tax on carbon or not?

speaker: LOUIS
text: I have a question for you.

speaker: LOUIS
text: You've said that climate change is the greatest threat to our nation's security.

speaker: LOUIS
text: You've called for a nationwide ban on fracking.

speaker: LOUIS
text: You've also called for phasing out all nuclear power in the U.S.

speaker: LOUIS
text: But wouldn't those proposals drive the country back to coal and oil, and actually undermine your fight against global warming?

speaker: SANDERS
text: No, they wouldn't.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Look, here's where we are.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let me reiterate.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We have a global crisis.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Pope Francis reminded us that we are on a suicide course.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Our legislation understands, Errol, that there will be economic dislocation.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It is absolutely true.

speaker: SANDERS
text: There will be some people who lose their job.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And we build into our legislation an enormous amount of money to protect those workers.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It is not their fault...

speaker: SANDERS
text: It is not their fault that fossil fuels are destroying our climate.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But we have got to stand up and say right now, as we would if we were attacked by some military force, we have got to move urgency -- urgently and boldly.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What does that mean?

speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
text: Senator -- senator, jobs...

speaker: SANDERS
text: Yes?

speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
text: -- jobs are one thing, but with less than 6 percent of all U.S. energy coming from solar, wind and geothermal, and 20 percent of U.S. power coming from nuclear, if you phase out all of that, how do you make up...

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, you don't phase...

speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
text: -- that difference?

speaker: SANDERS
text: -- it all out tomorrow.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And you certainly don't phase nuclear out tomorrow.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But this is what you do do.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: What you do do is say that we are going to have a massive program -- and I had introduced -- introduced legislation for 10 million solar rooftops.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We can put probably millions of people to work retrofitting and weatherizing buildings all over this country.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CHEERING)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Saving -- rebuilding our rail system.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Our mass transit system.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: If we approach this, Errol, as if we were literally at a war -- you know, in 1941, under Franklin Delano Roosevelt, we moved within three years, within three more years to rebuild our economy to defeat Nazism and Japanese imperialism.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That is exactly the kind of approach we need right now.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Lead the world.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you, Senator.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Let's turn to another critically important issue...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: -- the issue of national security and foreign policy.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Secretary Clinton, President Obama says the worst mistake in office that he made over these past seven and a half years was not preparing for Libya after Moammar Qadafi was removed.

speaker: BLITZER
text: You were his secretary of State.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Aren't you also responsible for that?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, let me say I think we did a great deal to help the Libyan people after Qadafi's demise.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And here's what we did.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We helped them hold two successful elections, something that is not easy, which they did very well because they had a pent up desire to try to chart their own future after 42 years of dictatorship.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I was very proud of that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We got rid of the chemical weapons stockpile that Qadafi had, getting it out of Libya, getting it away from militias or terrorist groups.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We also worked to help them set up their government.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We sent a lot of American experts there.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We offered to help them secure their borders, to train a new military.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They, at the end, when it came to security issues, Wolf, did not want troops from any other country, not just us, European or other countries, in Libya.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so we were caught in a very difficult position.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They could not provide security on their own, which we could see and we told them that, but they didn't want to have others helping to provide that security.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the result has been a clash between different parts of the country, terrorists taking up some locations in the country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we can't walk away from that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We need to be working with European and Arab partners...

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: -- with the United Nations in order to continue to try to support them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The Libyan people deserve a chance at democracy and self- government.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I, as president, will keep trying to give that to them

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator, go ahead.

speaker: SANDERS
text: According to "The New York Times.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: for President Obama, this was a pretty tough call, like a 51-49 call, do you overthrow Qadafi, who, of course, was a horrific dictator?

speaker: SANDERS
text: The New York Times" told us it was Secretary Clinton who led the effect for that regime change.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And this is the same type of mentality that supported the war in Iraq.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Look...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: -- Qadafi, Saddam Hussein are brutal, brutal murdering thugs.

speaker: SANDERS
text: No debate about that.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But what we have got to do and what the president was saying is we didn't think thoroughly about what happens the day after you get rid of these dictators.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Regime change often has unintended consequences in Iraq and in Libya right now, where ISIS has a very dangerous foothold.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And I think if you studied the whole history of...

speaker: BLITZER
text: Yes.

speaker: SANDERS
text: -- American involvement in regime change, you see that quite often.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Secretary, we're going to let you respond.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yes, well, I...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: -- I -- I would just point out that there was a vote in the Senate as to whether or not the United States should support the efforts by the Libyan people to protect themselves against the threats, the genocidal threats coming from Gadhafi, and whether we should go to the United Nations to seek Security Council support.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Senator Sanders voted for that, and that's exactly what we did.

speaker: SANDERS
text: No.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: CLINTON
text: We went to the United Nations -- yes, he did.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We went to the United Nations Security Council.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We got support from the Security Council.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we then supported the efforts of our European and Arab allies and partners.

speaker: CLINTON
text: This was a request made to our government by the Europeans and by the Arabs because of their great fear of what chaos in Syria would do to them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And if you want to know what chaos does, not just to the people inside but the people on the borders, look at Syria.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Nobody stood up to Assad and removed him, and we have had a far greater disaster in Syria than we are currently dealing with right now in Libya.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator, go ahead.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Secretary Clinton made this charge in previous debates and just repeating it doesn't make it truer.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What you are talking about is what I think was what they call the unanimous consent, you know what that is, where basically, do we support Libya moving to democracy?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, you know what, I surely have always supported Libya moving to democracy.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But please do not confuse that with your active effort for regime change without contemplating what happened the day after.

text: Totally different issue.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, that isn't...

text: Second of all -- second of all, if I might, in terms of Syria, in terms of Syria...

text: Senator, let her respond to that, then we'll get to that.

text: Go ahead, Secretary.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There was also in that a reference to the Security Council, and I know you're not shy when you oppose something, Senator.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, yes, it was unanimous.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's exactly right, including you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And what we did was to try to provide support for our European and Arab allies and partners.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The decision was the president's.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Did I do the due diligence?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Did I talk to everybody I could talk to?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Did I visit every capital and then report back to the president?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yes, I did.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's what a secretary of state does.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But at the end of the day, those are the decisions that are made by the president to in any way use American military power.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the president made that decision.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, yes, we did try without success because of the Libyans' obstruction to our efforts, but we did try and we will continue to try to help the Libyan people.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you, Secretary.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Go ahead, Senator.

speaker: SANDERS
text: If you listen, you know -- two points.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Number one, yes, 100-0 in the Senate voted for democracy in Libya and I would vote for that again.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But that is very different from getting actively involved to overthrow and bring about regime change without fully understanding what the consequence of that regime change would be.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Second of all, I know you keep referring to Barack Obama all night here, but you in Syria, you in Syria talked about a no-fly zone, which the president certainly does not support, nor do I support because, A, it will cost an enormous sum of money, second of all, it runs the risk of getting us sucked into perpetual warfare in that region.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Thirdly, when we talk about Syria right now, no debate, like Gadhafi, like Saddam Hussein, Assad is another brutal murdering dictator, but right now our fight is to destroy ISIS first, and to get rid of Assad second.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I think Senator Sanders has just reinforced my point.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yes, when I was secretary of state I did urge, along with the Department of Defense and the CIA that we seek out, vet, and train, and arm Syrian opposition figures so that they could defend themselves against Assad.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The president said no.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now, that's how it works.

speaker: CLINTON
text: People who work for the president make recommendations and then the president makes the decision.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I think it's only fair to look at where we are in Syria today.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, yes, I do still support a no-fly zone because I think we need to put in safe havens for those poor Syrians who are fleeing both Assad and ISIS and have some place that they can be safe.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Staying on national security, Dana Bash has a question.

speaker: BASH
text: Senator Sanders, in 1997, you said this about NATO, you said, quote: "It is not the time to continue wasting tens of billions of dollars helping to defend Europe, let alone assuming more than our share of any cost associated with expanding NATO."

speaker: BASH
text: Do you still feel that way?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, what I believe, if my memory is correct here, we spend about 75 percent of the entire cost of the military aspect of NATO.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Given the fact that France has a very good health care system and free public education, college education for their people, the U.K. has a good National Health Service and they also provide fairly reasonable higher education, you know what, yeah, I do believe that the countries of Europe should pick up more of the burden for their defense.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Yes, I do.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BASH
text: And just following up, Senator Sanders, Donald Trump also argues that NATO is unfair economically to the U.S. because America pays a disproportionate share.

speaker: BASH
text: So how is what you say about NATO and your proposal different than his?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, you got to ask -- you got to ask Trump.

speaker: SANDERS
text: All I can tell you is, with a huge deficit, with 47 million people living in poverty, with our inner cities collapsing, yeah, I do think countries like Germany and U.K. and France and European countries whose economy, or at least its standard of living and health care and education, they're doing pretty well.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So I would not be embarrassed as president of the United States to stay to our European allies, you know what, the United States of America cannot just support your economies.

speaker: SANDERS
text: You got to put up your own fair share of the defense burden.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Nothing wrong with that.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BASH
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I support our continuing involvement in NATO.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And it is important to ask for our NATO allies to pay more of the cost.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There is a requirement that they should be doing so, and I believe that needs to be enforced.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But there's a larger question here.

speaker: CLINTON
text: NATO has been the most successful military alliance in probably human history.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It has bound together across the Atlantic countries that are democracies, that have many of the same values and interests, and now we need to modernize it and move it into the 21st century to serve as that head of our defense operations in Europe when it comes to terrorism and other threats that we face.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So...

speaker: BASH
text: But, Madam Secretary... CLINTON: ... yes, of course they should be paying more, but that doesn't mean if they don't we leave, because I don't think that's in America's interests.

speaker: BASH
text: That's going to be part of my -- my question to you is, to that point, there are 28 countries in the alliance, and the United States gives more money to NATO's budget than 21 of those countries combined.

speaker: BASH
text: If they don't agree to pay more, as you suggested, then what would you do as commander-in-chief?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I will stay in NATO.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I will stay in NATO, and we will continue to look for missions and other kinds of programs that they will support.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Remember, NATO was with us in Afghanistan.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Most of the member countries also lost soldiers and civilians in Afghanistan.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They came to our rallying defense after 9/11.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That meant a lot.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, yes, we have to work out the financial aspects of it, but let's not forget what's really happening.

speaker: CLINTON
text: With Russia being more aggressive, making all kinds of intimidating moves toward the Baltic countries, we've seen what they've done in Eastern Ukraine, we know how they want to rewrite the map of Europe, it is not in our interests.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Think of how much it would cost if Russia's aggression were not deterred because NATO was there on the front lines making it clear they could not move forward.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you, Secretary.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator, let's talk about the U.S. relationship with Israel.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator Sanders, you maintained that Israel's response in Gaza in 2014 was, quote, "disproportionate and led to the unnecessary loss of innocent life."

text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: What do you say to those who believe that Israel has a right to defend itself as it sees fit?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, as somebody who spent many months of my life when I was a kid in Israel, who has family in Israel, of course Israel has a right not only to defend themselves, but to live in peace and security without fear of terrorist attack.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That is not a debate.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: But -- but what you just read, yeah, I do believe that.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Israel was subjected to terrorist attacks, has every right in the world to destroy terrorism.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But we had in the Gaza area -- not a very large area -- some 10,000 civilians who were wounded and some 1,500 who were killed.

text: Free Palestine!

speaker: SANDERS

speaker: SANDERS
text: That does not make me anti-Israel.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That paves the way, I think...

speaker: BLITZER
text: ... Thank you, Senator...

speaker: SANDERS

speaker: BLITZER
text: Secretary Clinton, do you agree with Senator Sanders that Israel overreacts to Palestinians attacks, and that in order for there to be peace between Israel and the Palestinians, Israel must, quote, end its disproportionate responses?

text: They do not invite the rockets raining down on their towns and villages.

text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: They do not believe that there should be a constant incitement by Hamas aided and abetted by Iran against Israel.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, I don't know how you run a country when you are under constant threat, terrorist tact, rockets coming at you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You have a right to defend yourself.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON

text: It also does not mean that we should not continue to do everything we can to try to reach a two-state solution, which would give the Palestinians the rights and...

text: ... Thank you...

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... just let me finish.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The rights and the autonomy that they deserve.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, let me say this, if Yasser Arafat had agreed with my husband at Camp David in the Late 1990s to the offer then Prime Minister Barat put on the table, we would have had a Palestinian state for 15 years.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE) (CHEERING)

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you, Senator, go ahead -- go ahead, Senator.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That is not the issue.

speaker: SANDERS

speaker: SANDERS

speaker: SANDERS
text: The question is not does Israel have a right to respond, nor does Israel have a right to go after terrorists and destroy terrorism.

speaker: SANDERS

speaker: SYSTEM

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (AUDIENCE REACTION)

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: BLITZER

speaker: SANDERS

speaker: SANDERS
text: That is what I believe the world wants to us do and that's the kind of leadership that we have got to exercise.

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I have been involved, both as first lady with my husband's efforts, as a senator supporting the efforts that even the Bush administration was undertaking, and as secretary of state for President Obama, I'm the person who held the last three meetings between the president of the Palestinian Authority and the prime minister of Israel.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There were only four of us in the room, Netanyahu, Abbas, George Mitchell, and me.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Three long meetings.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I was absolutely focused on what was fair and right for the Palestinians.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I was absolutely focused on what we needed to do to make sure that the Palestinian people had the right to self-government.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I believe that as president I will be able to continue to make progress and get an agreement that will be fair both to the Israelis and the Palestinians without ever, ever undermining Israel's security.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BLITZER
text: A final word, Senator, go ahead.

speaker: SANDERS
text: There comes a time -- there comes a time when if we pursue justice and peace, we are going to have to say that Netanyahu is not right all of the time.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well...

speaker: BLITZER
text: Secretary.

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: CLINTON
text: If you are from whatever perspective trying to seek peace, trying to create the conditions for peace when there is a terrorist group embedded in Gaza that does not want to see you exist, that is a very difficult challenge.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Senator, go ahead.

speaker: SANDERS

speaker: SANDERS
text: And I think, again, it is a complicated issue and God knows for decades presidents, including President Clinton and others, Jimmy Carter and others have tried to do the right thing.

speaker: SANDERS
text: All that I am saying is we cannot continue to be one-sided.

speaker: SANDERS
text: There are two sides to the issue.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you, Senator.

speaker: BLITZER
text: Thank you, Secretary.

speaker: BLITZER
text: We have to take another quick, quick break.

speaker: BLITZER
text: But much more on the CNN Democratic presidential debate live from Brooklyn, New York.

speaker: BLITZER
text: That is coming up right after this.

speaker: SYSTEM

speaker: SANDERS

speaker: SANDERS
text: For example, we are the only country, major country on Earth, that does not guarantee health care to all people, and yet we end up spending almost three times what the British do, 50 percent more than the French.

speaker: SANDERS

text: Wolf, we have seen in the last 30 years a massive transfer of wealth from the middle class to the top 0.1 percent.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we're now at 90 percent of coverage; I'm going to get us to 100 percent.

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: CLINTON
text: And there is no doubt by those who have analyzed it, progressive economists, health economists, and the like, that it would pose an incredible burden, not just on the budget, but on individuals.

speaker: CLINTON

speaker: CLINTON
