text: And I think the federal government could be in a position where we would offer and provide that.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump...

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'd like to respond to that.

speaker: HOLT
text: Please.

speaker: TRUMP
text: First of all, I agree, and a lot of people even within my own party want to give certain rights to people on watch lists and no- fly lists.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I agree with you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When a person is on a watch list or a no-fly list, and I have the endorsement of the NRA, which I'm very proud of.

speaker: TRUMP
text: These are very, very good people, and they're protecting the Second Amendment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I think we have to look very strongly at no-fly lists and watch lists.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And when people are on there, even if they shouldn't be on there, we'll help them, we'll help them legally, we'll help them get off.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I tend to agree with that quite strongly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I do want to bring up the fact that you were the one that brought up the words super-predator about young black youth.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that's a term that I think was a -- it's -- it's been horribly met, as you know.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think you've apologized for it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I think it was a terrible thing to say.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And when it comes to stop-and-frisk, you know, you're talking about takes guns away.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I'm talking about taking guns away from gangs and people that use them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I don't think -- I really don't think you disagree with me on this, if you want to know the truth.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think maybe there's a political reason why you can't say it, but I really don't believe -- in New York City, stop-and-frisk, we had 2,200 murders, and stop-and-frisk brought it down to 500 murders.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Five hundred murders is a lot of murders.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's hard to believe, 500 is like supposed to be good?

speaker: TRUMP
text: But we went from 2,200 to 500.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it was continued on by Mayor Bloomberg.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it was terminated by current mayor.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But stop-and- frisk had a tremendous impact on the safety of New York City.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Tremendous beyond belief.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So when you say it has no impact, it really did.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It had a very, very big impact.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, it's also fair to say, if we're going to talk about mayors, that under the current mayor, crime has continued to drop, including murders.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So there is...

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, you're wrong.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You're wrong.

speaker: CLINTON
text: No, I'm not.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Murders are up.

speaker: TRUMP
text: All right.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You check it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: New York -- New York has done an excellent job.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I give credit -- I give credit across the board going back two mayors, two police chiefs, because it has worked.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And other communities need to come together to do what will work, as well.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Look, one murder is too many.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But it is important that we learn about what has been effective.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And not go to things that sound good that really did not have the kind of impact that we would want.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Who disagrees with keeping neighborhoods safe?

speaker: CLINTON
text: But let's also add, no one should disagree about respecting the rights of young men who live in those neighborhoods.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so we need to do a better job of working, again, with the communities, faith communities, business communities, as well as the police to try to deal with this problem.

speaker: HOLT
text: This conversation is about race.

speaker: HOLT
text: And so, Mr. Trump, I have to ask you for five...

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'd like to just respond, if I might.

speaker: HOLT
text: Please -- 20 seconds.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'd just like to respond.

speaker: HOLT
text: Please respond, then I've got a quick follow-up for you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I will.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look, the African-American community has been let down by our politicians.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They talk good around election time, like right now, and after the election, they said, see ya later, I'll see you in four years.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The African-American community -- because -- look, the community within the inner cities has been so badly treated.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They've been abused and used in order to get votes by Democrat politicians, because that's what it is.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They've controlled these communities for up to 100 years.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, let me...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I -- I do think...

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I will tell you, you look at the inner cities -- and I just left Detroit, and I just left Philadelphia, and I just -- you know, you've seen me, I've been all over the place.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You decided to stay home, and that's OK.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I will tell you, I've been all over.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I've met some of the greatest people I'll ever meet within these communities.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they are very, very upset with what their politicians have told them and what their politicians have done.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, I...

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think -- I think -- I think Donald just criticized me for preparing for this debate.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, yes, I did.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And you know what else I prepared for?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I prepared to be president.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think that's a good thing.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, for five years, you perpetuated a false claim that the nation's first black president was not a natural-born citizen.

speaker: HOLT
text: You questioned his legitimacy.

speaker: HOLT
text: In the last couple of weeks, you acknowledged what most Americans have accepted for years: The president was born in the United States.

speaker: HOLT
text: Can you tell us what took you so long?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'll tell you very -- well, just very simple to say.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Sidney Blumenthal works for the campaign and close -- very close friend of Secretary Clinton.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And her campaign manager, Patti Doyle, went to -- during the campaign, her campaign against President Obama, fought very hard.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And you can go look it up, and you can check it out.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And if you look at CNN this past week, Patti Solis Doyle was on Wolf Blitzer saying that this happened.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Blumenthal sent McClatchy, highly respected reporter at McClatchy, to Kenya to find out about it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They were pressing it very hard.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She failed to get the birth certificate.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When I got involved, I didn't fail.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I got him to give the birth certificate.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So I'm satisfied with it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'll tell you why I'm satisfied with it.

speaker: HOLT
text: That was...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because I want to get on to defeating ISIS, because I want to get on to creating jobs, because I want to get on to having a strong border, because I want to get on to things that are very important to me and that are very important to the country.

speaker: HOLT
text: I will let you respond.

speaker: HOLT
text: It's important.

speaker: HOLT
text: But I just want to get the answer here.

speaker: HOLT
text: The birth certificate was produced in 2011.

speaker: HOLT
text: You've continued to tell the story and question the president's legitimacy in 2012, '13, '14, '15...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Yeah.

speaker: HOLT
text: as recently as January.

speaker: HOLT
text: So the question is, what changed your mind?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, nobody was pressing it, nobody was caring much about it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I figured you'd ask the question tonight, of course.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But nobody was caring much about it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I was the one that got him to produce the birth certificate.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I think I did a good job.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Secretary Clinton also fought it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, you know -- now, everybody in mainstream is going to say, oh, that's not true.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look, it's true.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Sidney Blumenthal sent a reporter -- you just have to take a look at CNN, the last week, the interview with your former campaign manager.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she was involved.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But just like she can't bring back jobs, she can't produce.

speaker: HOLT
text: I'm sorry.

speaker: HOLT
text: I'm just going to follow up -- and I will let you respond to that, because there's a lot there.

speaker: HOLT
text: But we're talking about racial healing in this segment.

speaker: HOLT
text: What do you say to Americans, people of color who...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, it was very -- I say nothing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I say nothing, because I was able to get him to produce it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He should have produced it a long time before.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I say nothing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But let me just tell you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When you talk about healing, I think that I've developed very, very good relationships over the last little while with the African-American community.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think you can see that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I feel that they really wanted me to come to that conclusion.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I think I did a great job and a great service not only for the country, but even for the president, in getting him to produce his birth certificate.

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, just listen to what you heard.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: CLINTON
text: And clearly, as Donald just admitted, he knew he was going to stand on this debate stage, and Lester Holt was going to be asking us questions, so he tried to put the whole racist birther lie to bed.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But it can't be dismissed that easily.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He has really started his political activity based on this racist lie that our first black president was not an American citizen.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There was absolutely no evidence for it, but he persisted, he persisted year after year, because some of his supporters, people that he was trying to bring into his fold, apparently believed it or wanted to believe it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But, remember, Donald started his career back in 1973 being sued by the Justice Department for racial discrimination because he would not rent apartments in one of his developments to African-Americans, and he made sure that the people who worked for him understood that was the policy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He actually was sued twice by the Justice Department.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So he has a long record of engaging in racist behavior.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the birther lie was a very hurtful one.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, Barack Obama is a man of great dignity.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I could tell how much it bothered him and annoyed him that this was being touted and used against him.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I like to remember what Michelle Obama said in her amazing speech at our Democratic National Convention: When they go low, we go high.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And Barack Obama went high, despite Donald Trump's best efforts to bring him down.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, you can respond and we're going to move on to the next segment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I would love to respond.

speaker: TRUMP
text: First of all, I got to watch in preparing for this some of your debates against Barack Obama.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You treated him with terrible disrespect.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I watched the way you talk now about how lovely everything is and how wonderful you are.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It doesn't work that way.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You were after him, you were trying to -- you even sent out or your campaign sent out pictures of him in a certain garb, very famous pictures.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't think you can deny that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But just last week, your campaign manager said it was true.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So when you tried to act holier than thou, it really doesn't work.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It really doesn't.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, as far as the lawsuit, yes, when I was very young, I went into my father's company, had a real estate company in Brooklyn and Queens, and we, along with many, many other companies throughout the country -- it was a federal lawsuit -- were sued.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We settled the suit with zero -- with no admission of guilt.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It was very easy to do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I notice you bring that up a lot.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And, you know, I also notice the very nasty commercials that you do on me in so many different ways, which I don't do on you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Maybe I'm trying to save the money.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But, frankly, I look -- I look at that, and I say, isn't that amazing?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because I settled that lawsuit with no admission of guilt, but that was a lawsuit brought against many real estate firms, and it's just one of those things.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'll go one step further.

speaker: TRUMP
text: In Palm Beach, Florida, tough community, a brilliant community, a wealthy community, probably the wealthiest community there is in the world, I opened a club, and really got great credit for it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: No discrimination against African- Americans, against Muslims, against anybody.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it's a tremendously successful club.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'm so glad I did it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I have been given great credit for what I did.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'm very, very proud of it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that's the way I feel.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That is the true way I feel.

speaker: HOLT
text: Our next segment is called "Securing America."

speaker: HOLT
text: We want to start with a 21st century war happening every day in this country.

speaker: HOLT
text: Our institutions are under cyber attack, and our secrets are being stolen.

speaker: HOLT
text: So my question is, who's behind it?

speaker: HOLT
text: And how do we fight it?

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton, this answer goes to you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I think cyber security, cyber warfare will be one of the biggest challenges facing the next president, because clearly we're facing at this point two different kinds of adversaries.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There are the independent hacking groups that do it mostly for commercial reasons to try to steal information that they can use to make money.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But increasingly, we are seeing cyber attacks coming from states, organs of states.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The most recent and troubling of these has been Russia.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There's no doubt now that Russia has used cyber attacks against all kinds of organizations in our country, and I am deeply concerned about this.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I know Donald's very praiseworthy of Vladimir Putin, but Putin is playing a really...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: CLINTON
text: tough, long game here.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And one of the things he's done is to let loose cyber attackers to hack into government files, to hack into personal files, hack into the Democratic National Committee.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we recently have learned that, you know, that this is one of their preferred methods of trying to wreak havoc and collect information.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We need to make it very clear -- whether it's Russia, China, Iran or anybody else -- the United States has much greater capacity.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we are not going to sit idly by and permit state actors to go after our information, our private-sector information or our public-sector information.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we're going to have to make it clear that we don't want to use the kinds of tools that we have.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We don't want to engage in a different kind of warfare.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we will defend the citizens of this country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the Russians need to understand that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think they've been treating it as almost a probing, how far would we go, how much would we do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And that's why I was so -- I was so shocked when Donald publicly invited Putin to hack into Americans.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That is just unacceptable.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's one of the reasons why 50 national security officials who served in Republican information -- in administrations...

speaker: HOLT
text: Your two minutes have expired.

speaker: CLINTON
text: have said that Donald is unfit to be the commander- in-chief.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's comments like that that really worry people who understand the threats that we face.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, you have two minutes and the same question.

speaker: HOLT
text: Who's behind it?

speaker: HOLT
text: And how do we fight it?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I do want to say that I was just endorsed -- and more are coming next week -- it will be over 200 admirals, many of them here -- admirals and generals endorsed me to lead this country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That just happened, and many more are coming.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'm very proud of it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: In addition, I was just endorsed by ICE.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They've never endorsed anybody before on immigration.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I was just endorsed by ICE.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I was just recently endorsed -- 16,500 Border Patrol agents.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So when Secretary Clinton talks about this, I mean, I'll take the admirals and I'll take the generals any day over the political hacks that I see that have led our country so brilliantly over the last 10 years with their knowledge.

speaker: TRUMP
text: OK?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because look at the mess that we're in.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look at the mess that we're in.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As far as the cyber, I agree to parts of what Secretary Clinton said.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We should be better than anybody else, and perhaps we're not.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't think anybody knows it was Russia that broke into the DNC.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's saying Russia, Russia, Russia, but I don't -- maybe it was.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, it could be Russia, but it could also be China.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It could also be lots of other people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It also could be somebody sitting on their bed that weighs 400 pounds, OK?

speaker: TRUMP
text: You don't know who broke in to DNC.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But what did we learn with DNC?

speaker: TRUMP
text: We learned that Bernie Sanders was taken advantage of by your people, by Debbie Wasserman Schultz.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look what happened to her.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But Bernie Sanders was taken advantage of.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's what we learned.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, whether that was Russia, whether that was China, whether it was another country, we don't know, because the truth is, under President Obama we've lost control of things that we used to have control over.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We came in with the Internet, we came up with the Internet, and I think Secretary Clinton and myself would agree very much, when you look at what ISIS is doing with the Internet, they're beating us at our own game.

speaker: TRUMP
text: ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So we have to get very, very tough on cyber and cyber warfare.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It is -- it is a huge problem.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have a son.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He's 10 years old.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He has computers.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He is so good with these computers, it's unbelievable.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The security aspect of cyber is very, very tough.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And maybe it's hardly doable.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I will say, we are not doing the job we should be doing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But that's true throughout our whole governmental society.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have so many things that we have to do better, Lester, and certainly cyber is one of them.

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I think there are a number of issues that we should be addressing.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have put forth a plan to defeat ISIS.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It does involve going after them online.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think we need to do much more with our tech companies to prevent ISIS and their operatives from being able to use the Internet to radicalize, even direct people in our country and Europe and elsewhere.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we also have to intensify our air strikes against ISIS and eventually support our Arab and Kurdish partners to be able to actually take out ISIS in Raqqa, end their claim of being a Caliphate.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We're making progress.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Our military is assisting in Iraq.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we're hoping that within the year we'll be able to push ISIS out of Iraq and then, you know, really squeeze them in Syria.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we have to be cognizant of the fact that they've had foreign fighters coming to volunteer for them, foreign money, foreign weapons, so we have to make this the top priority.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I would also do everything possible to take out their leadership.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I was involved in a number of efforts to take out Al Qaida leadership when I was secretary of state, including, of course, taking out bin Laden.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think we need to go after Baghdadi, as well, make that one of our organizing principles.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Because we've got to defeat ISIS, and we've got to do everything we can to disrupt their propaganda efforts online.

speaker: HOLT
text: You mention ISIS, and we think of ISIS certainly as over there, but there are American citizens who have been inspired to commit acts of terror on American soil, the latest incident, of course, the bombings we just saw in New York and New Jersey, the knife attack at a mall in Minnesota, in the last year, deadly attacks in San Bernardino and Orlando.

speaker: HOLT
text: I'll ask this to both of you.

speaker: HOLT
text: Tell us specifically how you would prevent homegrown attacks by American citizens, Mr. Trump?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, first I have to say one thing, very important.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Secretary Clinton is talking about taking out ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We will take out ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, President Obama and Secretary Clinton created a vacuum the way they got out of Iraq, because they got out -- what, they shouldn't have been in, but once they got in, the way they got out was a disaster.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And ISIS was formed.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So she talks about taking them out.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's been doing it a long time.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's been trying to take them out for a long time.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But they wouldn't have even been formed if they left some troops behind, like 10,000 or maybe something more than that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And then you wouldn't have had them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Or, as I've been saying for a long time, and I think you'll agree, because I said it to you once, had we taken the oil -- and we should have taken the oil -- ISIS would not have been able to form either, because the oil was their primary source of income.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And now they have the oil all over the place, including the oil -- a lot of the oil in Libya, which was another one of her disasters.

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I hope the fact-checkers are turning up the volume and really working hard.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Donald supported the invasion of Iraq.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wrong.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That is absolutely proved over and over again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wrong.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wrong.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He actually advocated for the actions we took in Libya and urged that Gadhafi be taken out, after actually doing some business with him one time.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But the larger point -- and he says this constantly -- is George W. Bush made the agreement about when American troops would leave Iraq, not Barack Obama.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the only way that American troops could have stayed in Iraq is to get an agreement from the then-Iraqi government that would have protected our troops, and the Iraqi government would not give that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But let's talk about the question you asked, Lester.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The question you asked is, what do we do here in the United States?

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's the most important part of this.

speaker: CLINTON
text: How do we prevent attacks?

speaker: CLINTON
text: How do we protect our people?

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think we've got to have an intelligence surge, where we are looking for every scrap of information.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I was so proud of law enforcement in New York, in Minnesota, in New Jersey.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, they responded so quickly, so professionally to the attacks that occurred by Rahami.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And they brought him down.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we may find out more information because he is still alive, which may prove to be an intelligence benefit.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So we've got to do everything we can to vacuum up intelligence from Europe, from the Middle East.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That means we've got to work more closely with our allies, and that's something that Donald has been very dismissive of.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We're working with NATO, the longest military alliance in the history of the world, to really turn our attention to terrorism.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We're working with our friends in the Middle East, many of which, as you know, are Muslim majority nations.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Donald has consistently insulted Muslims abroad, Muslims at home, when we need to be cooperating with Muslim nations and with the American Muslim community.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They're on the front lines.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They can provide information to us that we might not get anywhere else.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They need to have close working cooperation with law enforcement in these communities, not be alienated and pushed away as some of Donald's rhetoric, unfortunately, has led to.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I have to respond.

speaker: HOLT
text: Please respond.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The secretary said very strongly about working with -- we've been working with them for many years, and we have the greatest mess anyone's ever seen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You look at the Middle East, it's a total mess.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Under your direction, to a large extent.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But you look at the Middle East, you started the Iran deal, that's another beauty where you have a country that was ready to fall, I mean, they were doing so badly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They were choking on the sanctions.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And now they're going to be actually probably a major power at some point pretty soon, the way they're going.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But when you look at NATO, I was asked on a major show, what do you think of NATO?

speaker: TRUMP
text: And you have to understand, I'm a businessperson.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I did really well.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I have common sense.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I said, well, I'll tell you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I haven't given lots of thought to NATO.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But two things.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Number one, the 28 countries of NATO, many of them aren't paying their fair share.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Number two -- and that bothers me, because we should be asking -- we're defending them, and they should at least be paying us what they're supposed to be paying by treaty and contract.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And, number two, I said, and very strongly, NATO could be obsolete, because -- and I was very strong on this, and it was actually covered very accurately in the New York Times, which is unusual for the New York Times, to be honest -- but I said, they do not focus on terror.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I was very strong.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I said it numerous times.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And about four months ago, I read on the front page of the Wall Street Journal that NATO is opening up a major terror division.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I think that's great.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I think we should get -- because we pay approximately 73 percent of the cost of NATO.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's a lot of money to protect other people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I'm all for NATO.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I said they have to focus on terror, also.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they're going to do that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that was -- believe me -- I'm sure I'm not going to get credit for it -- but that was largely because of what I was saying and my criticism of NATO.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think we have to get NATO to go into the Middle East with us, in addition to surrounding nations, and we have to knock the hell out of ISIS, and we have to do it fast, when ISIS formed in this vacuum created by Barack Obama and Secretary Clinton.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And believe me, you were the ones that took out the troops.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Not only that, you named the day.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They couldn't believe it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They sat back probably and said, I can't believe it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They said...

speaker: CLINTON
text: Lester, we've covered...

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, wait a minute.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've covered this ground.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When they formed, when they formed, this is something that never should have happened.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It should have never happened.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, you're talking about taking out ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But you were there, and you were secretary of state when it was a little infant.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now it's in over 30 countries.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And you're going to stop them?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't think so.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, a lot of these are judgment questions.

speaker: HOLT
text: You had supported the war in Iraq before the invasion.

speaker: HOLT
text: What makes your...

speaker: TRUMP
text: I did not support the war in Iraq.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That is a mainstream media nonsense put out by her, because she -- frankly, I think the best person in her campaign is mainstream media.

speaker: HOLT
text: My question is, since you supported it...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Just -- would you like to hear...

speaker: HOLT
text: why is your -- why is your judgment...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wait a minute.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I was against the war in Iraq.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Just so you put it out.

speaker: HOLT
text: The record shows otherwise, but why -- why was...

speaker: TRUMP
text: The record does not show that.

speaker: HOLT
text: Why was -- is your judgment any...

speaker: TRUMP
text: The record shows that I'm right.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When I did an interview with Howard Stern, very lightly, first time anyone's asked me that, I said, very lightly, I don't know, maybe, who knows?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Essentially.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I then did an interview with Neil Cavuto.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We talked about the economy is more important.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I then spoke to Sean Hannity, which everybody refuses to call Sean Hannity.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I had numerous conversations with Sean Hannity at Fox.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And Sean Hannity said -- and he called me the other day -- and I spoke to him about it -- he said you were totally against the war, because he was for the war.

speaker: HOLT
text: Why is your judgment better than...

speaker: TRUMP
text: And when he -- excuse me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that was before the war started.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Sean Hannity said very strongly to me and other people -- he's willing to say it, but nobody wants to call him.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I was against the war.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He said, you used to have fights with me, because Sean was in favor of the war.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I understand that side, also, not very much, because we should have never been there.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But nobody called Sean Hannity.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And then they did an article in a major magazine, shortly after the war started.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think in '04.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But they did an article which had me totally against the war in Iraq.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And one of your compatriots said, you know, whether it was before or right after, Trump was definitely -- because if you read this article, there's no doubt.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But if somebody -- and I'll ask the press -- if somebody would call up Sean Hannity, this was before the war started.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He and I used to have arguments about the war.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I said, it's a terrible and a stupid thing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's going to destabilize the Middle East.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that's exactly what it's done.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's been a disaster.

speaker: HOLT
text: My reference was to what you had said in 2002, and my question was...

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, no.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You didn't hear what I said.

speaker: HOLT
text: Why is your judgment -- why is your judgment any different than Mrs. Clinton's judgment?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I have much better judgment than she does.

speaker: TRUMP
text: There's no question about that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I also have a much better temperament than she has, you know?

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have a much better -- she spent -- let me tell you -- she spent hundreds of millions of dollars on an advertising -- you know, they get Madison Avenue into a room, they put names -- oh, temperament, let's go after -- I think my strongest asset, maybe by far, is my temperament.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have a winning temperament.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I know how to win.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She does not have a...

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wait.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The AFL-CIO the other day, behind the blue screen, I don't know who you were talking to, Secretary Clinton, but you were totally out of control.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I said, there's a person with a temperament that's got a problem.

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Whew, OK.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Let's talk about two important issues that were briefly mentioned by Donald, first, NATO.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, NATO as a military alliance has something called Article 5, and basically it says this: An attack on one is an attack on all.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And you know the only time it's ever been invoked?

speaker: CLINTON
text: After 9/11, when the 28 nations of NATO said that they would go to Afghanistan with us to fight terrorism, something that they still are doing by our side.

speaker: CLINTON
text: With respect to Iran, when I became secretary of state, Iran was weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They had mastered the nuclear fuel cycle under the Bush administration.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They had built covert facilities.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They had stocked them with centrifuges that were whirling away.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we had sanctioned them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I voted for every sanction against Iran when I was in the Senate, but it wasn't enough.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I spent a year-and-a-half putting together a coalition that included Russia and China to impose the toughest sanctions on Iran.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we did drive them to the negotiating table.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And my successor, John Kerry, and President Obama got a deal that put a lid on Iran's nuclear program without firing a single shot.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's diplomacy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's coalition-building.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's working with other nations.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The other day, I saw Donald saying that there were some Iranian sailors on a ship in the waters off of Iran, and they were taunting American sailors who were on a nearby ship.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He said, you know, if they taunted our sailors, I'd blow them out of the water and start another war.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's not good judgment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That would not start a war.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That is not the right temperament to be commander-in- chief, to be taunted.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the worst part...

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, they were taunting us.

speaker: CLINTON
text: of what we heard Donald say has been about nuclear weapons.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He has said repeatedly that he didn't care if other nations got nuclear weapons, Japan, South Korea, even Saudi Arabia.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It has been the policy of the United States, Democrats and Republicans, to do everything we could to reduce the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He even said, well, you know, if there were nuclear war in East Asia, well, you know, that's fine...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wrong.

speaker: CLINTON
text: have a good time, folks.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's lies.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, in fact, his cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons is so deeply troubling.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That is the number-one threat we face in the world.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And it becomes particularly threatening if terrorists ever get their hands on any nuclear material.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So a man who can be provoked by a tweet should not have his fingers anywhere near the nuclear codes, as far as I think anyone with any sense about this should be concerned.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That line's getting a little bit old, I must say.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I would like to...

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's a good one, though.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It well describes the problem.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's not an accurate one at all.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's not an accurate one.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So I just want to give a lot of things -- and just to respond.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I agree with her on one thing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The single greatest problem the world has is nuclear armament, nuclear weapons, not global warming, like you think and your -- your president thinks.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Nuclear is the single greatest threat.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Just to go down the list, we defend Japan, we defend Germany, we defend South Korea, we defend Saudi Arabia, we defend countries.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They do not pay us.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But they should be paying us, because we are providing tremendous service and we're losing a fortune.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's why we're losing -- we're losing -- we lose on everything.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I say, who makes these -- we lose on everything.

speaker: TRUMP
text: All I said, that it's very possible that if they don't pay a fair share, because this isn't 40 years ago where we could do what we're doing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We can't defend Japan, a behemoth, selling us cars by the million...

speaker: HOLT
text: We need to move on.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, wait, but it's very important.

speaker: TRUMP
text: All I said was, they may have to defend themselves or they have to help us out.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're a country that owes $20 trillion.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They have to help us out.

speaker: HOLT
text: Our last...

speaker: TRUMP
text: As far as the nuclear is concerned, I agree.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It is the single greatest threat that this country has.

speaker: HOLT
text: Which leads to my next question, as we enter our last segment here (inaudible) the subject of securing America.

speaker: HOLT
text: On nuclear weapons, President Obama reportedly considered changing the nation's longstanding policy on first use.

speaker: HOLT
text: Do you support the current policy?

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, you have two minutes on that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I have to say that, you know, for what Secretary Clinton was saying about nuclear with Russia, she's very cavalier in the way she talks about various countries.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But Russia has been expanding their -- they have a much newer capability than we do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have not been updating from the new standpoint.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I looked the other night.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I was seeing B-52s, they're old enough that your father, your grandfather could be flying them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We are not -- we are not keeping up with other countries.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I would like everybody to end it, just get rid of it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I would certainly not do first strike.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think that once the nuclear alternative happens, it's over.

speaker: TRUMP
text: At the same time, we have to be prepared.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I can't take anything off the table.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because you look at some of these countries, you look at North Korea, we're doing nothing there.

speaker: TRUMP
text: China should solve that problem for us.

speaker: TRUMP
text: China should go into North Korea.

speaker: TRUMP
text: China is totally powerful as it relates to North Korea.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And by the way, another one powerful is the worst deal I think I've ever seen negotiated that you started is the Iran deal.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Iran is one of their biggest trading partners.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Iran has power over North Korea.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And when they made that horrible deal with Iran, they should have included the fact that they do something with respect to North Korea.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they should have done something with respect to Yemen and all these other places.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And when asked to Secretary Kerry, why didn't you do that?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why didn't you add other things into the deal?

speaker: TRUMP
text: One of the great giveaways of all time, of all time, including $400 million in cash.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Nobody's ever seen that before.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That turned out to be wrong.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It was actually $1.7 billion in cash, obviously, I guess for the hostages.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It certainly looks that way.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So you say to yourself, why didn't they make the right deal?

speaker: TRUMP
text: This is one of the worst deals ever made by any country in history.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The deal with Iran will lead to nuclear problems.

speaker: TRUMP
text: All they have to do is sit back 10 years, and they don't have to do much.

speaker: HOLT
text: Your two minutes is expired.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they're going to end up getting nuclear.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I met with Bibi Netanyahu the other day.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Believe me, he's not a happy camper.

speaker: HOLT
text: All right.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mrs. Clinton, Secretary Clinton, you have two minutes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, let me -- let me start by saying, words matter.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Words matter when you run for president.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And they really matter when you are president.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I want to reassure our allies in Japan and South Korea and elsewhere that we have mutual defense treaties and we will honor them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It is essential that America's word be good.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so I know that this campaign has caused some questioning and worries on the part of many leaders across the globe.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've talked with a number of them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I want to -- on behalf of myself, and I think on behalf of a majority of the American people, say that, you know, our word is good.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's also important that we look at the entire global situation.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There's no doubt that we have other problems with Iran.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But personally, I'd rather deal with the other problems having put that lid on their nuclear program than still to be facing that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And Donald never tells you what he would do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Would he have started a war?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Would he have bombed Iran?

speaker: CLINTON
text: If he's going to criticize a deal that has been very successful in giving us access to Iranian facilities that we never had before, then he should tell us what his alternative would be.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But it's like his plan to defeat ISIS.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He says it's a secret plan, but the only secret is that he has no plan.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So we need to be more precise in how we talk about these issues.

speaker: CLINTON
text: People around the word follow our presidential campaigns so closely, trying to get hints about what we will do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Can they rely on us?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Are we going to lead the world with strength and in accordance with our values?

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's what I intend to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I intend to be a leader of our country that people can count on, both here at home and around the world, to make decisions that will further peace and prosperity, but also stand up to bullies, whether they're abroad or at home.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We cannot let those who would try to destabilize the world to interfere with American interests and security...

speaker: HOLT
text: Your two minutes is...

speaker: CLINTON
text: to be given any opportunities at all.

speaker: HOLT
text: is expired.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Lester, one thing I'd like to say.

speaker: HOLT
text: Very quickly.

speaker: HOLT
text: Twenty seconds.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I will go very quickly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I will tell you that Hillary will tell you to go to her website and read all about how to defeat ISIS, which she could have defeated by never having it, you know, get going in the first place.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Right now, it's getting tougher and tougher to defeat them, because they're in more and more places, more and more states, more and more nations.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump...

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it's a big problem.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And as far as Japan is concerned, I want to help all of our allies, but we are losing billions and billions of dollars.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We cannot be the policemen of the world.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We cannot protect countries all over the world...

speaker: HOLT
text: We have just...

speaker: TRUMP
text: where they're not paying us what we need.

speaker: HOLT
text: We have just a few final questions...

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she doesn't say that, because she's got no business ability.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We need heart.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We need a lot of things.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But you have to have some basic ability.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And sadly, she doesn't have that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: All of the things that she's talking about could have been taken care of during the last 10 years, let's say, while she had great power.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But they weren't taken care of.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And if she ever wins this race, they won't be taken care of.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, this year Secretary Clinton became the first woman nominated for president by a major party.

speaker: HOLT
text: Earlier this month, you said she doesn't have, quote, "a presidential look."

speaker: HOLT
text: She's standing here right now.

speaker: HOLT
text: What did you mean by that?

speaker: TRUMP
text: She doesn't have the look.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She doesn't have the stamina.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I said she doesn't have the stamina.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I don't believe she does have the stamina.

speaker: TRUMP
text: To be president of this country, you need tremendous stamina.

speaker: HOLT
text: The quote was, "I just don't think she has the presidential look."

speaker: TRUMP
text: You have -- wait a minute.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wait a minute, Lester.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You asked me a question.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Did you ask me a question?

speaker: TRUMP
text: You have to be able to negotiate our trade deals.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You have to be able to negotiate, that's right, with Japan, with Saudi Arabia.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, can you imagine, we're defending Saudi Arabia?

speaker: TRUMP
text: And with all of the money they have, we're defending them, and they're not paying?

speaker: TRUMP
text: All you have to do is speak to them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wait.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You have so many different things you have to be able to do, and I don't believe that Hillary has the stamina.

speaker: HOLT
text: Let's let her respond.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, as soon as he travels to 112 countries and negotiates a peace deal, a cease-fire, a release of dissidents, an opening of new opportunities in nations around the world, or even spends 11 hours testifying in front of a congressional committee, he can talk to me about stamina.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TRUMP
text: The world -- let me tell you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Let me tell you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Hillary has experience, but it's bad experience.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have made so many bad deals during the last -- so she's got experience, that I agree.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TRUMP
text: But it's bad, bad experience.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Whether it's the Iran deal that you're so in love with, where we gave them $150 billion back, whether it's the Iran deal, whether it's anything you can -- name -- you almost can't name a good deal.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I agree.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's got experience, but it's bad experience.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And this country can't afford to have another four years of that kind of experience.

speaker: HOLT
text: We are at -- we are at the final question.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, one thing.

speaker: CLINTON
text: One thing, Lester.

speaker: HOLT
text: Very quickly, because we're at the final question now.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, he tried to switch from looks to stamina.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But this is a man who has called women pigs, slobs and dogs, and someone who has said pregnancy is an inconvenience to employers, who has said...

speaker: TRUMP
text: I never said that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: women don't deserve equal pay unless they do as good a job as men.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I didn't say that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And one of the worst things he said was about a woman in a beauty contest.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He loves beauty contests, supporting them and hanging around them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And he called this woman "Miss Piggy."

speaker: CLINTON
text: Then he called her "Miss Housekeeping," because she was Latina.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Donald, she has a name.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Where did you find this?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Where did you find this?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Her name is Alicia Machado.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Where did you find this?

speaker: CLINTON
text: And she has become a U.S. citizen, and you can bet...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Oh, really?

speaker: CLINTON
text: she's going to vote this November.

speaker: TRUMP
text: OK, good.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Let me just tell you...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, could we just take 10 seconds and then we ask the final question...

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know, Hillary is hitting me with tremendous commercials.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Some of it's said in entertainment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Some of it's said -- somebody who's been very vicious to me, Rosie O'Donnell, I said very tough things to her, and I think everybody would agree that she deserves it and nobody feels sorry for her.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But you want to know the truth?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I was going to say something...

speaker: HOLT
text: Please very quickly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: ... extremely rough to Hillary, to her family, and I said to myself, "I can't do it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I just can't do it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's inappropriate.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's not nice."

speaker: TRUMP
text: But she spent hundreds of millions of dollars on negative ads on me, many of which are absolutely untrue.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're untrue.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they're misrepresentations.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I will tell you this, Lester: It's not nice.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I don't deserve that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But it's certainly not a nice thing that she's done.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's hundreds of millions of ads.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And the only gratifying thing is, I saw the polls come in today, and with all of that money...

speaker: HOLT
text: We have to move on to the final question.

speaker: TRUMP
text: $200 million is spent, and I'm either winning or tied, and I've spent practically nothing.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: HOLT
text: One of you will not win this election.

speaker: HOLT
text: So my final question to you tonight, are you willing to accept the outcome as the will of the voters?

speaker: HOLT
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I support our democracy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And sometimes you win, sometimes you lose.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I certainly will support the outcome of this election.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I know Donald's trying very hard to plant doubts about it, but I hope the people out there understand: This election's really up to you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's not about us so much as it is about you and your families and the kind of country and future you want.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I sure hope you will get out and vote as though your future depended on it, because I think it does.

speaker: HOLT
text: Mr. Trump, very quickly, same question.

speaker: HOLT
text: Will you accept the outcome as the will of the voters?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I want to make America great again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We are a nation that is seriously troubled.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're losing our jobs.

speaker: TRUMP
text: People are pouring into our country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The other day, we were deporting 800 people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And perhaps they passed the wrong button, they pressed the wrong button, or perhaps worse than that, it was corruption, but these people that we were going to deport for good reason ended up becoming citizens.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Ended up becoming citizens.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it was 800.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And now it turns out it might be 1,800, and they don't even know.

speaker: HOLT
text: Will you accept the outcome of the election?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look, here's the story.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I want to make America great again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm going to be able to do it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't believe Hillary will.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The answer is, if she wins, I will absolutely support her.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: HOLT
text: All right.

speaker: HOLT
text: Well, that is going to do it for us.

speaker: HOLT
text: That concludes our debate for this evening, a spirit one.

speaker: HOLT
text: We covered a lot of ground, not everything as I suspected we would.

speaker: HOLT
text: The next presidential debates are scheduled for October 9th at Washington University in St. Louis and October 19th at the University of Nevada Las Vegas.

speaker: HOLT
text: The conversation will continue.

speaker: HOLT
text: A reminder.

speaker: HOLT
text: The vice presidential debate is scheduled for October 4th at Longwood University in Farmville, Virginia.

speaker: HOLT
text: My thanks to Hillary Clinton and to Donald Trump and to Hofstra University for hosting us tonight.

speaker: HOLT
text: Good night, everyone.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Good evening.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: From Longwood University in Farmville, Virginia, and welcome to the first, and only, vice presidential debate of 2016, sponsored by the Commission on Presidential Debates.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I'm Elaine Quijano, anchor at CBSN, and correspondent for CBS News.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: It's an honor to moderate this debate between Senator Tim Kaine and Governor Mike Pence.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Both are longtime public servants who are also proud fathers of sons serving in the U.S. Marines.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: The campaigns have agreed to the rules of this 90-minute debate.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: There will be nine different segments covering domestic and foreign policy issues.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Each segment will begin with a question to both candidates who will each have two minutes to answer.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Then I'll ask follow-up questions to facilitate a discussion between the candidates.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: By coin toss, it's been determined that Senator Kaine will be first to answer the opening question.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: We have an enthusiastic audience tonight.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: They've agreed to only express that enthusiasm once at the end of the debate and right now as we welcome Governor Mike Pence and Senator Tim Kaine.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentlemen, welcome.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: It truly is a privilege to be with both of you tonight.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I'd like to start with the topic of presidential leadership.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Twenty-eight years ago tomorrow night, Lloyd Bentsen said the vice presidential debate was not about the qualifications for the vice presidency, but about how if tragedy should occur, the vice president has to step in without any margin for error, without time for preparation, to take over the responsibility for the biggest job in the world.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: What about your qualities, your skills, and your temperament equip you to step into that role at a moment's notice?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, thank you for being here tonight, and, Governor Pence, welcome.

speaker: KAINE
text: It is so great to be back at Longwood University in Farmville, Virginia.

speaker: KAINE
text: This is a very special place.

speaker: KAINE
text: Sixty-five years ago, a young, courageous woman, Barbara Johns, led a walkout of her high school, Moton High School.

speaker: KAINE
text: She made history by protesting school segregation.

speaker: KAINE
text: She believed our nation was stronger together.

speaker: KAINE
text: And that walkout led to the Brown v. Board of Education decision that moved us down the path toward equality.

speaker: KAINE
text: I am so proud to be running with another strong, history-making woman, Hillary Clinton, to be president of the United States.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'm proud because her vision of stronger together, building an economy that works for all, not just those at the top, being safe in the world not only with a strong military, but also strong alliances to battle terrorism and climate change, and also to build a community of respect, just like Barbara Johns tried to do 65 years ago.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's why I'm so proud to be her running mate.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary told me why she asked me to be her running mate.

speaker: KAINE
text: She said the test of a Clinton administration will not be the signing of a bill or the passage of a bill.

speaker: KAINE
text: It'll be whether we can make somebody's life better, whether we can make a classroom better learning environment for schoolkids or teachers, whether we can make a safer -- it's going to be about results.

speaker: KAINE
text: And she said to me, you've been a missionary and a civil rights lawyer.

speaker: KAINE
text: You've been a city councilman and mayor.

speaker: KAINE
text: You've been a lieutenant governor and governor and now a U.S. senator.

speaker: KAINE
text: I think you will help me figure out how to govern this nation so that we always keep in mind that the success of the administration is the difference we make in people's lives.

speaker: KAINE
text: And that's what I bring to the ticket, that experience having served at all levels of government.

speaker: KAINE
text: But my primary role is to be Hillary Clinton's right-hand person and strong supporter as she puts together the most historic administration possible.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I relish that role.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'm so proud of her.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'll just say this: We trust Hillary Clinton, my wife and I, and we trust her with the most important thing in our life.

speaker: KAINE
text: We have a son deployed overseas in the Marine Corps right now.

speaker: KAINE
text: We trust Hillary Clinton as president and commander-in-chief, but the thought of Donald Trump as commander-in-chief scares us to death.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, first off, thank you, Elaine, and thank you to -- thank you to Norwood University for their wonderful hospitality and the Commission on Presidential Debates.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's deeply humbling for me to be here, to be surrounded by my -- my wonderful family.

speaker: PENCE
text: And, Senator Kaine, it's an honor to be here with you, as well.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I just -- I also want to say -- I want to say thanks to everyone that's looking in tonight, who understands what an enormously important time this is in the life of our nation.

speaker: PENCE
text: For the last seven-and-a-half years, we've seen America's place in the world weakened.

speaker: PENCE
text: We've seen an economy stifled by more taxes, more regulation, a war on coal, and a failing health care reform come to be known as Obamacare, and the American people know that we need to make a change.

speaker: PENCE
text: And so I want to thank all of you for being -- being with us tonight.

speaker: PENCE
text: I also want to thank Donald Trump for making that call and inviting us to be a part of this ticket.

speaker: PENCE
text: I have to tell you, I'm a -- I'm a small-town boy from a place not too different from Farmville.

speaker: PENCE
text: I grew up with a cornfield in my backyard.

speaker: PENCE
text: My grandfather had immigrated to this country when he was about my son's age.

speaker: PENCE
text: My mom and dad built a -- everything that matters in a small town in Southern Indiana.

speaker: PENCE
text: They built a family and -- and a good name and a business.

speaker: PENCE
text: And they raised a family.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I dreamed some day of representing my home town in Washington, D.C., but I -- honestly, Elaine, I never imagined -- never imagined I'd have the opportunity to be governor of the state that I love, let alone be sitting at a table like this in this kind of a position.

speaker: PENCE
text: So to answer your question, I would say I -- I would hope that if -- if the responsibility ever fell to me in this role, that I would meet it with the way that I'm going to meet the responsibility should I be elected vice president of the United States.

speaker: PENCE
text: And that's to bring a lifetime of experience, a lifetime growing up in a small town, a lifetime where I've served in the Congress of the United States, where -- where I've led a state that works in the great state of Indiana, and whatever other responsibilities might follow from this, I -- I would hope and, frankly, I would pray to be able to meet that moment with that -- that lifetime of experience.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine, on the campaign trail, you praised Secretary Clinton's character, including her commitment to public service, yet 60 percent of voters don't think she's trustworthy.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Why do so many people distrust her?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Is it because they have questions about her e-mails and the Clinton Foundation?

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, let me tell you why I trust Hillary Clinton.

speaker: KAINE
text: Here's what people should look at as they look at a public servant.

speaker: KAINE
text: Do they have a passion in their life that showed up before they were in public life?

speaker: KAINE
text: And have they held onto that passion throughout their life, regardless of whether they were in office or not, succeeding or failing?

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary Clinton has that passion.

speaker: KAINE
text: From a time as a kid in a Methodist youth group in the suburbs of Chicago, she has been focused on serving others with a special focus on empowering families and kids.

speaker: KAINE
text: As a civil rights lawyer in the South, with the Children's Defense Fund, first lady of Arkansas and this country, senator, secretary of state, it's always been about putting others first.

speaker: KAINE
text: And that's a sharp contrast with Donald Trump.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump always puts himself first.

speaker: KAINE
text: He built a business career, in the words of one of his own campaign staffers, "off the backs of the little guy."

speaker: KAINE
text: And as a candidate, he started his campaign with a speech where he called Mexicans rapists and criminals, and he has pursued the discredited and really outrageous lie that President Obama wasn't born in the United States.

speaker: KAINE
text: It is so painful to suggest that we go back to think about these days where an African-American could not be a citizen of the United States.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I can't imagine how Governor Pence can defend the insult- driven selfish "me first" style of Donald Trump.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence, let me ask you, you have said Donald Trump is, quote, "thoughtful, compassionate, and steady."

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Yet 67 percent of voters feel he is a risky choice, and 65 percent feel he does not have the right kind of temperament to be president.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Why do so many Americans think Mr. Trump is simply too erratic?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, let me -- let me say first and foremost that, Senator, you and Hillary Clinton would know a lot about an insult- driven campaign.

speaker: PENCE
text: It really is remarkable.

speaker: PENCE
text: At a time when literally, in the wake of Hillary Clinton's tenure as secretary of state, where she was the architect of the Obama administration's foreign policy, we see entire portions of the world, particularly the wider Middle East, literally spinning out of control.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, the situation we're watching hour by hour in Syria today is the result of the failed foreign policy and the weak foreign policy that Hillary Clinton helped lead in this administration and create.

speaker: PENCE
text: The newly emboldened -- the aggression of Russia, whether it was in Ukraine or now they're heavy-handed approach...

speaker: KAINE
text: You guys love Russia.

speaker: KAINE
text: You both have said...

speaker: PENCE
text: their heavy-handed approach.

speaker: KAINE
text: You both have said -- you both have said Vladimir Putin is a better leader than the president.

speaker: PENCE
text: Well...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Well, we're going to get to Russia in just a moment.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: But I do want to get back to the question at...

speaker: PENCE
text: But in the midst -- Elaine, thank you.

speaker: PENCE
text: Thank you.

speaker: PENCE
text: Thank you, Senator, I'll...

speaker: KAINE
text: These guys have praised Vladimir Putin as a great leader.

speaker: KAINE
text: How can that...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Yes, and we will get to that, Senator.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: We do have that coming up here.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: But in the meantime, the questions...

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, Senator, I must have hit a...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: I must have hit a nerve here.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Why the disconnect?

speaker: PENCE
text: Because at a time of great challenge in the life of this nation, where we've weakened America's place in the world, stifled America's economy, the campaign of Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine has been an avalanche of insults.

speaker: PENCE
text: Look, to get to your question about trustworthiness, Donald Trump has built a business through hard times and through good times.

speaker: PENCE
text: He's brought an extraordinary business acumen.

speaker: PENCE
text: He's employed tens of thousands of people in this country.

speaker: KAINE
text: And paid few taxes and lost a billion a year.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: And why the disconnect with your running mate?

speaker: PENCE
text: But there's a -- there's a reason why people question the trustworthiness of Hillary Clinton.

speaker: PENCE
text: And that's because they're paying attention.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, the reality is, when she was secretary of state, Senator, come on.

speaker: PENCE
text: She had a Clinton Foundation accepting contributions from foreign governments.

speaker: KAINE
text: You are Donald Trump's apprentice.

speaker: KAINE
text: Let me talk about this...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: Senator, I think I'm still on my time.

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, I think -- isn't this a discussion?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: This is our open discussion.

speaker: KAINE
text: Yeah, let's talk about the state of...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, let me interrupt -- let me interrupt you and finish my sentence, if I can.

speaker: KAINE
text: Finish your sentence.

speaker: PENCE
text: The Clinton Foundation accepted foreign contributions from foreign governments and foreign donors while she was secretary of state.

speaker: KAINE
text: OK, now I can weigh in.

speaker: KAINE
text: Now...

speaker: PENCE
text: She had a private server...

speaker: KAINE
text: Now, I get to weigh in.

speaker: KAINE
text: Now, let me just say this...

speaker: PENCE
text: that was discovered...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator, you have an opportunity to respond.

speaker: PENCE
text: keep that pay to play process out of the reach of the public.

speaker: KAINE
text: Governor Pence -- Governor Pence doesn't think the world's going so well and he, you know, is going to say it's everybody's fault.

speaker: PENCE
text: Do you?

speaker: KAINE
text: Let me tell you this.

speaker: KAINE
text: When Hillary Clinton became secretary of state, Governor Pence, did you know that Osama bin Laden was alive?

speaker: PENCE
text: Yes.

speaker: KAINE
text: Do you know that we had 175,000 troops deployed in the battlefield in Iraq and Afghanistan?

speaker: KAINE
text: Do you know that Iran was racing toward a nuclear weapon and Russia was expanding its stockpile?

speaker: KAINE
text: Under Secretary Clinton's leadership, she was part of the national team, public safety team that went after and revived the dormant hunt against bin Laden and wiped him off the face of the Earth.

speaker: KAINE
text: She worked to deal with the Russians to reduce their chemical weapons stockpile.

speaker: KAINE
text: She worked a tough negotiation with nations around the world to eliminate the Iranian nuclear weapons program without firing a shot.

speaker: PENCE
text: Eliminate the Iranian nuclear weapons program?

speaker: KAINE
text: Absolutely, without firing a shot.

speaker: KAINE
text: And instead of 175,000 American troops deployed overseas, we now have 15,000.

speaker: PENCE
text: Right and...

speaker: KAINE
text: These are very, very good things.

speaker: PENCE
text: And Iraq has been overrun by ISIS, because Hillary Clinton failed to renegotiate...

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, if you want to put more American troops in Iraq, you can propose that.

speaker: PENCE
text: Hillary Clinton -- Hillary Clinton -- Hillary Clinton failed to renegotiate a status of forces agreement...

speaker: KAINE
text: No, that is incorrect.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's incorrect.

speaker: PENCE
text: And so we removed -- we removed all of our...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentlemen, we'll get to...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: troops from Iraq, and ISIS was able to be conjured up in that vacuum.

speaker: KAINE
text: But I'd like to correct...

speaker: PENCE
text: and overrun vast areas of Iraq.

speaker: KAINE
text: Governor, President Bush said we would leave Iraq at the end of 2011.

speaker: KAINE
text: And, Elaine, Iraq didn't want our troops to stay, and they wouldn't give us the protection for our troops.

speaker: KAINE
text: And guess what?

speaker: KAINE
text: If a nation where our troops are serving does not want us to stay, we're not going to stay without their protection.

speaker: PENCE
text: It was a failure of the secretary of state...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: We need to move on to the next topic, gentlemen.

speaker: KAINE
text: If Governor Pence wants to put more troops back in Iraq, that's...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: There are a lot of people wondering in this country about the economy.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Let's turn to the issue of the economy.

speaker: KAINE
text: OK.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: According to the nonpartisan Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, neither of your economic plans will reduce the growing $19 trillion gross national debt.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: In fact, your plans would add even more to it.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Both of you were governors who balanced state budgets.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Are you concerned that adding more to the debt could be disastrous for the country.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence?

speaker: PENCE
text: I think the fact that -- that under this past administration was of which Hillary Clinton was a part, we've almost doubled the national debt is atrocious.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, I'm very proud of the fact that -- I come from a state that works.

speaker: PENCE
text: The state of Indiana has balanced budgets.

speaker: PENCE
text: We cut taxes, we've made record investments in education and in infrastructure, and I still finish my term with $2 billion in the bank.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's a little bit different than when Senator Kaine was governor here in Virginia.

speaker: PENCE
text: He actually -- he actually tried to raise taxes by about $4 billion.

speaker: PENCE
text: He left his state about $2 billion in the hole.

speaker: PENCE
text: In the state of Indiana, we've cut unemployment in half; unemployment doubled when he was governor.

speaker: PENCE
text: But I think he's a very fitting running mate for Hillary Clinton, because in the wake of a season where American families are struggling in this economy under the weight of higher taxes and Obamacare and the war on coal and the stifling avalanche of regulation coming out of this administration, Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine want more of the same.

speaker: PENCE
text: It really is remarkable that they actually are advocating a trillion dollars in tax increases, which I get that.

speaker: PENCE
text: You tried to raise taxes here in Virginia and were unsuccessful.

speaker: PENCE
text: But a trillion dollars in tax increases, more regulation, more of the same war on coal, and more of Obamacare that now even former President Bill Clinton calls Obamacare a crazy plan.

speaker: PENCE
text: But Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine want to build on Obamacare.

speaker: PENCE
text: They want to expand it into a single-payer program.

speaker: PENCE
text: And for all the world, Hillary Clinton just thinks Obamacare is a good start.

speaker: PENCE
text: Look, Donald Trump and I have a plan to get this economy moving again just the way that it worked in the 1980s, just the way it worked in the 1960s, and that is by lowering taxes across the board for working families, small businesses and family farms, ending the war on coal that is hurting jobs and hurting this economy even here in Virginia, repealing Obamacare lock, stock, and barrel, and repealing all of the executive orders that Barack Obama has signed that are stifling economic growth in this economy.

speaker: PENCE
text: We can get America moving again.

speaker: PENCE
text: Put on top of that the kind of trade deals that'll put the American worker first, and you've got a prescription for real growth.

speaker: PENCE
text: And when you get the economy growing, Elaine, that's when you can deal with the national debt.

speaker: PENCE
text: When we get back to 3.5 percent to 4 percent growth with Donald Trump's plan will do, then we're going to have the resources to meet our nation's needs at home and abroad, and we're going to have the ability to bring down the national debt.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, on the economy, there's a fundamental choice for the American electorate.

speaker: KAINE
text: Do you want a "you're hired" president in Hillary Clinton or do you want a "you're fired" president in Donald Trump?

speaker: KAINE
text: I think that's not such a hard choice.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary and I have a plan that's on the table that's a "you're hired" plan.

speaker: KAINE
text: Five components.

speaker: KAINE
text: First thing we do is we invest in manufacturing, infrastructure, and research in the clean energy jobs of tomorrow.

speaker: KAINE
text: Second thing is we invest in our workforce, from pre-K education to great teachers to debt-free college and tuition-free college for families that make less than $125,000 a year.

speaker: KAINE
text: Third, we promote fairness by raising the minimum wage, so you can't work full-time and be under the poverty level, and by paying women equal pay for equal work.

speaker: KAINE
text: Fourth, we promote small business growth, just as we've done in Virginia, to make it easier to start and grow small businesses.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary and I each grew up in small-business families.

speaker: KAINE
text: My dad, who ran an iron working and welding shop, is here tonight.

speaker: KAINE
text: And, fifth, we have a tax plan that targets tax relief to middle- class individuals and small businesses and asks those at the very top who've benefited as we've come out of recession to pay more.
