speaker: KAINE
text: The Trump plan is a different plan.

speaker: KAINE
text: It's a "you're fired" plan.

speaker: KAINE
text: And there's two key elements to it.

speaker: KAINE
text: First, Donald Trump said wages are too high.

speaker: KAINE
text: And both Donald Trump and Mike Pence think we ought to eliminate the federal minimum wage.

speaker: KAINE
text: Mike Pence, when he was in Congress, voted against raising the minimum wage above $5.15.

speaker: KAINE
text: And he has been a one-man bulwark against minimum wage increases in Indiana.

speaker: KAINE
text: The second component of the plan is massive tax breaks for the very top, trillions of dollars of tax breaks for people just like Donald Trump.

speaker: KAINE
text: The problem with this, Elaine, is that's exactly what we did 10 years ago and it put the economy into the deepest recession -- the deepest recession since the 1930s.

speaker: KAINE
text: Independent analysts say the Clinton plan would grow the economy by 10.5 million jobs.

speaker: KAINE
text: The Trump plan would cost 3.5 million jobs.

speaker: KAINE
text: And Donald Trump -- why would he do this?

speaker: KAINE
text: Because his tax plan basically helps him.

speaker: KAINE
text: And if he ever met his promise and he gave his tax returns to the American public like he said he would, we would see just how much his economic plan is really a Trump-first plan.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: On that point, Governor Pence, recently the New York Times released part of Mr. Trump's 1995 tax return and reported that he could have avoided paying federal income taxes for years.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Yesterday, Mr. Trump said he brilliantly used the laws to pay as little tax as legally possible.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Does that seem fair to you?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, first, let me say, I appreciated the "you're hired," "you're fired" thing, Senator.

speaker: PENCE
text: You use that a whole lot.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I think your running mate used a lot of pre-done lines.

speaker: PENCE
text: Look, what -- what you all just heard out there is more taxes, $2 trillion in more spending, more deficits, more debt, more government.

speaker: PENCE
text: And if you think that's all working, then you look at the other side of the table.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, the truth of the matter is, the policies of this administration, which Hillary Clinton and Senator Kaine want to continue, have run this economy into a ditch.

speaker: PENCE
text: We're in the...

speaker: KAINE
text: Fifteen million new jobs?

speaker: PENCE
text: slowest economic recovery since the Great Depression.

speaker: KAINE
text: Fifteen million new jobs?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: There are millions more people living in poverty today than the day that Barack Obama with Hillary Clinton at his side...

speaker: KAINE
text: And the poverty level and the median income...

speaker: PENCE
text: stepped into the Oval Office.

speaker: KAINE
text: improved dramatically between 2014 and 2015.

speaker: PENCE
text: You -- honestly, Senator, you can roll out the numbers and the sunny side, but I got to tell you, people in Scranton know different.

speaker: PENCE
text: People in Fort Wayne, Indiana, know different.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, this economy is struggling.

speaker: PENCE
text: The answer to this economy is not more taxes.

speaker: KAINE
text: But it's not the giveaway tax relief to the folks at the top.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's not more spending...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: KAINE
text: I am interested to hear whether he'll defend his running mate's not releasing taxes and not paying taxes.

speaker: PENCE
text: Absolutely I will.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, with all due respect, the question was about whether it seems fair to you that Mr. Trump said he brilliantly used the laws to pay as little tax as legally possible.

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, this is probably the difference between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton and Senator Kaine.

speaker: PENCE
text: And, I mean, Hillary Clinton and Senator Kaine -- God bless you for it, career public servants, that's great -- Donald Trump is a businessman, not a career politician.

speaker: PENCE
text: He actually built a business.

speaker: PENCE
text: Those tax returns that were -- that came out publicly this week show that he faced some pretty tough times 20 years ago.

speaker: PENCE
text: But like virtually every other business, including the New York Times not too long ago, he used what's called net operating loss.

speaker: PENCE
text: We have a tax code, Senator, that actually is designed to encourage entrepreneurship in this country.

speaker: KAINE
text: But why won't he release his tax returns?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, we're answering the question about -- about a business thing, is he...

speaker: KAINE
text: I do want to come back to that, but...

speaker: PENCE
text: His tax returns -- his tax returns showed he went through a very difficult time, but he used the tax code just the way it's supposed to be used.

speaker: PENCE
text: And he did it brilliantly.

speaker: KAINE
text: How do you know that?

speaker: KAINE
text: You haven't seen his tax returns.

speaker: PENCE
text: He created a runway -- because he's created a business that's worth billions of dollars today.

speaker: KAINE
text: How do you know that?

speaker: PENCE
text: And with regard to paying taxes, this whole riff about not paying taxes and people saying he didn't pay taxes for years, Donald Trump has created tens of thousands of jobs.

speaker: PENCE
text: And he's paid payroll taxes, sales taxes, property taxes...

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, let me talk about something.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator, I'm going to give you about 30 seconds to respond, and I have question on Social Security for you.

speaker: KAINE
text: OK.

speaker: PENCE
text: The only issue on taxes -- Hillary Clinton is going to raise taxes, and Donald Trump and I are going to cut them.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump started this campaign in 2014 and he said, "If I run for president, I will absolutely release my taxes."

speaker: KAINE
text: He's broken his first...

speaker: PENCE
text: And he will.

speaker: KAINE
text: He's broken his first promise.

speaker: KAINE
text: Second, he stood on the stage...

speaker: PENCE
text: He hasn't broken his promise.

speaker: PENCE
text: He said he's...

speaker: KAINE
text: He stood on the stage last week and when Hillary said, you haven't been paying taxes, he said, "That makes me smart."

speaker: KAINE
text: So it's smart not to pay for our military?

speaker: KAINE
text: It's smart not to pay for veterans?

speaker: KAINE
text: It's smart not to pay for teachers?

speaker: KAINE
text: And I guess all of us who do pay for those things, I guess we're stupid.

speaker: KAINE
text: And the last thing I'll say is this...

speaker: PENCE
text: Senator, do you take all the deductions that you're entitled to?

speaker: KAINE
text: The last thing -- the last thing I want to ask Governor Pence is...

speaker: PENCE
text: I do.

speaker: KAINE
text: Governor Pence had to give Donald Trump his tax returns to show he was qualified to be vice president.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump must give the American public his tax returns to show that he's qualified to be president.

speaker: KAINE
text: And he's breaking his promise.

speaker: PENCE
text: Elaine, I have to respond to this.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: You get very little time, 20 seconds.

speaker: PENCE
text: I'll be -- I'll be very respectful.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor?

speaker: PENCE
text: Look, Donald Trump has filed over 100 pages of financial disclosure, which is what the law requires.

speaker: KAINE
text: But he said he would release his tax returns.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right, Gentlemen...

speaker: PENCE
text: The American people can review that.

speaker: PENCE
text: And he's going -- Senator, he's going to release his tax returns when the audit is over...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I need to ask you about Social Security...

speaker: KAINE
text: Richard Nixon released tax returns when he was under audit.

speaker: PENCE
text: They're going to raise your taxes.

speaker: PENCE
text: We're going to cut your taxes.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentlemen...

speaker: KAINE
text: If you can't meet Nixon's standard...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: The people at home cannot understand either one of you when you speak over each other.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I would please ask you to wait until it is that the other is finished.

speaker: KAINE
text: All right.

speaker: KAINE
text: We're having fun up here.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine, on the issue of Social Security, in 18 years, when the Social Security Trust Funds run out of money, you'll be 76.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: The Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget estimates your benefits could be cut by as much as $7,500 per year.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: What would your administration do to prevent this cut?

speaker: KAINE
text: First, we're going to protect Social Security, which is one of the greatest programs that the American government has ever done.

speaker: KAINE
text: It happened at a time when you would work your whole life, your whole life, raising your kids, working, being a Little League coach or a Sunday school teacher, and then you would retire into poverty.

speaker: KAINE
text: And Social Security has enabled people to retire with dignity and overwhelmingly not be in poverty.

speaker: KAINE
text: We have to keep it solvent.

speaker: KAINE
text: And we will keep it solvent.

speaker: KAINE
text: And we'll look for strategies like adjusting the payroll tax cap upward in order to do that.

speaker: KAINE
text: Here's what Hillary and I will not do.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I want to make this very plain.

speaker: KAINE
text: We will never, ever engage in a risky scheme to privatize Social Security.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump wrote a book and he said Social Security is a Ponzi scheme and privatization would be good for all of us.

speaker: KAINE
text: And when Congressman Pence was in Congress, he was the chief cheerleader for the privatization of Social Security.

speaker: KAINE
text: Even after President Bush stopped pushing for it, Congressman Pence kept pushing for it.

speaker: KAINE
text: We're going to stand up against efforts to privatize Social Security.

speaker: KAINE
text: And we'll look for ways to keep it solvent going forward, focusing primarily on the payroll tax cap.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence, I'll give you an opportunity to respond.

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, thanks, Elaine.

speaker: PENCE
text: There they go again.

speaker: PENCE
text: OK...

speaker: KAINE
text: Go read -- go read the book.

speaker: PENCE
text: All Donald Trump -- all Donald Trump and I have said about Social Security is we're going to meet our obligations to our seniors.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's it.

speaker: KAINE
text: Go read the book.

speaker: PENCE
text: We've said we're going to meet the obligations of Medicare.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's what this campaign is really about, Senator.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I get, this is -- this is the old scare tactic that they roll out...

speaker: KAINE
text: But -- but you have a voting record, Governor.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I get all of that.

speaker: PENCE
text: I just, look...

speaker: PENCE
text: There's a question that you asked a little bit earlier that I want to go back to.

speaker: KAINE
text: I can't believe that you won't defend your own voting record.

speaker: PENCE
text: I have to go back to.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: We...

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, look, I -- you're running with Hillary Clinton, who wants to raise taxes by $1 trillion, increase spending by $2 trillion, and you say you're going to keep the promises of Social Security.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump and I are going to cut taxes.

speaker: PENCE
text: We're going to -- we're going to -- we're going to...

speaker: KAINE
text: You're not going to cut taxes.

speaker: KAINE
text: You're going to raise taxes on the middle class.

speaker: PENCE
text: reform government programs so we can meet the obligations of Social Security and Medicare.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right.

speaker: PENCE
text: Stay on the path that your party has us on, we're going to be in a -- in a mountain range of debt.

speaker: PENCE
text: And we're going to face hard choices and...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentleman, I want to move on now.

speaker: KAINE
text: You did ask this question about debt, and the debt explosion on the Trump plan is much, much bigger than anything on the Clinton side.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Let me move on now...

speaker: PENCE
text: Three hundred and five (ph) economists said your plan is bad for the economy.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: to the issue of law enforcement and race relations.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Law enforcement and race relations.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: After the Dallas police shooting, Police Chief David Brown said, quote, "We're asking cops to do too much in this country.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Every societal failure we put it off on the cops to solve.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Not enough mental health funding, not enough drug addiction funding, schools fail, let's give it to the cops."

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Do we ask too much of police officers in this country?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: And how would you specifically address the chief's concerns?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, I think that's a very fair comment.

speaker: KAINE
text: I think we put a lot on police shoulders.

speaker: KAINE
text: And this is something I got a lot of scar tissue and experience on.

speaker: KAINE
text: I was a city councilman and mayor in Richmond.

speaker: KAINE
text: And when I came in, we had one of the highest homicide rates in the United States.

speaker: KAINE
text: We fought very, very hard over the course of my time in local office with our police department, and we reduced our homicide rate nearly in half.

speaker: KAINE
text: And then when I was governor of Virginia, we worked hard, too.

speaker: KAINE
text: And we did something we had really wanted to do.

speaker: KAINE
text: For the first time ever, we cracked the top 10, 10 safest states, because we worked together.

speaker: KAINE
text: Here's what I learned as a mayor and a governor.

speaker: KAINE
text: The way you make communities safer and the way you make police safer is through community policing.

speaker: KAINE
text: You build the bonds between the community and the police force, build bonds of understanding, and then when people feel comfortable in their communities, that gap between the police and the communities they serve narrows.

speaker: KAINE
text: And when that gap narrows, it's safer for the communities and it's safer for the police.

speaker: KAINE
text: That model still works across our country, but there are some other models that don't work, an overly aggressive, more militarized model.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump recently said we need to do more stop-and-frisk around the country.

speaker: KAINE
text: That would be a big mistake because it polarizes the relationship between the police and the community.

speaker: KAINE
text: So here's what we'll do.

speaker: KAINE
text: We'll focus on community policing.

speaker: KAINE
text: We will focus on -- and Hillary Clinton has rolled out a really comprehensive mental health reform package that she worked on with law enforcement professionals, and we will also fight the scourge of gun violence in the United States.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'm a gun-owner.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'm a strong Second Amendment supporter.

speaker: KAINE
text: But I've got a lot of scar tissue, because when I was governor of Virginia, there was a horrible shooting at Virginia Tech, and we learned that through that painful situation that gaps in the background record check system should have been closed and it could have prevented that crime, and so we're going to work to do things like close background record checks.

speaker: KAINE
text: And if we do, we won't have the tragedies that we did.

speaker: KAINE
text: One of those killed at Virginia Tech was a guy named Liviu Librescu.

speaker: KAINE
text: He was a 70-plus-year-old Romanian Holocaust survivor.

speaker: KAINE
text: He had survived the Holocaust.

speaker: KAINE
text: Then he survived the Soviet Union takeover of his country.

speaker: KAINE
text: But then he was a visiting professor at Virginia Tech, and he couldn't survive the scourge of gun violence.

speaker: KAINE
text: We can support the Second Amendment and do things like background record checks and make us safer, and that will make police safer, too.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence?

speaker: PENCE
text: You know, my uncle was a cop, a career cop, on the beat in downtown Chicago.

speaker: PENCE
text: He was my hero when I was growing up.

speaker: PENCE
text: And we'd go up to visit my dad's family in Chicago.

speaker: PENCE
text: My three brothers and I would marvel at my uncle when he would come out in his uniform, sidearm at his side.

speaker: PENCE
text: Police officers are the best of us.

speaker: PENCE
text: And the men and women, white, African-American, Asian, Latino, Hispanic, they put their lives on the line every single day.

speaker: PENCE
text: And let my say, at the risk of agreeing with you, community policing is a great idea.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's worked in the Hoosier state.

speaker: PENCE
text: And we fully support that.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump and I are going to make sure that law enforcement have the resources and the tools to be able to really restore law and order to the cities and communities in this nation.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's probably -- probably why the 330,000 members of the Fraternal Order of Police endorsed Donald Trump as the next president of the United States of America, because they see his commitment to them.

speaker: PENCE
text: They see his commitment to law and order.

speaker: PENCE
text: But they also -- they also hear the bad mouthing, the bad mouthing that comes from people that seize upon tragedy in the wake of police action shootings as -- as a reason to -- to use a broad brush to accuse law enforcement of -- of implicit bias or institutional racism.

speaker: PENCE
text: And that really has got to stop.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, when an African-American police officer in Charlotte named Brentley Vinson, an all-star football player who went to Liberty University here in the state, came home, followed his dad into law enforcement, joined the force in Charlotte, joined the force in Charlotte in 2014, was involved in a police action shooting that claimed the life of Keith -- Keith Lamont Scott, it was a tragedy.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, I -- we -- we mourn with those who mourn.

speaker: PENCE
text: We -- we grieve with those who grieve.

speaker: PENCE
text: And we're saddened at the loss of life.

speaker: PENCE
text: But Hillary Clinton actually referred to that moment as an example of implicit bias in the police force, where -- where she used -- when she was asked in the debate a week ago whether there was implicit bias in law enforcement, her only answer was that there's implicit bias in everyone in the United States.

speaker: PENCE
text: I just think...

speaker: KAINE
text: Can I -- can I explain...

speaker: PENCE
text: I just think what we ought to do is we ought to stop seizing on these moments of tragedy.

speaker: PENCE
text: We ought to assure the public that we'll have a full and complete and transparent investigation whenever there's a loss of life because of police action.

speaker: PENCE
text: But, Senator, please, you know, enough of this seeking every opportunity to demean law enforcement broadly by making the accusation of implicit bias every time tragedy occurs.

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine -- Elaine, people shouldn't be afraid to bring up issues of bias in law enforcement.

speaker: KAINE
text: And if you're afraid to have...

speaker: PENCE
text: I'm not afraid to bring that up.

speaker: KAINE
text: And if -- if you're afraid to have the discussion, you'll never solve it.

speaker: KAINE
text: And so here's -- here's an example, heartbreaking.

speaker: KAINE
text: We would agree this was a heartbreaking example.

speaker: KAINE
text: The guy, Philando Castile, who was killed in St. Paul, he was a worker, a valued worker in a local school.

speaker: KAINE
text: And he was killed for no apparent reason in an incident that will be discussed and will be investigated.

speaker: KAINE
text: But when folks went and explored this situation, what they found is that Philando Castile, who was a -- they called him Mr. Rogers with Dreadlocks in the school that he worked.

speaker: KAINE
text: The kids loved him.

speaker: KAINE
text: But he had been stopped by police 40 or 50 times before that fatal incident.

speaker: KAINE
text: And if you look at sentencing in this country, African-Americans and Latinos get sentenced for the same crimes at very different rates.

speaker: PENCE
text: We need criminal justice reform.

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, we do.

speaker: PENCE
text: Indiana has passed criminal justice reform.

speaker: KAINE
text: But I just want to say, those who say that we should not...

speaker: PENCE
text: But that's not what you're talking about.

speaker: KAINE
text: we should not be able to bring up and talk about bias in the system, we'll never solve the problem...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence...

speaker: PENCE
text: Senator, when African-American police officers involved in a police action shooting involving an African-American, why would Hillary Clinton accuse that African-American police officer of implicit bias?

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, I guess I can't believe you are defending the position that there is no bias and it's a topic we don't even...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence, I have a question on that point.

speaker: PENCE
text: I did not make that statement.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Your fellow Republican, Governor Pence, Senator Tim Scott, who is African-American, recently spoke on the Senate floor.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: He said he was stopped seven times by law enforcement in one year.

speaker: KAINE
text: A U.S. senator.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: He said, "I have felt the anger, the frustration, the sadness, and the humiliation that comes with feeling like you're being targeted for nothing more than being just yourself."

speaker: QUIJANO
text: What would you say to Senator Scott about his experiences?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, I have the deepest respect for Senator Scott, and he's a close friend.

speaker: PENCE
text: And what I would say is that we -- we need to adopt criminal justice reform nationally.

speaker: PENCE
text: I -- I signed criminal justice reform in the state of Indiana, Senator, and we're very proud of it.

speaker: PENCE
text: I worked when I was Congress on a second chance act.

speaker: PENCE
text: We have got to do a better job recognizing and correcting the errors in the system that do reflect on institutional bias in criminal justice.

speaker: PENCE
text: But what -- what -- what Donald Trump and I are saying is let's not have the reflex of assuming the worst of men and women in law enforcement.

speaker: PENCE
text: We truly do believe that law enforcement is not a force for racism or division in our country...

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, can I...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: So what would you say to Senator Scott, Governor?

speaker: PENCE
text: Law enforcement in this country is a force for good.

speaker: PENCE
text: They are the -- they truly are people that put their lives on the line every single day.

speaker: PENCE
text: But I would -- I would suggest to you, what we need to do is assert a stronger leadership at the national level to support law enforcement.

speaker: PENCE
text: You just heard Senator Kaine reject stop-and-frisk.

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, I would suggest to you that the families that live in our inner cities that are besieged by crime...

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, let me -- let me...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, the question is about Senator Scott.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: What would -- what would you tell Senator Scott?

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, if I could -- if I could jump in.

speaker: KAINE
text: I've heard Senator Scott make that eloquent plea.

speaker: KAINE
text: And look, criminal justice is about respecting the law and being respected by the law.

speaker: KAINE
text: So there is a fundamental respect issue here.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I just want to talk about the tone that's set from the top.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump during his campaign has called Mexicans rapists and criminals.

speaker: KAINE
text: He's called women slobs, pigs, dogs, disgusting.

speaker: KAINE
text: I don't like saying that in front of my wife and my mother.

speaker: KAINE
text: He attacked an Indiana-born federal judge and said he was unqualified to hear a federal lawsuit because his parents were Mexican.

speaker: KAINE
text: He went after John McCain, a POW, and said he wasn't hero because he'd been captured.

speaker: KAINE
text: He said African-Americans are living in Hell.

speaker: KAINE
text: And he perpetrated this outrageous and bigoted lie that President Obama is not a U.S. citizen.

speaker: KAINE
text: If you want to have a society where people are respected and respect laws, you can't have somebody at the top who demeans every group that he talks about.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I just -- again, I cannot believe that Governor Pence will defend the insult-driven campaign that Donald Trump has run.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I want to turn to our next segment now, immigration.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Your running mates have both said that undocumented immigrants who have committed violent crimes should be deported.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: What would you tell the millions of undocumented immigrants who have not committed violent crimes?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence?

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump's laid out a plan to end illegal immigration once and for all in this country.

speaker: PENCE
text: We've been talking it to death for 20 years.

speaker: PENCE
text: Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine want to continue the policies of open borders, amnesty, catch and release, sanctuary cities, all the things that are driving -- that are driving wages down in this country, Senator, and also too often with criminal aliens in the country, it's bringing heartbreak.

speaker: PENCE
text: But I -- Donald Trump has a plan that he laid out in Arizona, that will deal systemically with illegal immigration, beginning with border security, internal enforcement.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's probably why for the first time in the history of Immigration and Customs Enforcement their union actually endorsed Donald Trump as the next president of the United States, because they know they need help to enforce the laws of this country.

speaker: PENCE
text: And Donald Trump has laid out a priority to remove criminal aliens, remove people that have overstayed their visas.

speaker: PENCE
text: And -- and once we have accomplished all of that, which will -- which will strengthen our economy, strengthen the rule of law in the country and make our communities safer once the criminal aliens are out, then we'll deal with those that remain.

speaker: PENCE
text: But I have to tell you, I just -- I was listening to the avalanche of insults coming out of Senator Kaine a minute ago.

speaker: KAINE
text: These were Donald's -- hold on a second, Governor.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: It's my time, Senator.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: It is, in fact, the governor's time.

speaker: KAINE
text: I apologize.

speaker: KAINE
text: It's your two minutes.

speaker: KAINE
text: I apologize.

speaker: PENCE
text: Thanks.

speaker: PENCE
text: I forgive you.

speaker: PENCE
text: He says ours is an insult-driven campaign.

speaker: PENCE
text: Did you all just hear that?

speaker: PENCE
text: Ours is an insult-driven campaign?

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, to be honest with you, if Donald Trump had said all of the things that you've said he said in the way you said he said them, he still wouldn't have a fraction of the insults that Hillary Clinton leveled when she said that half of our supporters were a basket of deplorables.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's -- she said they were irredeemable, they were not American.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, it's extraordinary.

speaker: PENCE
text: And then she labeled one after another "ism" on millions of Americans who believe that we can have a stronger America at home and abroad, who believe we can get this economy moving again, who believe that we can end illegal immigration once and for all.

speaker: PENCE
text: So, Senator, this -- this insult-driven campaign, I mean...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor...

speaker: PENCE
text: That's small potatoes compared to Hillary Clinton...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: PENCE
text: calling half of Donald Trump's supporters a basket of deplorables.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary Clinton said something on the campaign trail, and the very next day, she said, you know what, I shouldn't have said that.

speaker: PENCE
text: She said she shouldn't have said half.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, this is Senator Kaine's two minutes, please.

speaker: KAINE
text: Yeah, that's right, so now we're even.

speaker: PENCE
text: Yeah.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: KAINE
text: Look for Donald trump apologizing to John McCain for saying he wasn't a hero...

speaker: PENCE
text: Oh...

speaker: KAINE
text: to Donald Trump apologizing for calling women slobs, pigs, dogs, disgusting.

speaker: PENCE
text: She apologized for saying "half."

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: It is his two minutes, please.

speaker: KAINE
text: Did Donald Trump apologize for taking after somebody in a Twitter war and making fun of her weight?

speaker: KAINE
text: Did he apologize for saying African-Americans are living in Hell?

speaker: KAINE
text: Did he apologize for saying President Obama was not even a citizen of the United States?

speaker: KAINE
text: You will look in vain to see Donald Trump ever taking responsibility for anybody and apologizing.

speaker: KAINE
text: Immigration.

speaker: KAINE
text: There's two plans on the table.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary and I believe in comprehensive immigration reform.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump believes in deportation nation.

speaker: KAINE
text: You've got to pick your choice.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary and I want a bipartisan reform that will put keeping families together as the top goal, second, that will help focus enforcement efforts on those who are violent, third, that will do more border control, and, fourth, that will provide a path to citizenship for those who work hard, pay taxes, play by the rules, and take criminal background record checks.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's our proposal.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump proposes to deport 16 million people, 11 million who are here without documents.

speaker: KAINE
text: And both Donald Trump and Mike Pence want to get rid of birthright citizenship.

speaker: KAINE
text: So if you're born here, but your parents don't have documents, they want to eliminate that.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's another 4.5 million people.

speaker: KAINE
text: These guys -- and Donald Trump have said it -- deportation force.

speaker: KAINE
text: They want to go house to house, school to school, business to business, and kick out 16 million people.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I cannot believe...

speaker: PENCE
text: That's nonsense.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's nonsense.

speaker: KAINE
text: I cannot believe that Governor Pence would sit here and defend his running mate's claim that we should create a deportation force to -- so that they'll all be gone.

speaker: PENCE
text: Senator, we have a deportation force.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's called Immigrations and Customs Enforcement.

speaker: PENCE
text: And the union for Immigrations and Customs Enforcement for the first time in their history endorsed Donald Trump to be the next president of the United States of America.

speaker: KAINE
text: So you like the 16 million deportations?

speaker: PENCE
text: Senator, that's -- that's nonsense.

speaker: PENCE
text: Look, what you just heard is they have a plan for open borders, amnesty.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: KAINE
text: Our plan is like Ronald Reagan's plan from 1986.

speaker: PENCE
text: They call it comprehensive immigration reform -- they call it comprehensive immigration reform on Capitol Hill.

speaker: PENCE
text: We all know the routine.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's amnesty.

speaker: PENCE
text: And you heard one of the last things he mentioned was border security.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's how Washington always plays it.

speaker: KAINE
text: No, I...

speaker: PENCE
text: They always say we're going to do this, we're going to do that, we'll eventually get the border...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: KAINE
text: border security three years ago, and Governor Pence was against it.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, Mr. Trump has said...

speaker: PENCE
text: Ronald Reagan said a nation without borders is not a nation.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump is committed to restoring the borders of this nation and securing our nation, enforcing our laws.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: So, Governor, how would these millions of undocumented immigrants leave?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Would they be forcibly removed?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, I think Donald Trump laid out a series of priorities that doesn't ends with border security.

speaker: PENCE
text: It begins with border security.

speaker: PENCE
text: And after we secure the border, not only build a wall, but beneath the ground and in the air, we do internal enforcement.

speaker: PENCE
text: But he said the focus has to be on criminal aliens.

speaker: PENCE
text: We just -- we just had a conversation about law enforcement.

speaker: PENCE
text: We just had a conversation about the -- the violence that's besetting our cities.

speaker: PENCE
text: The reality is that there's heartbreak and tragedy that has struck American families because people that came into this country illegally are now involved in criminal enterprise and activity.

speaker: PENCE
text: And we don't have the resources or the will to deport them systemically.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump has said we're going to move those people out, people who've overstayed their visas.

speaker: PENCE
text: We're going to enforce the law of this country.

speaker: PENCE
text: We're going to strengthen Immigrations and Customs Enforcements with more resources and more personnel to be able to do that.

speaker: PENCE
text: And then Donald Trump has made it clear, once we've done all of those things, that we're going to reform the immigration system that we have...

speaker: KAINE
text: I just have to correct Governor Pence....

speaker: PENCE
text: where people can come into this country.

speaker: KAINE
text: I have to...

speaker: PENCE
text: That's the order that you should do it.

speaker: PENCE
text: Border security, removing criminal aliens, upholding with law, and then -- but then, Senator, I'll work you when you go back to the Senate, I promise you, we'll work you to reform the immigration system.

speaker: KAINE
text: I look forward to working together in whatever capacities we serve in.

speaker: KAINE
text: But I just want to make it very, very clear that he's trying to fuzz up what Donald Trump has said.

speaker: KAINE
text: When Donald Trump spoke in Phoenix, he looked the audience in the eye and he said, no, we're building a wall, and we're deporting everybody.

speaker: KAINE
text: He said, quote, "They will all be gone."

speaker: KAINE
text: They will all be gone.

speaker: KAINE
text: And this is one of these ones where you can just go to the tape on it and see what Donald Trump has said.

speaker: KAINE
text: And to add...

speaker: PENCE
text: He's talking about criminal aliens.

speaker: KAINE
text: And to add to it, and to add to it, and to add to it, we are a nation of immigrants.

speaker: KAINE
text: Mike Pence and I both are descended from immigrant families.

speaker: KAINE
text: Some things, you know, maybe weren't said so great about the Irish when they came, but we've done well by absorbing immigrants, and it's made our nation stronger.

speaker: KAINE
text: When Donald Trump says Mexicans are rapists and criminals, Mexican immigrants, when Donald Trump says about your judge, a Hoosier judge, he said that Judge Curiel was unqualified to hear a case because his parents were Mexican, I can't imagine how you could defend that.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentleman, I'd like to shift now to the threat of terrorism.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Do you think the world today is a safer or more dangerous place than it was eight years ago?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Has the terrorist threat increased or decreased?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: KAINE
text: The terrorist threat has decreased in some ways, because bin Laden is dead.

speaker: KAINE
text: The terrorist threat has decreased in some ways because an Iranian nuclear weapons program has been stopped.

speaker: KAINE
text: The terrorist threat to United States troops has been decreased in some ways because there's not 175,000 in a dangerous part of the world.

speaker: KAINE
text: There's only 15,000.

speaker: KAINE
text: But there are other parts of the world that are challenging.

speaker: KAINE
text: Let me tell you this: To beat terrorism, there's only one candidate who can do it, and it's Hillary Clinton.

speaker: KAINE
text: Remember, Hillary Clinton was the senator from New York on 9/11.

speaker: KAINE
text: She was there at the World Trade Center when they were still searching for victims and survivors.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's seared onto her, the need to beat terrorism.

speaker: KAINE
text: And she's got a plan to do it.

speaker: KAINE
text: She was part of the national security team that wiped out bin Laden.

speaker: KAINE
text: Here's her plan to defeat ISIL.

speaker: KAINE
text: First, we've got to keep taking out their leaders on the battlefield.

speaker: KAINE
text: She was part of the team that got bin Laden, and she'll lead the team that will get Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the head of ISIS.

speaker: KAINE
text: Second, we've got to disrupt financing networks, third, disrupt their ability to recruit on the Internet, in their safe havens.

speaker: KAINE
text: But, fourth, we also have to work with allies to share and surge intelligence.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's the Hillary Clinton plan; she's got the experience to do it.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump can't start a Twitter war with Miss Universe without shooting himself in the foot.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump doesn't have a plan.

speaker: KAINE
text: He said, I have a secret plan," and then he said, Um, I know more than all the generals about ISIL.

speaker: KAINE
text: And then he said, "I'm going to call the generals to help me figure out a plan."

speaker: KAINE
text: And finally he said, "I'm going to fire all the generals."

speaker: KAINE
text: He doesn't have a plan.

speaker: KAINE
text: But he does have dangerous ideas.

speaker: KAINE
text: Here's four.

speaker: KAINE
text: He trash talks the military.

speaker: KAINE
text: The military is a disaster, John McCain's no hero, the generals need all to be fired, and I know more than them.

speaker: KAINE
text: He wants to tear up alliances.

speaker: KAINE
text: NATO is obsolete, and we'll only work together with Israel if they pay "big league."

speaker: KAINE
text: Third, he loves dictators.

speaker: KAINE
text: He's got kind of a personal Mount Rushmore, Vladimir Putin, Kim Jong-un, Moammar Gadhafi...

speaker: PENCE
text: Oh, please.

speaker: PENCE
text: Come on.

speaker: KAINE
text: and Saddam Hussein.

speaker: KAINE
text: And last and most dangerously, Donald Trump believes -- Donald Trump believes that the world will be safer if more nations have nuclear weapons.

speaker: KAINE
text: He's said Saudi Arabia should get them, Japan should get them, Korea should get them.

speaker: KAINE
text: And when he was confronted with this, and told, wait a minute, terrorists could get those, proliferation could lead to nuclear war, here's what Donald Trump said, and I quote: "Go ahead, folks, enjoy yourselves."

speaker: KAINE
text: I'd love to hear Governor Pence tell me what's so enjoyable or comical about nuclear war.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence?

speaker: PENCE
text: Did you work on that one a long time?

speaker: PENCE
text: Because that had a lot of really creative lines in it.

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, I'm going to see if you can defend any of it.

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, look, I can defend -- I -- I -- I can -- I can make very clear to the American people, after traveling millions of miles as our secretary of state, after being the architect of the foreign policy of this administration, America is less safe today than it was the day that Barack Obama became president of the United States.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's absolutely inarguable.

speaker: PENCE
text: We've weakened America's place in the world.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's been a combination of factors, but mostly it's been a lack of leadership.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, I will give you -- and I was in Washington, D.C., on 9/11.

speaker: PENCE
text: I saw the clouds of smoke rise from the Pentagon.

speaker: KAINE
text: I was in Virginia where the Pentagon's...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: I know you were.

speaker: PENCE
text: We all lived through that day as a nation.

speaker: PENCE
text: It was heartbreaking.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I want to give this president credit for bringing Osama bin Laden to justice.

speaker: PENCE
text: But the truth is, Osama bin Laden led Al Qaida.

speaker: PENCE
text: Our primary threat today is ISIS.

speaker: PENCE
text: And because Hillary Clinton failed to renegotiate a status of forces agreement that would have allowed some American combat troops to remain in Iraq and secure the hard fought gains the American soldier had won by 2009, ISIS was able to be literally conjured up out of the desert, and it's overrun vast areas that the American soldier had won in Operation Iraqi Freedom.

speaker: PENCE
text: My heart breaks for the likes of Lance Cpl.

speaker: PENCE
text: Scott Zubowski.

speaker: PENCE
text: He fell in Fallujah in 2005.

speaker: PENCE
text: He fought hard through some of the most difficult days in Operation Iraqi Freedom, and he paid the ultimate sacrifice to defend our freedom and secure that nation.

speaker: PENCE
text: And that nation was secured in 2009.

speaker: PENCE
text: But because Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama failed to provide a status of forces agreement and leave sufficient troops in there, we are back at war.

speaker: PENCE
text: The president just ordered more troops on the ground.

speaker: PENCE
text: We are back at war in Iraq.

speaker: PENCE
text: And Scott Zubowski, whose mom would always come to Memorial Day events in Newcastle, Indiana, to see me, and I'd give her a hug and tell her we're never going to forget her son and we never will, Scott Zubowski and the sacrifices the American soldier made were squandered in Iraq because this administration created a vacuum in which ISIS was able to grow.

speaker: PENCE
text: And a reference to the Iranian deal, the Iranian deal that Hillary Clinton initiated, $150 billion to the radical mullahs in Iran.

speaker: KAINE
text: Stopping a nuclear weapons program without firing a shot?

speaker: PENCE
text: You didn't stop the nuclear weapons program.

speaker: KAINE
text: Yes, we did.

speaker: PENCE
text: You essentially...

speaker: KAINE
text: Even the Israeli military says it stopped.

speaker: PENCE
text: guaranteed that Iran will someday become a nuclear power, because there's no limitations once the period of time of the treaty comes off.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence, Mr. Trump has proposed extreme vetting of immigrants from parts of the world that export terrorism.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: But that does not address many of the recent terrorist attacks in the United States, such as the Orlando nightclub massacre and the recent bombings in New York and New Jersey.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Those were homegrown, committed by U.S. citizens and legal residents.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: What specific tools would you use to prevent those kinds of attacks?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, I think it's -- I think it's a great question, Elaine, but it really does begin with us reforming our immigration system and putting the interests, particularly the safety and security of the American people, first.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, Donald Trump has called for extreme vetting for people coming into this country so that we don't bring people into the United States who are hostile to our Bill of Rights freedoms, who are hostile to the American way life.

speaker: PENCE
text: But also, Donald Trump and I are committed to suspending the Syrian refugee program and programs and immigration from areas of the world that have been compromised by terrorism.

speaker: PENCE
text: Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine want to increase the Syrian refugee program by 500...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, I want to...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, the question was about homegrown.

speaker: PENCE
text: Yeah, and so -- but first, you know, let's make sure we're putting the safety and security of the American people first instead of Hillary Clinton expanding the Syrian refugee program...

speaker: KAINE
text: Or instead of you violating the Constitution by blocking people based on their national origin rather than whether they're dangerous.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's not -- that's absolutely false.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's what the Seventh Circuit decided just -- here's the difference, Elaine.

speaker: PENCE
text: The Seventh Circuit...

speaker: KAINE
text: We have different views on -- on refugee issues and on immigration.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary and I want to do enforcement based on, are people dangerous?

speaker: KAINE
text: These guys say all Mexicans are bad.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's absolutely false.

speaker: KAINE
text: And with respect to refugees, we want to keep people out if they're dangerous.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump said keep them out if they're Muslim.

speaker: KAINE
text: Mike Pence...

speaker: PENCE
text: Absolutely...

speaker: KAINE
text: put a program in place to keep them out if they're from Syria.

speaker: KAINE
text: And yesterday an appellate court with three Republican judges struck down the Pence plan...

speaker: PENCE
text: Right.

speaker: PENCE
text: Right.

speaker: KAINE
text: and said it was discriminatory...

speaker: PENCE
text: And those judges -- those judges said...

speaker: KAINE
text: We should focus upon danger, not upon discrimination.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor?

speaker: PENCE
text: Elaine, to your point, those judges said it was because there wasn't any evidence yet that -- that ISIS had infiltrated the United States.

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, Germany just arrested three Syrian refugees that were connected to ISIS.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: KAINE
text: But they told you there's a right way and a wrong way to do it.

speaker: PENCE
text: But, look, if you're going to be critical of me on that, that's fair game.

speaker: PENCE
text: I will tell you, after two Syrian refugees were involved in the attack in Paris that is called Paris' 9/11, as governor of the state of Indiana, I have no higher priority than the safety and security of the people of my state.

speaker: KAINE
text: But, Governor Pence...

speaker: PENCE
text: So you bet I suspended that program.

speaker: KAINE
text: But, Governor Pence, I just...

speaker: PENCE
text: And I stand by that decision.

speaker: PENCE
text: And if I'm vice president of the United States or Donald Trump is president, we're going to put the safety and security of the American people first.

speaker: KAINE
text: Sure.

speaker: KAINE
text: Can we just be clear -- Hillary and I will do immigration enforcement and we'll vet refugees based on whether they're dangerous or not.

speaker: KAINE
text: We won't do it based on discriminating against you from the country you come from or the religion that you practice.

speaker: PENCE
text: But the problem with that...

speaker: KAINE
text: That is completely antithetical to the Jeffersonian values of...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: Elaine, the director of the FBI, our homeland security, said we can't know for certain who these people are coming from Syria.

speaker: KAINE
text: Yes, we can, and when we don't let them know, we don't let them in.

speaker: PENCE
text: So -- the FBI...

speaker: KAINE
text: When we don't know who they are, we don't let them in.

speaker: PENCE
text: The FBI and homeland security said we can't know for certain.

speaker: PENCE
text: You've got to err on the side of the safety and security of the American people, Senator.

speaker: PENCE
text: I understand the...

speaker: KAINE
text: By trashing all Syrians or trashing all Muslims?

speaker: PENCE
text: the U.N. wants us to expand the Syrian refugee program...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine, let me ask you this.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Secretary Clinton...

speaker: PENCE
text: We're going to put the safety and security of the American people first.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: has talked about an intelligence surge.

speaker: KAINE
text: Yes.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: What exactly would an intelligence surge look like?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: And how would that help identify terrorists with no operational connection to a foreign terrorist organization?

speaker: KAINE
text: Intelligence surge is two-thirds, Elaine.

speaker: KAINE
text: It's two things.

speaker: KAINE
text: It's, first, dramatically expanding our intelligence capacities by hiring great professionals, but also we've got some of the best intel and cyber employees in the world right here in the United States working for many of our private sector companies.

speaker: KAINE
text: So it involves increasing our own workforce, but striking great partnerships with some of our cyber and intel experts in the private sector so that we can, consistent with constitutional principles, gather more intelligence.

speaker: KAINE
text: But the second piece of this is really, really important.

speaker: KAINE
text: It also means creating stronger alliances, because you gather intelligence and then you share your intelligence back and forth with allies.

speaker: KAINE
text: And that's how you find out who may be trying to recruit, who may be trying to come to one country or the next.

speaker: KAINE
text: Alliances are critical.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's why Donald Trump's claim that he wants to -- that NATO is obsolete and that we need to get rid of NATO is so dangerous.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's not his plan.

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, he said NATO is obsolete.

speaker: KAINE
text: And, look, if you put aside -- push aside your alliances, who you're going to share intelligence with?

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary Clinton is the secretary of state who knows how to build alliances.

speaker: KAINE
text: She built the sanctions regime around the word that stopped the Iranian nuclear weapons program.

speaker: KAINE
text: And that's what an intelligence surge means.

speaker: KAINE
text: Better skill and capacity, but also better alliances.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I'd like to turn now to the tragedy in Syria.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Two hundred fifty thousand...

speaker: PENCE
text: Can I speak about the cybersecurity surge at all?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: You can -- you can have 30 seconds, Governor, quickly, please.

speaker: PENCE
text: First, Donald Trump just spoke about this issue this week.

speaker: PENCE
text: We have got to bring together the best resources of this country to understand that cyber warfare is the new warfare of the asymmetrical enemies that we face in this country.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I look forward if I'm privileged to be in this role of working with you in the Senate to make sure that we resource that effort.

speaker: KAINE
text: We will work together in whatever roles we inhabit.

speaker: PENCE
text: We have an intelligence, sir (ph).

speaker: PENCE
text: But I will also tell you that it's important in this moment to remember that Hillary Clinton had a private server in her home that had classified information on it...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: And I don't -- 30 seconds is on up.

speaker: PENCE
text: about drone strikes, e-mails from the president of the United States of America were on there.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Right.

speaker: PENCE
text: Her private server was subject to being hacked by foreign...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I'd like to ask you about Syria, Governor.

speaker: PENCE
text: We could put cybersecurity first if we just make sure the next secretary of state doesn't have a private server.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: KAINE
text: And all investigation concluded that not one reasonable prosecutor would take any additional step.

speaker: KAINE
text: You don't get to decide the rights and wrongs of this.

speaker: KAINE
text: We have a justice system that does that.

speaker: KAINE
text: And a Republican FBI director did an investigation and concluded that...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right, we are moving on now.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Two hundred fifty thousand people...

speaker: PENCE
text: If your son or my son handled classified information the way Hillary Clinton did...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: one hundred thousand of them children -- Governor...

speaker: PENCE
text: they'd be court martialed.

speaker: KAINE
text: That is absolutely false and you know that.

speaker: PENCE
text: Absolutely true.

speaker: KAINE
text: And you know that, Governor.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor...

speaker: PENCE
text: It's absolutely true.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentlemen, please.

speaker: KAINE
text: Because the FBI did an investigation.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentlemen.

speaker: KAINE
text: And they concluded that there was no reasonable prosecutor who would take it further.

speaker: KAINE
text: Sorry.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine, Governor Pence, please.

speaker: KAINE
text: Syria.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I want to turn now to Syria.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Two hundred fifty thousand people, 100,000 of them children, are under siege in Aleppo, Syria.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Bunker buster bombs, cluster munitions, and incendiary weapons are being dropped on them by Russian and Syrian militaries.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Does the U.S. have a responsibility to protect civilians and prevent mass casualties on this scale, Governor Pence?

speaker: PENCE
text: The United States of America needs to begin to exercise strong leadership to protect the vulnerable citizens and over 100,000 children in Aleppo.

speaker: PENCE
text: Hillary Clinton's top priority when she became secretary of state was the Russian reset, the Russians reset.

speaker: PENCE
text: After the Russian reset, the Russians invaded Ukraine and took over Crimea.

speaker: PENCE
text: And the small and bullying leader of Russia is now dictating terms to the United States to the point where all the United States of America -- the greatest nation on Earth -- just withdraws from talks about a cease-fire while Vladimir Putin puts a missile defense system in Syria while he marshals the forces and begins -- look, we have got to begin to lean into this with strong, broad-shouldered American leadership.

speaker: PENCE
text: It begins by rebuilding our military.

speaker: PENCE
text: And the Russians and the Chinese have been making enormous investments in the military.

speaker: PENCE
text: We have the smallest Navy since 1916.

speaker: PENCE
text: We have the lowest number of troops since the end of the Second World War.

speaker: PENCE
text: We've got to work with Congress, and Donald Trump will, to rebuild our military and project American strength in the world.

speaker: PENCE
text: But about Aleppo and about Syria, I truly do believe that what America ought to do right now is immediately establish safe zones, so that families and vulnerable families with children can move out of those areas, work with our Arab partners, real time, right now, to make that happen.

speaker: PENCE
text: And secondly, I just have to tell you that the provocations by Russia need to be met with American strength.

speaker: PENCE
text: And if Russia chooses to be involved and continue, I should say, to be involved in this barbaric attack on civilians in Aleppo, the United States of America should be prepared to use military force to strike military targets of the Assad regime to prevent them from this humanitarian crisis that is taking place in Aleppo.

speaker: PENCE
text: There's a broad range of other things that we ought to do, as well.

speaker: PENCE
text: We ought to deploy a missile defense shield to the Czech Republic and Poland which Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama pulled back on out of not wanting to offend the Russians back in 2009.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, your two minutes are up.

speaker: PENCE
text: We've just got to have American strength on the world stage.

speaker: PENCE
text: When Donald Trump becomes president of the United States, the Russians and other countries in the world will know they're dealing with a strong American president.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary and I also agree that the establishment of humanitarian zones in northern Syria with the provision of international human aid, consistent with the U.N. Security Council resolution that was passed in February 2014, would be a very, very good idea.

speaker: KAINE
text: And Hillary also has the ability to stand up to Russia in a way that this ticket does not.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump, again and again, has praised Vladimir Putin.

speaker: KAINE
text: And it's clear that he has business dealings with Russian oligarchs who are very connected to Putin.

speaker: KAINE
text: The Trump campaign management team had to be fired a month or so ago because of those shadowy connections with pro-Putin forces.

speaker: KAINE
text: Governor Pence made the odd claim, he said inarguably Vladimir Putin is a better leader than President Obama.

speaker: KAINE
text: Vladimir Putin has run his economy into the ground.

speaker: KAINE
text: He persecutes LGBT folks and journalists.

speaker: KAINE
text: If you don't know the difference between dictatorship and leadership, then you got to go back to a fifth-grade civics class.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'll tell you what offends me...

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, that offended me.

speaker: KAINE
text: Governor Pence just said -- Governor Pence just said that Donald Trump will rebuild the military.

speaker: KAINE
text: No, he won't.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump is avoiding paying taxes.

speaker: KAINE
text: The New York Times story -- and we need to get this -- but the New York Times suggested that he probably didn't pay taxes for about 18 years starting in 1995.

speaker: KAINE
text: Those years included the years of 9/11.

speaker: KAINE
text: So get this.

speaker: KAINE
text: On 9/11, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump's hometown was attacked by the worst terrorist attack in the history of the United States.

speaker: KAINE
text: Young men and women -- young men and women signed up to serve in the military to fight terrorism.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary Clinton went to Washington to get funds to rebuild her city and protect first responders, but Donald Trump was fighting a very different fight.

speaker: KAINE
text: It was a fight to avoid paying taxes so that he wouldn't support the fight against terror.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: The question was about Aleppo, Senator.

speaker: KAINE
text: He wouldn't support troops.

speaker: KAINE
text: He wouldn't -- he wouldn't support -- this is important, Elaine.

speaker: KAINE
text: When a guy running for president will not support the troops, not support veterans, not support teachers, that's really important.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Right.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I said about Aleppo, we do agree the notion is we have to create a humanitarian zone in northern Syria.

speaker: KAINE
text: It's very important.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence, you had mentioned no-fly zone.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Where would you propose setting up a safe zone specifically?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: How would you keep it safe?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, first and foremost, Donald Trump supports our troops.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump supports our veterans.

speaker: KAINE
text: He won't pay taxes.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump has paid all the taxes that he's -- do you not take deductions?

speaker: PENCE
text: How does that work?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentlemen, this is about Syria.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I'd like to...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: Honestly, Senator.

speaker: PENCE
text: Honestly, Senator.

speaker: KAINE
text: It is about our troops.

speaker: KAINE
text: It is about our troops.

speaker: PENCE
text: I understand why you want to change -- I understand why you want to change the subject.

speaker: KAINE
text: How can you support the troops if you won't pay taxes?

speaker: PENCE
text: I understand why you want to change the subject.

speaker: PENCE
text: And let me be very clear on this Russian thing.

speaker: PENCE
text: The larger question here...

speaker: KAINE
text: Do you think Donald Trump is smart to not pay taxes?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentlemen, we're going to have time to get to Russia here.

speaker: PENCE
text: What we're dealing with is the -- you know, there's an old proverb that says the Russian bear never dies, it just hibernates.

speaker: PENCE
text: And the truth of the matter is, the weak and feckless foreign policy of Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama has awakened an aggression in Russia that first appeared a few years ago with their move in Georgia, now their move into Crimea, now their move into the wider Middle East.

speaker: PENCE
text: And all the while, all we do is fold our arms and say we're not having talks anymore.

speaker: PENCE
text: To answer your question, we just need American strength.

speaker: PENCE
text: We need to -- we need to marshal the resources of our allies in the region, and in the immediate, we need to act and act now to get people out of harm's way.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: And exactly how would those safe zones work?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: How would they remain safe?

speaker: PENCE
text: The -- the safe zones would have to be -- as the senator said, there's already a framework for this that's been recognized by the international community.

speaker: PENCE
text: The United States of America needs to be prepared to work with our allies in the region to create a route for safe passage and then to protect people in those areas, including with a no-fly zone.

speaker: PENCE
text: But, look, this is very tough stuff.

speaker: PENCE
text: I served on the Foreign Affairs Committee for a decade.

speaker: PENCE
text: I traveled in and out of that region for 10 years.

speaker: PENCE
text: I saw what the American soldier won in Operation Iraqi Freedom.

speaker: PENCE
text: And to see the weak and feckless leadership that Hillary Clinton was the architect of and the foreign policy of the Obama administration...

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, let me -- let me come back...

speaker: PENCE
text: is deeply troubling to me.

speaker: PENCE
text: That will all change the day Donald Trump becomes president of the United States.

speaker: KAINE
text: and talk about -- let me talk about the things that Governor Pence doesn't want to acknowledge, Elaine.

speaker: KAINE
text: He doesn't want to acknowledge that we stopped the Iranian nuclear weapons program.

speaker: KAINE
text: He doesn't want to acknowledge...

speaker: PENCE
text: We didn't.

speaker: KAINE
text: that Hillary was part of a team that got bin Laden.

speaker: KAINE
text: He doesn't want to acknowledge...

speaker: PENCE
text: I just did.

speaker: KAINE
text: that it's a good thing, not a bad thing, that it's a good thing -- not a bad thing -- that we're down from 175,000 troops deployed overseas to 15,000.

speaker: KAINE
text: But let me tell you what will really make the Middle East dangerous.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump's idea that more nations should get nuclear weapons, Saudi Arabia, Japan, South Korea.

speaker: KAINE
text: Ronald Reagan said something really interesting about nuclear proliferation back in the 1980s.

speaker: KAINE
text: He said the problem with nuclear proliferation is that some fool or maniac could trigger a catastrophic event.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I think that's who Governor Pence's running mate is, exactly who Governor Reagan warned us about.

speaker: PENCE
text: And come on.

speaker: PENCE
text: Senator.

speaker: PENCE
text: Senator, that was even beneath you and Hillary Clinton.

speaker: PENCE
text: And that -- that's pretty low.

speaker: KAINE
text: But do you -- do you think -- do you think we should have -- more nuclear weapons in the world will make us safer?

speaker: PENCE
text: Senator, the...

speaker: KAINE
text: That's what Donald Trump thinks.

speaker: PENCE
text: Ronald Reagan also said nuclear war should never be fought because it can never be won.

speaker: PENCE
text: And the United States of America needs to make investments in modernizing our nuclear force for both deterrence...

speaker: KAINE
text: But can you defend Donald Trump's claim that more nations should get nuclear weapons?

speaker: PENCE
text: and assurance to our allies.

speaker: PENCE
text: But let me go back to this Iran thing.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, he keeps saying that they prevented -- that Hillary Clinton started the deal with the Iranians prevented Iran from getting a nuclear weapon.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: KAINE
text: That's what the Israeli joint chiefs of staff is saying right now.

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, that's not what -- that's not what Israel thinks.

speaker: KAINE
text: Gadi Eizenkot, you can go check it.

speaker: PENCE
text: You wouldn't necessarily know that.

speaker: KAINE
text: Go to the tape.

speaker: PENCE
text: I know you boycotted Prime Minister Netanyahu's speech when he came before the Congress.

speaker: KAINE
text: No, I visited him in his office.

speaker: KAINE
text: I visited him in his office.

speaker: PENCE
text: You boycotted the speech.

speaker: PENCE
text: The point is, what this Iran -- so-called Iran deal did was essentially guarantee -- I mean, when I was in Congress, I fought hard on a bipartisan basis with Republican and Democrat members to move forward the toughest sanctions, it -- literally in the history of the United States, against Iran.

speaker: KAINE
text: And then Hillary used them to get a deal.

speaker: PENCE
text: We were bringing them to heel, but the goal was always that we would only lift the sanctions if Iran permanently renounced their nuclear ambitions.

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, let me just mention one thing.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: They have not -- Elaine, let me finish a sentence.

speaker: PENCE
text: They have not renounced their nuclear ambitions.

speaker: PENCE
text: And when the deal's period runs out, there's no limitation on them obtaining weapons.

speaker: PENCE
text: That...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: And very quickly, Senator.

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine...

speaker: PENCE
text: and the fact that they got $1.7 billion in a ransom payment...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: We need to talk about Russia.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Very quickly, though, Senator, please.

speaker: PENCE
text: is astonishing to the American people.

speaker: KAINE
text: Six times tonight, I have said to Governor Pence I can't imagine how you can defend your running mate's position on one issue after the next.

speaker: KAINE
text: And in all six cases, he's refused to defend his running mate.

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, let's -- no, no, don't put words in my mouth.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right.

speaker: PENCE
text: He's going...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: KAINE
text: And yet he is asking everybody to vote for somebody that he cannot defend.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I just think that should be underlined.

speaker: PENCE
text: No, I'm -- look...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right, gentlemen, let's talk about Russia.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: This is a topic that has come up.

speaker: PENCE
text: I'm very, very happy to defend Donald Trump.

speaker: PENCE
text: If he wants to take these one at a time, I'll take them one at a time.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I will give you an opportunity to do that.

speaker: KAINE
text: More nations should get nuclear weapons.

speaker: KAINE
text: Try to defend that.

speaker: PENCE
text: Don't put words in my mouth.

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, he never said that, Senator.

speaker: KAINE
text: He absolutely said it.

speaker: KAINE
text: Saudi Arabia, South Korea, Japan.

speaker: PENCE
text: Most of the stuffy you've said, he's never said.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Gentlemen, Russia.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Russian President Vladimir Putin invaded Ukraine, annexed Crimea, and has provided crucial military support to the Assad regime.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: What steps, if any, would your administration take to counter these actions?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: KAINE
text: You've got to be tough on Russia.

speaker: KAINE
text: So let's start with not praising Vladimir Putin as a great leader.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump and Mike Pence have said he's a great leader.

speaker: KAINE
text: And Donald Trump has business...

speaker: PENCE
text: No, we haven't.

speaker: KAINE
text: has business dealings -- has business dealings with Russia that he refuses to disclose.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary Clinton has gone toe-to- toe with Russia.

speaker: KAINE
text: She went toe-to-toe with Russia as secretary of state to do the New START Agreement to reduce Russia's nuclear stockpile.

speaker: KAINE
text: She's had the experience doing it.

speaker: KAINE
text: She went toe-to-toe with Russia and lodged protests when they went into Georgia.

speaker: KAINE
text: And we've done the same thing about Ukraine, but more than launching protests, we've put punishing economic sanctions on Russia that we need to continue.

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump, on the other hand, didn't know that Russia had invaded the Crimea.

speaker: PENCE
text: Oh, that's nonsense.

speaker: KAINE
text: He was on a TV show a couple months back, and he said, "I'll guarantee you this, Russia's not going into the Ukraine."

speaker: KAINE
text: And he had to be reminded that they had gone into the Crimea two years before.

speaker: PENCE
text: He knew that.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary Clinton has gone toe-to-toe with Russia to work out a deal on New START.

speaker: KAINE
text: She got them engaged on a meaningful way to cap Iran's nuclear weapons program.

speaker: KAINE
text: And yet she stood up to them on issues such as Syria and their invasion of Georgia.

speaker: KAINE
text: You've got to have the ability to do that, and Hillary does.

speaker: KAINE
text: On the other hand, in Donald Trump, you have somebody who praises Vladimir Putin all the time.

speaker: KAINE
text: America should really wonder about a President Trump, who had a campaign manager with ties to Putin, pro- Putin elements in the Ukraine, who had to be fired for that reason.

speaker: KAINE
text: They should wonder -- when Donald Trump is sitting down with Vladimir Putin, is it going to be America's bottom line or is it going to be Donald Trump's bottom line that he's going to be worried about with all of his business dealings?

speaker: KAINE
text: Now, this could be solved if Donald Trump would be willing to release his tax returns, as he told the American public that he would do.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I know he's laughing at this, but every president...

speaker: PENCE
text: But what's it got to do with Russia?

speaker: KAINE
text: Every president since Richard Nixon has done it, and Donald Trump has said I'm doing business with Russia.

speaker: KAINE
text: The only way the American public will see whether he has a conflict of interest...

speaker: PENCE
text: No, he hasn't said that.

speaker: KAINE
text: He has, actually.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator, your time is up.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, thanks.

speaker: PENCE
text: I'm just trying to keep up with the insult-driven campaign on the other side of the table.

speaker: KAINE
text: You know, I'm just saying facts about your running mate.

speaker: PENCE
text: Yeah.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I know you can't defend.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator, please.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: This is the governor's two minutes.

speaker: PENCE
text: I'm happy to defend him, Senator.

speaker: PENCE
text: Don't put words in my mouth that I'm not defending him.

speaker: KAINE
text: You're not.

speaker: PENCE
text: I'm happy to defend him.

speaker: PENCE
text: Most of what you said is completely false, and the American people know that.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'll run through the list of things where you won't defend...

speaker: PENCE
text: This isn't the old days where you can just say stuff and people believe it.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator, please.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: This is Governor Pence's two minutes.

speaker: PENCE
text: Look, this is the alternative universe of Washington, D.C., versus reality.

speaker: PENCE
text: Hillary Clinton said her number-one priority was a reset with Russia.

speaker: PENCE
text: That reset resulted in the invasion of Ukraine, after they'd infiltrated with what are called little green men, Russian soldiers that were dressing up like Ukrainian dissidents, and then they moved all the way into Crimea, took over the Crimean Peninsula.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump knew that happened.

speaker: PENCE
text: He basically was saying it's not going to happen again.

speaker: PENCE
text: The truth of the matter is that what you have in the rise of aggressive Russia, which has had -- increased its influence in Iran, that's now -- now because of this deal is on a pathway in the future to obtain a nuclear -- the leading state sponsor of terror in the world in Iran now has a closer working relationship with Russia because of Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama's foreign policy and $150 billion and sanctions all being lifted.

speaker: PENCE
text: And then, of course, Syria, I mean, it really is extraordinary that -- Syria is imploding.

speaker: PENCE
text: You just asked a very thoughtful question about the disaster in Aleppo.

speaker: PENCE
text: ISIS is headquartered in Raqqa.

speaker: PENCE
text: It is -- ISIS from Raqqa has overrun vast areas that at great sacrifice the American soldier won in Operation Iraqi Freedom, and yet Senator Kaine still sits here, loyal soldier -- I get all that -- in saying that the foreign policy of Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama somehow made the world more secure.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, it really is astonishing that on the day...

speaker: KAINE
text: We even wiped out the leader of Al Qaida.

speaker: PENCE
text: on the day that Iran released four American hostages...

speaker: KAINE
text: We stopped Iran from getting nuclear weapons.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor...

speaker: PENCE
text: we delivered $400 million in cash as a ransom payment for Americans held by the radical mullahs in Tehran.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, yesterday, Mr. Trump said...

speaker: KAINE
text: And we stopped a nuclear weapons program without a shot.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: quote, "Putin has no respect for Hillary Clinton and no respect for Obama."

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Why do you think he'll respect a Trump- Pence administration?

speaker: PENCE
text: Strength.

speaker: PENCE
text: Plain and simple.

speaker: KAINE
text: Business dealings.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump -- that's nonsense.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump is a strong leader...

speaker: KAINE
text: Donald Trump's son says that the Trump organization...

speaker: PENCE
text: who is going to lead with American strength.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Please, Senator, I'll give you a chance to respond.

speaker: PENCE
text: We're going to rebuild our military.

speaker: PENCE
text: And let me -- let me -- this whole Putin thing.

speaker: PENCE
text: Look, America is stronger than Russia.

speaker: PENCE
text: Our economy is 16 times larger than the Russian economy.

speaker: PENCE
text: America's political system is superior to the crony, corrupt capitalist system in Russia in every way.

speaker: PENCE
text: When Donald Trump and I observe that, as I've said in Syria, in Iran, in Ukraine, that the small and bullying leader of Russia has been stronger on the world stage than this administration, that's stating painful facts.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's not an endorsement of Vladimir Putin.

speaker: PENCE
text: That's an indictment of the weak and feckless leadership...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: PENCE
text: of Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama.

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, this is one where we can just kind of go to the tape on it.

speaker: KAINE
text: But Governor Pence said, inarguably, Vladimir Putin is a better leader than President Obama.

speaker: PENCE
text: That is absolutely inaccurate.

speaker: KAINE
text: And -- and -- and I just think a guy who praises...

speaker: PENCE
text: He said he's stronger -- he's been stronger on the world stage.

speaker: KAINE
text: No, he said leader.

speaker: KAINE
text: And if -- and I'll just say this, Governor.

speaker: PENCE
text: You just said better.

speaker: KAINE
text: If you mistake leadership for dictatorship, and you can't tell the difference, a country that's running its economy into the ground...

speaker: PENCE
text: Yeah, here we go.

speaker: PENCE
text: This is the grade school thing again?

speaker: KAINE
text: persecuting journalists...

speaker: PENCE
text: Right, this is grade school.

speaker: KAINE
