text: if you can't tell the difference, you shouldn't be commander-in-chief.

speaker: PENCE
text: Yeah.

speaker: KAINE
text: And with Donald Trump -- Donald Trump's sons say that they have all these business dealings with Russia.

speaker: KAINE
text: Those could be disclosed with tax returns, but they refuse to do them.

speaker: KAINE
text: Americans need to worry about whether Donald Trump will be watching out for America's bottom line or his own bottom line.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine, what went wrong with the Russia reset?

speaker: KAINE
text: Vladimir Putin.

speaker: KAINE
text: Vladimir Putin is a dictator.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: And what would do you differently?

speaker: KAINE
text: Vladimir Putin is a dictator.

speaker: KAINE
text: He's not a leader.

speaker: KAINE
text: Anybody who thinks otherwise doesn't know Russian history and they don't know Vladimir Putin.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary Clinton knows exactly who this guy is.

speaker: KAINE
text: John McCain said, I look in his eyes and I see KGB.

speaker: KAINE
text: And Hillary kind of has that same feeling.

speaker: PENCE
text: Right.

speaker: KAINE
text: So how do deal with him?

speaker: KAINE
text: You've got to -- we do have to deal with Russia in a lot of different ways.

speaker: KAINE
text: There are areas where we can cooperate.

speaker: KAINE
text: So it was Hillary Clinton who worked with Russia on the New START Treaty to reduce their nuclear weapons stockpile.

speaker: KAINE
text: It was Hillary Clinton that worked with Russia to get them engaged in a community of nations to stop the Iranian nuclear weapons without firing a shot.

speaker: KAINE
text: She's not going around praising Vladimir Putin as a great guy.

speaker: KAINE
text: But she knows how to sit down at a table and negotiate tough deals.

speaker: KAINE
text: This is a very challenging part of the world, and we ought to have a commander-in-chief who is prepared and done it, rather than somebody who goes around praising Vladimir Putin as a great leader.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right, I'd like to ask now about North Korea, Iran and the threat of nuclear weapons.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: North Korea recently conducted its fifth and most powerful nuclear test.

speaker: PENCE
text: Right.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: What specific steps would you take to prevent North Korea from developing a nuclear-armed missile capable of reaching the United States?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, first, we need to -- we need to make a commitment to rebuild our military, including modernizing our nuclear forces.

speaker: PENCE
text: And we also need -- we also need an effective American diplomacy that will marshal the resources of nations in the Asian Pacific Rim to put pressure on North Korea, on Kim Jong-un, to abandon his nuclear ambitions.

speaker: PENCE
text: It has to remain the policy of the United States of America the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula, plain and simple.

speaker: PENCE
text: And when Donald Trump is president of the United States, we're -- we're not going to have the -- the kind of posture in the world that has Russia invading Crimea and Ukraine, that has the Chinese building new islands in the South China Sea, that has literally the world, including North Korea, flouting American power.

speaker: PENCE
text: We're going to -- we're going to go back to the days of peace through strength.

speaker: PENCE
text: But I have to tell you that -- that all this talk about tax returns -- and I get it, you know, you want to keep bringing that up.

speaker: PENCE
text: It must have -- must have...

speaker: KAINE
text: Until he...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: done well in some focus group.

speaker: PENCE
text: But here -- Hillary Clinton and her husband set up a private foundation called the Clinton Foundation.

speaker: PENCE
text: While she was secretary of state, the Clinton Foundation accepted tens of millions of dollars from foreign governments and foreign donors.

speaker: PENCE
text: Now, you all need to know out there, this is basic stuff.

speaker: PENCE
text: Foreign donors, and certainly foreign governments, cannot participate in the American political process.

speaker: PENCE
text: They cannot make financial contributions.

speaker: PENCE
text: But the Clintons figured out a way to create a foundation where foreign governments and foreign donors could donate millions of dollars.

speaker: PENCE
text: And then we found, thanks to the good work of the Associated Press, that more than half her private meetings when she was secretary of state were given to major donors of the Clinton Foundation.

speaker: PENCE
text: When you talk about all these -- all these baseless rumors about Russia and the rest, Hillary Clinton -- you asked the trustworthy question at the very beginning -- the reason...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, your two minutes are up.

speaker: PENCE
text: the reason the American people don't trust Hillary Clinton is because they are looking at the pay to play politics that she operated with the Clinton Foundation through a private server...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, please.

speaker: PENCE
text: while she's secretary of state.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Your two minutes are up, Governor.

speaker: PENCE
text: And they're saying enough is enough.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: KAINE
text: I'm going to talk about the foundation, and then I'll talk about North Korea.

speaker: KAINE
text: So, on the foundation.

speaker: KAINE
text: I am glad to talk about the foundation.

speaker: KAINE
text: The Clinton Foundation is one of the highest- rated charities in the world.

speaker: KAINE
text: It provides AIDS drugs to about 11.5 million people.

speaker: KAINE
text: It helps Americans deal with opioid overdoses.

speaker: KAINE
text: It gets higher rankings for its charity than the American Red Cross does.

speaker: KAINE
text: The Clinton foundation does an awful lot of good work.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary Clinton as secretary of state took no action to benefit the foundation.

speaker: KAINE
text: The State Department did an investigation, and they concluded that everything Hillary Clinton did as secretary of state was completely in the interest of the United States.

speaker: KAINE
text: So the foundation does good work.

speaker: KAINE
text: And Hillary Clinton as secretary of state acted in the interests of the United States.

speaker: KAINE
text: But let's compare this now with the Trump organization and the Trump Foundation.

speaker: KAINE
text: The Trump organization is an octopus-like organization with tentacles all over the world whose conflict of interests could only be known if Donald Trump would release his tax returns.

speaker: KAINE
text: He's refused to do it.

speaker: KAINE
text: His sons have said that the organization has a lot of business dealings in Russia.

speaker: KAINE
text: And remember, the Trump organization is not a non-profit.

speaker: KAINE
text: It's putting money into Donald Trump's pockets and into the pockets of his children, whereas the Clinton Foundation is a non- profit and no Clinton family member draws any salary.

speaker: PENCE
text: The Trump Foundation is non-profit.

speaker: KAINE
text: In addition, Donald Trump has a foundation.

speaker: KAINE
text: The foundation was just fined for illegally contributing foundation dollars to a political campaign of a Florida attorney general.

speaker: KAINE
text: They made an illegal contribution, and then they tried to hide it by disguising it to somebody else.

speaker: KAINE
text: And the person they donated to was somebody whose office was charged with investigating Trump University.

speaker: KAINE
text: This is the difference between a foundation that does good work and a secretary of state who acted in accordance with American interest and somebody who is conflicted and doing work around the world and won't share with the American public what he's doing and what those conflicts are.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, I will give you 30 seconds to respond, because I know you want to, but, again, I would remind you both this was about North Korea.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, Thank you.

speaker: PENCE
text: Thank you.

speaker: PENCE
text: The Trump Foundation is a private family foundation.

speaker: PENCE
text: They give virtually every cent in the Trump Foundation to charitable causes.

speaker: KAINE
text: Political contributions?

speaker: PENCE
text: Less than ten cents on the dollar in the Clinton Foundation has gone to charitable causes.

speaker: KAINE
text: A $20,000 portrait of Donald Trump?

speaker: PENCE
text: Less than 10 cents on the dollar of the Clinton Foundation has gone to charitable causes.

speaker: KAINE
text: Ninety percent.

speaker: PENCE
text: It has been a platform for the Clintons to travel the world, to have staff.

speaker: PENCE
text: But honestly, Senator, we would know a lot more about it if Hillary Clinton would just turn over the 33,000 e-mails...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right, let's turn back to North Korea...

speaker: PENCE
text: that she refused to turn over in her private server...

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine...

speaker: PENCE
text: and we'd have a much better picture of what the Clinton Foundation was about.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine, if you had intelligence that North Korea was about to launch a missile, a nuclear-armed missile capable of reaching the United States, would you take preemptive action?

speaker: KAINE
text: If we -- look, a president should take action to defend the United States against imminent threat.

speaker: KAINE
text: You have to.

speaker: KAINE
text: A president has to do that.

speaker: KAINE
text: Now exactly what action, you would have to determine what your intelligence was, how certain you were of that intelligence, but you would have to take action.

speaker: KAINE
text: You asked the question about how do we deal with a North Korea.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'm on the Foreign Relations Committee.

speaker: KAINE
text: We just did an extensive sanctions package against North Korea.

speaker: KAINE
text: And interestingly enough, Elaine, the U.N. followed and did this -- virtually the same package.

speaker: KAINE
text: Often China will use their veto in the Security Council to veto a package like that.

speaker: KAINE
text: They're starting to get worried about North Korea, too.

speaker: KAINE
text: So they actually supported the sanctions package, even though many of the sanctions are against Chinese firms, Chinese financial institutions.

speaker: KAINE
text: So we're working together with China, and we need to.

speaker: KAINE
text: China's another one of those relationships where it's competitive, it's also challenging, and in times like North Korea, we have to be able to cooperate.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary understands that very well.

speaker: KAINE
text: She went once famously to China and stood up at a human rights meeting and looked them in the eye and said, "Women's rights are human rights."

speaker: KAINE
text: They didn't want her to say that, but she did.

speaker: KAINE
text: But she's also worked on a lot of diplomatic and important diplomatic deals with China.

speaker: KAINE
text: And that's what it's going to take.

speaker: KAINE
text: The thing I would worry a little bit about is that Donald Trump owes about $650 million to banks, including the Bank of China.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'm not sure he could stand up so tough to the people who have loaned him money.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I'd like to turn to our next segment now.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: And in this, I'd like to focus on social issues.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: You have both been open about the role that faith has played in your lives.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Can you discuss in detail a time when you struggled to balance your personal faith and a public policy position?

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine?

speaker: KAINE
text: Yeah, that's an easy one for me, Elaine.

speaker: KAINE
text: It's an easy one.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'm really fortunate.

speaker: KAINE
text: I grew up in a wonderful household with great Irish Catholic parents.

speaker: KAINE
text: My mom and dad are sitting right here.

speaker: KAINE
text: I was educated by Jesuits at Rockhurst High School in Kansas City.

speaker: KAINE
text: My 40th reunion is in 10 days.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I worked with Jesuit missionaries in Honduras, now nearly 35 years ago, and they were the heroes of my life.

speaker: KAINE
text: I try to practice my religion in a very devout way and follow the teachings of my church in my own personal life.

speaker: KAINE
text: But I don't believe in this nation, a First Amendment nation, where we don't raise any religion over the other, and we allow people to worship as they please, that the doctrines of any one religion should be mandated for everyone.

speaker: KAINE
text: For me, the hardest struggle in my faith life was the Catholic Church is against the death penalty and so am I.

speaker: KAINE
text: But I was governor of a state, and the state law said that there was a death penalty for crimes if the jury determined them to be heinous.

speaker: KAINE
text: And so I had to grapple with that.

speaker: KAINE
text: When I was running for governor, I was attacked pretty strongly because of my position on the death penalty.

speaker: KAINE
text: But I looked the voters of Virginia in the eye and said, look, this is my religion.

speaker: KAINE
text: I'm not going to change my religious practice to get one vote, but I know how to take an oath and uphold the law.

speaker: KAINE
text: And if you elect me, I will uphold the law.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I was elected, and I did.

speaker: KAINE
text: It was very, very difficult to allow executions to go forward, but in circumstances where I didn't feel like there was a case for clemency, I told Virginia voters I would uphold the law, and I did.

speaker: KAINE
text: That was a real struggle.

speaker: KAINE
text: But I think it is really, really important that those of us who have deep faith lives don't feel that we could just substitute our own views for everybody else in society, regardless of their views.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor Pence?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, it's a wonderful question.

speaker: PENCE
text: And my Christian faith is at the very heart of who I am.

speaker: PENCE
text: I was also raised in a wonderful family of faith.

speaker: PENCE
text: It was a church on Sunday morning and grace before dinner.

speaker: PENCE
text: But my Christian faith became real for me when I made a personal decision for Christ when I was a freshman in college.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I've tried to live that out however imperfectly every day of my life since.

speaker: PENCE
text: And with my wife at my side, we've followed a calling into public service, where we've -- we've tried to -- we've tried to keep faith with the values that we cherish.

speaker: PENCE
text: And with regard to when I struggle, I appreciate, and -- and -- and -- I have a great deal of respect for Senator Kaine's sincere faith.

speaker: PENCE
text: I truly do.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's shared.

speaker: PENCE
text: But for me, I would tell you that for me the sanctity of life proceeds out of the belief that -- that ancient principle that -- where God says before you were formed in the womb, I knew you, and so for my first time in public life, I sought to stand with great compassion for the sanctity of life.

speaker: PENCE
text: The state of Indiana has also sought to make sure that we expand alternatives in health care counseling for women, non-abortion alternatives.

speaker: PENCE
text: I'm also very pleased at the fact we're well on our way in Indiana to becoming the most pro-adoption state in America.

speaker: PENCE
text: I think if you're going to be pro-life, you should -- you should be pro- adoption.

speaker: PENCE
text: But what I can't understand is with Hillary Clinton and now Senator Kaine at her side is to support a practice like partial-birth abortion.

speaker: PENCE
text: I mean, to hold to the view -- and I know Senator Kaine, you hold pro-life views personally -- but the very idea that a child that is almost born into the world could still have their life taken from them is just anathema to me.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I cannot -- I can't conscience about -- about a party that supports that.

speaker: PENCE
text: Or that -- I know you've historically opposed taxpayer funding of abortion.

speaker: PENCE
text: But Hillary Clinton wants to -- wants to repeal the longstanding provision in the law where we said we wouldn't use taxpayer dollars to fund abortion.

speaker: PENCE
text: So for me, my faith informs my life.

speaker: PENCE
text: I try and spend a little time on my knees every day.

speaker: PENCE
text: But it all for me begins with cherishing the dignity, the worth, the value of every human life.

speaker: KAINE
text: Elaine, this is a fundamental question, a fundamental question.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary and I are both people out of religious backgrounds, from Methodist church experience, which was really formative for her as a public servant.

speaker: KAINE
text: But we really feel like you should live fully and with enthusiasm the commands of your faith.

speaker: KAINE
text: But it is not the role of the public servant to mandate that for everybody else.

speaker: KAINE
text: So let's talk about abortion and choice.

speaker: KAINE
text: Let's talk about them.

speaker: KAINE
text: We support Roe v. Wade.

speaker: KAINE
text: We support the constitutional right of American women to consult their own conscience, their own supportive partner, their own minister, but then make their own decision about pregnancy.

speaker: KAINE
text: That's something we trust American women to do that.

speaker: KAINE
text: And we don't think that women should be punished, as Donald Trump said they should, for making the decision to have an abortion.

speaker: KAINE
text: Governor Pence wants to repeal Roe v. Wade.

speaker: KAINE
text: He said he wants to put it on the ash heap of history.

speaker: KAINE
text: And we have some young people in the audience who weren't even born when Roe was decided.

speaker: KAINE
text: This is pretty important.

speaker: KAINE
text: Before Roe v. Wade, states could pass criminal laws to do just that, to punish women if they made the choice to terminate a pregnancy.

speaker: KAINE
text: I think you should live your moral values.

speaker: KAINE
text: But the last thing, the very last thing that government should do is have laws that would punish women who make reproductive choices.

speaker: KAINE
text: And that is the fundamental difference between a Clinton-Kaine ticket and a Trump- Pence ticket that wants to punish women who make that choice.

speaker: PENCE
text: No, it's really not.

speaker: PENCE
text: Donald Trump and I would never support legislation that punished women who made the heartbreaking choice to end a pregnancy.

speaker: KAINE
text: Then why did Donald Trump say that?

speaker: PENCE
text: We just never would.

speaker: KAINE
text: Why did he say that?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, look, it's -- look, he's not a polished politician like you and Hillary Clinton.

speaker: PENCE
text: And so...

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, I would admit that's not a polished...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: PENCE
text: You know, things don't always come out exactly the way he means them.

speaker: KAINE
text: Well, can I say...

speaker: PENCE
text: But I'm telling you what the policy of our administration would be.

speaker: KAINE
text: Great line from the -- great line from the gospel of Matthew.

speaker: KAINE
text: From the fullness of the heart, the mouth speaks.

speaker: PENCE
text: Yeah.

speaker: KAINE
text: When Donald Trump says women should be punished or Mexicans are rapists and criminals...

speaker: PENCE
text: I'm telling you...

speaker: KAINE
text: or John McCain is not a hero, he is showing you who he is.

speaker: PENCE
text: Senator, you've whipped out that Mexican thing again.

speaker: PENCE
text: He -- look...

speaker: KAINE
text: Can you defend it?

speaker: PENCE
text: There are criminal aliens in this country, Tim, who have come into this country illegally who are perpetrating violence and taking American lives.

speaker: KAINE
text: You want to -- you want to use a big broad brush against Mexicans on that?

speaker: PENCE
text: He also said and many of them are good people.

speaker: PENCE
text: You keep leaving that out of your quote.

speaker: PENCE
text: And if you want me to go there, I'll go there.

speaker: PENCE
text: But here's -- there is a choice, and it is a choice on life.

speaker: PENCE
text: I couldn't be more proud to be standing with Donald Trump, who's standing for the right to life.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's a principle that -- Senator Kaine -- and I'm very gentle about this, because I really do respect you -- it's a principle that you embrace.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I have appreciated the fact that you've supported the Hyde amendment, which bans the use of taxpayer funding for abortion, in the past, but that's not Hillary Clinton's view.

speaker: PENCE
text: People need to understand, we can come together as a nation.

speaker: PENCE
text: We can create a culture of life.

speaker: PENCE
text: More and more young people today are embracing life because we know we are -- we're better for it.

speaker: PENCE
text: We can -- like Mother Teresa said at that famous national prayer breakfast...

speaker: KAINE
text: This is important --

speaker: PENCE
text: bring the -- let's welcome the children into our world.

speaker: PENCE
text: There are so many families around the country who can't have children.

speaker: PENCE
text: We could improve adoption...

speaker: KAINE
text: But, Governor...

speaker: PENCE
text: so that families that can't have children can adopt more readily those children from crisis pregnancies.

speaker: KAINE
text: Governor, why don't you trust women to make this choice for themselves?

speaker: KAINE
text: We can encourage people to support life.

speaker: KAINE
text: Of course we can.

speaker: KAINE
text: But why don't you trust women?

speaker: KAINE
text: Why doesn't Donald Trump trust women to make this choice for themselves?

speaker: KAINE
text: That's what we ought to be doing in public life.

speaker: KAINE
text: Living our lives of faith or motivation with enthusiasm and excitement, convincing other, dialoguing with each other about important moral issues of the day...

speaker: PENCE
text: Because there are...

speaker: KAINE
text: but on fundamental issues of morality, we should let women make their own decisions.

speaker: PENCE
text: Because there is -- a society can be judged by how it deals with its most vulnerable, the aged, the infirm, the disabled, and the unborn.

speaker: PENCE
text: I believe it with all my heart.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I couldn't be more proud to be standing with a pro-life candidate in Donald Trump.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: I do have one final question for you both tonight.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: It has been a divisive campaign.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Senator Kaine, if your ticket wins, what specifically are you going to do to unify the country and reassure the people who voted against you?

speaker: KAINE
text: That's a really important one.

speaker: KAINE
text: That may be the $64,000 question, because it has been a divisive campaign.

speaker: KAINE
text: And again, Hillary is running a campaign about stronger together, and Donald Trump -- and this is -- this is not directed at this man, except to the extent that he can't defend Donald Trump -- Donald Trump has run a campaign that's been about one insult after the next.

speaker: KAINE
text: But we do have to bring the country together.

speaker: KAINE
text: So here's what we'll do.

speaker: KAINE
text: Hillary Clinton was first lady, then senator for eight years and secretary of state.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I served in the Senate.

speaker: KAINE
text: And I'm really amazed, Elaine, as I talk to Republican senators, how well they regard and respect Hillary Clinton.

speaker: KAINE
text: She was on the Armed Services Committee.

speaker: KAINE
text: She was on other committees.

speaker: KAINE
text: She worked across the aisle when she was first lady to get the CHIP program passed so that 8 million low-income kids have health insurance in this country, including 150,000 in Indiana.

speaker: KAINE
text: She worked across the aisle after 9/11 to get health benefits for the first responders who bravely went into the towers and into the Pentagon.

speaker: KAINE
text: She worked to get benefits for -- TRICARE benefits for National Guard members, including Hoosiers and Virginians in the National Guard.

speaker: KAINE
text: She has a track record of working across the aisle to make things happen.

speaker: KAINE
text: And, you know, Elaine, I have the same track record.

speaker: KAINE
text: I was a governor of Virginia with two Republican houses.

speaker: KAINE
text: And in the Senate, I have good working relationships across the aisle.

speaker: KAINE
text: Because I think it's fine to be a Democrat or Republican or independent, but after Election Day, the goal is work together.

speaker: KAINE
text: And Hillary Clinton has a track record of accomplishment across the aisle that will enable her to do just that when we work with the new Congress in January.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Governor, how will you unify the country if you win?

speaker: PENCE
text: Well, thank you, Elaine, and thanks for a great discussion...

speaker: KAINE
text: Absolutely.

speaker: PENCE
text: tonight.

speaker: PENCE
text: Thank you, Senator.

speaker: PENCE
text: This is a very challenging time in the life of our nation.

speaker: PENCE
text: Weakened America's place in the world after the leadership of Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama on the world stage has been followed by an economy that is truly struggling, stifled by an avalanche of more taxes, more regulation, Obamacare, the war on coal, and the kind of trade deals that have put American workers in the back seat.

speaker: PENCE
text: I think the best way that we can bring people together is through change in Washington, D.C.

speaker: PENCE
text: You know, I served in Washington, D.C., for 12 years in the Congress of the United States.

speaker: PENCE
text: And I served with many Republicans and Democrats, men and women of goodwill.

speaker: PENCE
text: The potential is there to really change the direction of this country, but it's going to take leadership to do it.

speaker: PENCE
text: The American people want to see our nation standing tall on the world stage again.

speaker: PENCE
text: They want to see us supporting our military, rebuilding our military, commanding the respect of the world, and they want to see the American economy off to the races again.

speaker: PENCE
text: They want to see an American comeback.

speaker: PENCE
text: And Donald Trump's entire career has been about building.

speaker: PENCE
text: It's been about -- it's going through hardship just like a businessperson does and finding a way through smarts and ingenuity and resilience to fight forward and -- when Donald Trump becomes president of the United States, we're going to have a stronger America.

speaker: PENCE
text: When you hear him say he wants to make America great again, when we do that, I truly do believe the American people are going to be standing taller.

speaker: PENCE
text: They're going to see that real change can happen after decades of just talking about it.

speaker: PENCE
text: And when that happens, the American people are going to stand tall, stand together, and we'll have the kind of unity that's been missing for way too long.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: All right, gentlemen, thank you so much.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: This concludes the vice presidential debate.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: My thanks to the candidates, the commission, and to you for watching.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Please tune in this Sunday for the second presidential debate at Washington University in St. Louis and the final debate on October 19th at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: From Farmville, Virginia, I'm Elaine Quijano of CBS News.

speaker: QUIJANO
text: Good night.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen the Republican nominee for president, Donald J. Trump, and the Democratic nominee for president, Hillary Clinton.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you very much for being here.

speaker: COOPER
text: We're going to begin with a question from one of the members in our town hall.

speaker: COOPER
text: Each of you will have two minutes to respond to this question.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, you won the coin toss, so you'll go first.

speaker: COOPER
text: Our first question comes from Patrice Brock.

speaker: COOPER
text: Patrice?

speaker: QUESTION
text: Thank you, and good evening.

speaker: QUESTION
text: The last debate could have been rated as MA, mature audiences, per TV parental guidelines.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Knowing that educators assign viewing the presidential debates as students' homework, do you feel you're modeling appropriate and positive behavior for today's youth?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, thank you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Are you a teacher?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yes, I think that that's a very good question, because I've heard from lots of teachers and parents about some of their concerns about some of the things that are being said and done in this campaign.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think it is very important for us to make clear to our children that our country really is great because we're good.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we are going to respect one another, lift each other up.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We are going to be looking for ways to celebrate our diversity, and we are going to try to reach out to every boy and girl, as well as every adult, to bring them in to working on behalf of our country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have a very positive and optimistic view about what we can do together.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's why the slogan of my campaign is "Stronger Together," because I think if we work together, if we overcome the divisiveness that sometimes sets Americans against one another, and instead we make some big goals -- and I've set forth some big goals, getting the economy to work for everyone, not just those at the top, making sure that we have the best education system from preschool through college and making it affordable, and so much else.

speaker: CLINTON
text: If we set those goals and we go together to try to achieve them, there's nothing in my opinion that America can't do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So that's why I hope that we will come together in this campaign.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Obviously, I'm hoping to earn your vote, I'm hoping to be elected in November, and I can promise you, I will work with every American.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to be the president for all Americans, regardless of your political beliefs, where you come from, what you look like, your religion.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want us to heal our country and bring it together because that's, I think, the best way for us to get the future that our children and our grandchildren deserve.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, thank you.

speaker: COOPER
text: Mr. Trump, you have two minutes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I actually agree with that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I agree with everything she said.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I began this campaign because I was so tired of seeing such foolish things happen to our country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: This is a great country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: This is a great land.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I've gotten to know the people of the country over the last year-and-a-half that I've been doing this as a politician.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I cannot believe I'm saying that about myself, but I guess I have been a politician.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And my whole concept was to make America great again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When I watch the deals being made, when I watch what's happening with some horrible things like Obamacare, where your health insurance and health care is going up by numbers that are astronomical, 68 percent, 59 percent, 71 percent, when I look at the Iran deal and how bad a deal it is for us, it's a one-sided transaction where we're giving back $150 billion to a terrorist state, really, the number one terror state, we've made them a strong country from really a very weak country just three years ago.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When I look at all of the things that I see and all of the potential that our country has, we have such tremendous potential, whether it's in business and trade, where we're doing so badly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Last year, we had almost $800 billion trade deficit.

speaker: TRUMP
text: In other words, trading with other countries.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We had an $800 billion deficit.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's hard to believe.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Inconceivable.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You say who's making these deals?

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going the make great deals.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to have a strong border.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to bring back law and order.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Just today, policemen was shot, two killed.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And this is happening on a weekly basis.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to bring back respect to law enforcement.

speaker: TRUMP
text: At the same time, we have to take care of people on all sides.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We need justice.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I want to do things that haven't been done, including fixing and making our inner cities better for the African-American citizens that are so great, and for the Latinos, Hispanics, and I look forward to doing it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's called make America great again.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you, Mr. Trump.

speaker: COOPER
text: The question from Patrice was about are you both modeling positive and appropriate behavior for today's youth?

speaker: COOPER
text: We received a lot of questions online, Mr. Trump, about the tape that was released on Friday, as you can imagine.

speaker: COOPER
text: You called what you said locker room banter.

speaker: COOPER
text: You described kissing women without consent, grabbing their genitals.

speaker: COOPER
text: That is sexual assault.

speaker: COOPER
text: You bragged that you have sexually assaulted women.

speaker: COOPER
text: Do you understand that?

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, I didn't say that at all.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't think you understood what was -- this was locker room talk.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm not proud of it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I apologize to my family.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I apologize to the American people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Certainly I'm not proud of it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But this is locker room talk.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know, when we have a world where you have ISIS chopping off heads, where you have -- and, frankly, drowning people in steel cages, where you have wars and horrible, horrible sights all over, where you have so many bad things happening, this is like medieval times.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We haven't seen anything like this, the carnage all over the world.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they look and they see.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Can you imagine the people that are, frankly, doing so well against us with ISIS?

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they look at our country and they see what's going on.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Yes, I'm very embarrassed by it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I hate it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But it's locker room talk, and it's one of those things.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I will knock the hell out of ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to defeat ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: ISIS happened a number of years ago in a vacuum that was left because of bad judgment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I will tell you, I will take care of ISIS.

speaker: COOPER
text: So, Mr. Trump...

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we should get on to much more important things and much bigger things.

speaker: COOPER
text: Just for the record, though, are you saying that what you said on that bus 11 years ago that you did not actually kiss women without consent or grope women without consent?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have great respect for women.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Nobody has more respect for women than I do.

speaker: COOPER
text: So, for the record, you're saying you never did that?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I've said things that, frankly, you hear these things I said.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I was embarrassed by it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I have tremendous respect for women.

speaker: COOPER
text: Have you ever done those things?

speaker: TRUMP
text: And women have respect for me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I will tell you: No, I have not.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I will tell you that I'm going to make our country safe.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to have borders in our country, which we don't have now.

speaker: TRUMP
text: People are pouring into our country, and they're coming in from the Middle East and other places.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to make America safe again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to make America great again, but we're going to make America safe again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we're going to make America wealthy again, because if you don't do that, it just -- it sounds harsh to say, but we have to build up the wealth of our nation.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you, Mr. Trump.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Right now, other nations are taking our jobs and they're taking our wealth.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you, Mr. Trump.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that's what I want to talk about.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, do you want to respond?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, like everyone else, I've spent a lot of time thinking over the last 48 hours about what we heard and saw.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, with prior Republican nominees for president, I disagreed with them on politics, policies, principles, but I never questioned their fitness to serve.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Donald Trump is different.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I said starting back in June that he was not fit to be president and commander-in-chief.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And many Republicans and independents have said the same thing.

speaker: CLINTON
text: What we all saw and heard on Friday was Donald talking about women, what he thinks about women, what he does to women.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And he has said that the video doesn't represent who he is.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I think it's clear to anyone who heard it that it represents exactly who he is.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Because we've seen this throughout the campaign.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have seen him insult women.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've seen him rate women on their appearance, ranking them from one to ten.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've seen him embarrass women on TV and on Twitter.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We saw him after the first debate spend nearly a week denigrating a former Miss Universe in the harshest, most personal terms.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, yes, this is who Donald Trump is.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But it's not only women, and it's not only this video that raises questions about his fitness to be our president, because he has also targeted immigrants, African- Americans, Latinos, people with disabilities, POWs, Muslims, and so many others.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So this is who Donald Trump is.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the question for us, the question our country must answer is that this is not who we are.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's why -- to go back to your question -- I want to send a message -- we all should -- to every boy and girl and, indeed, to the entire world that America already is great, but we are great because we are good, and we will respect one another, and we will work with one another, and we will celebrate our diversity.

speaker: CLINTON
text: These are very important values to me, because this is the America that I know and love.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I can pledge to you tonight that this is the America that I will serve if I'm so fortunate enough to become your president.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And we want to get to some questions from online...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Am I allowed to respond to that?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I assume I am.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Yes, you can respond to that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's just words, folks.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's just words.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Those words, I've been hearing them for many years.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I heard them when they were running for the Senate in New York, where Hillary was going to bring back jobs to upstate New York and she failed.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I've heard them where Hillary is constantly talking about the inner cities of our country, which are a disaster education-wise, jobwise, safety-wise, in every way possible.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm going to help the African-Americans.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm going to help the Latinos, Hispanics.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I am going to help the inner cities.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's done a terrible job for the African-Americans.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She wants their vote, and she does nothing, and then she comes back four years later.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We saw that firsthand when she was United States senator.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She campaigned where the primary part of her campaign...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump, Mr. Trump -- I want to get to audience questions and online questions.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So, she's allowed to do that, but I'm not allowed to respond?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You're going to have -- you're going to get to respond right now.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Sounds fair.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: This tape is generating intense interest.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: In just 48 hours, it's become the single most talked about story of the entire 2016 election on Facebook, with millions and millions of people discussing it on the social network.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: As we said a moment ago, we do want to bring in questions from voters around country via social media, and our first stays on this topic.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Jeff from Ohio asks on Facebook, "Trump says the campaign has changed him.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: When did that happen?"

speaker: RADDATZ
text: So, Mr. Trump, let me add to that.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: When you walked off that bus at age 59, were you a different man or did that behavior continue until just recently?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And you have two minutes for this.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It was locker room talk, as I told you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That was locker room talk.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm not proud of it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I am a person who has great respect for people, for my family, for the people of this country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And certainly, I'm not proud of it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But that was something that happened.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If you look at Bill Clinton, far worse.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Mine are words, and his was action.

speaker: TRUMP
text: His was what he's done to women.

speaker: TRUMP
text: There's never been anybody in the history politics in this nation that's been so abusive to women.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So you can say any way you want to say it, but Bill Clinton was abusive to women.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Hillary Clinton attacked those same women and attacked them viciously.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Four of them here tonight.

speaker: TRUMP
text: One of the women, who is a wonderful woman, at 12 years old, was raped at 12.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Her client she represented got him off, and she's seen laughing on two separate occasions, laughing at the girl who was raped.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Kathy Shelton, that young woman is here with us tonight.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So don't tell me about words.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I am absolutely -- I apologize for those words.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But it is things that people say.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But what President Clinton did, he was impeached, he lost his license to practice law.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He had to pay an $850,000 fine to one of the women.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Paula Jones, who's also here tonight.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I will tell you that when Hillary brings up a point like that and she talks about words that I said 11 years ago, I think it's disgraceful, and I think she should be ashamed of herself, if you want to know the truth.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Can we please hold the applause?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, you have two minutes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, first, let me start by saying that so much of what he's just said is not right, but he gets to run his campaign any way he chooses.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He gets to decide what he wants to talk about.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Instead of answering people's questions, talking about our agenda, laying out the plans that we have that we think can make a better life and a better country, that's his choice.

speaker: CLINTON
text: When I hear something like that, I am reminded of what my friend, Michelle Obama, advised us all: When they go low, you go high.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, look, if this were just about one video, maybe what he's saying tonight would be understandable, but everyone can draw their own conclusions at this point about whether or not the man in the video or the man on the stage respects women.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But he never apologizes for anything to anyone.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He never apologized to Mr. and Mrs. Khan, the Gold Star family whose son, Captain Khan, died in the line of duty in Iraq.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And Donald insulted and attacked them for weeks over their religion.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He never apologized to the distinguished federal judge who was born in Indiana, but Donald said he couldn't be trusted to be a judge because his parents were, quote, "Mexican."

speaker: CLINTON
text: He never apologized to the reporter that he mimicked and mocked on national television and our children were watching.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And he never apologized for the racist lie that President Obama was not born in the United States of America.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He owes the president an apology, he owes our country an apology, and he needs to take responsibility for his actions and his words.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, you owe the president an apology, because as you know very well, your campaign, Sidney Blumenthal -- he's another real winner that you have -- and he's the one that got this started, along with your campaign manager, and they were on television just two weeks ago, she was, saying exactly that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So you really owe him an apology.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You're the one that sent the pictures around your campaign, sent the pictures around with President Obama in a certain garb.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That was long before I was ever involved, so you actually owe an apology.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Number two, Michelle Obama.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I've gotten to see the commercials that they did on you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I've gotten to see some of the most vicious commercials I've ever seen of Michelle Obama talking about you, Hillary.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So, you talk about friend?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Go back and take a look at those commercials, a race where you lost fair and square, unlike the Bernie Sanders race, where you won, but not fair and square, in my opinion.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And all you have to do is take a look at WikiLeaks and just see what they say about Bernie Sanders and see what Deborah Wasserman Schultz had in mind, because Bernie Sanders, between super-delegates and Deborah Wasserman Schultz, he never had a chance.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I was so surprised to see him sign on with the devil.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But when you talk about apology, I think the one that you should really be apologizing for and the thing that you should be apologizing for are the 33,000 e-mails that you deleted, and that you acid washed, and then the two boxes of e-mails and other things last week that were taken from an office and are now missing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'll tell you what.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I didn't think I'd say this, but I'm going to say it, and I hate to say it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But if I win, I am going to instruct my attorney general to get a special prosecutor to look into your situation, because there has never been so many lies, so much deception.

speaker: TRUMP
text: There has never been anything like it, and we're going to have a special prosecutor.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When I speak, I go out and speak, the people of this country are furious.

speaker: TRUMP
text: In my opinion, the people that have been long-term workers at the FBI are furious.

speaker: TRUMP
text: There has never been anything like this, where e-mails -- and you get a subpoena, you get a subpoena, and after getting the subpoena, you delete 33,000 e-mails, and then you acid wash them or bleach them, as you would say, very expensive process.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So we're going to get a special prosecutor, and we're going to look into it, because you know what?

speaker: TRUMP
text: People have been -- their lives have been destroyed for doing one-fifth of what you've done.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it's a disgrace.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And honestly, you ought to be ashamed of yourself.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, I want to follow up on that.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I'm going to let you talk about e-mails.

speaker: CLINTON
text: because everything he just said is absolutely false, but I'm not surprised.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Oh, really?

speaker: CLINTON
text: In the first debate...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And really, the audience needs to calm down here.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I told people that it would be impossible to be fact-checking Donald all the time.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'd never get to talk about anything I want to do and how we're going to really make lives better for people.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, once again, go to HillaryClinton.com.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have literally Trump -- you can fact check him in real time.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Last time at the first debate, we had millions of people fact checking, so I expect we'll have millions more fact checking, because, you know, it is -- it's just awfully good that someone with the temperament of Donald Trump is not in charge of the law in our country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because you'd be in jail.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton...

speaker: COOPER
text: We want to remind the audience to please not talk out loud.

speaker: COOPER
text: Please do not applaud.

speaker: COOPER
text: You're just wasting time.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And, Secretary Clinton, I do want to follow up on e- mails.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You've said your handing of your e-mails was a mistake.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You disagreed with FBI Director James Comey, calling your handling of classified information, quote, "extremely careless."

speaker: RADDATZ
text: The FBI said that there were 110 classified e-mails that were exchanged, eight of which were top secret, and that it was possible hostile actors did gain access to those e-mails.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You don't call that extremely careless?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, Martha, first, let me say -- and I've said before, but I'll repeat it, because I want everyone to hear it -- that was a mistake, and I take responsibility for using a personal e-mail account.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Obviously, if I were to do it over again, I would not.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm not making any excuses.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It was a mistake.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I am very sorry about that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I think it's also important to point out where there are some misleading accusations from critics and others.

speaker: CLINTON
text: After a year-long investigation, there is no evidence that anyone hacked the server I was using and there is no evidence that anyone can point to at all -- anyone who says otherwise has no basis -- that any classified material ended up in the wrong hands.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I take classified materials very seriously and always have.

speaker: CLINTON
text: When I was on the Senate Armed Services Committee, I was privy to a lot of classified material.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Obviously, as secretary of state, I had some of the most important secrets that we possess, such as going after bin Laden.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I am very committed to taking classified information seriously.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And as I said, there is no evidence that any classified information ended up in the wrong hands.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: OK, we're going to move on.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And yet she didn't know the word -- the letter C on a document.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Right?

speaker: TRUMP
text: She didn't even know what that word -- what that letter meant.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know, it's amazing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm watching Hillary go over facts.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she's going after fact after fact, and she's lying again, because she said she -- you know, what she did with the e-mail was fine.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You think it was fine to delete 33,000 e-mails?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't think so.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She said the 33,000 e-mails had to do with her daughter's wedding, number one, and a yoga class.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, maybe we'll give three or three or four or five or something.

speaker: TRUMP
text: 33,000 e-mails deleted, and now she's saying there wasn't anything wrong.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And more importantly, that was after getting a subpoena.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That wasn't before.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That was after.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She got it from the United States Congress.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'll be honest, I am so disappointed in congressmen, including Republicans, for allowing this to happen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Our Justice Department, where our husband goes on to the back of a airplane for 39 minutes, talks to the attorney general days before a ruling is going to be made on her case.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But for you to say that there was nothing wrong with you deleting 39,000 e-mails, again, you should be ashamed of yourself.

speaker: TRUMP
text: What you did -- and this is after getting a subpoena from the United States Congress.

speaker: COOPER
text: We have to move on.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You did that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Wait a minute.

speaker: TRUMP
text: One second.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, you can respond, and then we got to move on.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We want to give the audience a chance.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If you did that in the private sector, you'd be put in jail, let alone after getting a subpoena from the United States Congress.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, you can respond.

speaker: COOPER
text: Then we have to move on to an audience question.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Look, it's just not true.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so please, go to...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Oh, you didn't delete them?

speaker: COOPER
text: Allow her to respond, please.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It was personal e-mails, not official.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Yeah.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Not -- well, we turned over 35,000, so...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Oh, yeah.

speaker: TRUMP
text: What about the other 15,000?

speaker: COOPER
text: Please allow her to respond.

speaker: COOPER
text: She didn't talk while you talked.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yes, that's true, I didn't.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because you have nothing to say.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I didn't in the first debate, and I'm going to try not to in this debate, because I'd like to get to the questions that the people have brought here tonight to talk to us about.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Get off this question.

speaker: CLINTON
text: OK, Donald.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I know you're into big diversion tonight, anything to avoid talking about your campaign and the way it's exploding and the way Republicans are leaving you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But let's at least focus...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Let's see what happens...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: COOPER
text: Allow her to respond.

speaker: CLINTON
text: on some of the issues that people care about tonight.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Let's get to their questions.

speaker: COOPER
text: We have a question here from Ken Karpowicz.

speaker: COOPER
text: He has a question about health care.

speaker: COOPER
text: Ken?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'd like to know, Anderson, why aren't you bringing up the e-mails?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'd like to know.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why aren't you bringing...

speaker: COOPER
text: We brought up the e-mails.

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, it hasn't.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It hasn't.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it hasn't been finished at all.

speaker: COOPER
text: Ken Karpowicz has a question.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's nice to -- one on three.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Thank you.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Affordable Care Act, known as Obamacare, it is not affordable.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Premiums have gone up.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Deductibles have gone up.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Copays have gone up.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Prescriptions have gone up.

speaker: QUESTION
text: And the coverage has gone down.

speaker: QUESTION
text: What will you do to bring the cost down and make coverage better?

speaker: COOPER
text: That first one goes to Secretary Clinton, because you started out the last one to the audience.

speaker: CLINTON
text: If he wants to start, he can start.

speaker: CLINTON
text: No, go ahead, Donald.

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, I'm a gentlemen, Hillary.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Go ahead.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I think Donald was about to say he's going to solve it by repealing it and getting rid of the Affordable Care Act.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I'm going to fix it, because I agree with you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Premiums have gotten too high.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Copays, deductibles, prescription drug costs, and I've laid out a series of actions that we can take to try to get those costs down.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But here's what I don't want people to forget when we're talking about reining in the costs, which has to be the highest priority of the next president, when the Affordable Care Act passed, it wasn't just that 20 million got insurance who didn't have it before.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But that in and of itself was a good thing.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I meet these people all the time, and they tell me what a difference having that insurance meant to them and their families.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But everybody else, the 170 million of us who get health insurance through our employees got big benefits.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Number one, insurance companies can't deny you coverage because of a pre-existing condition.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Number two, no lifetime limits, which is a big deal if you have serious health problems.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Number three, women can't be charged more than men for our health insurance, which is the way it used to be before the Affordable Care Act.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Number four, if you're under 26, and your parents have a policy, you can be on that policy until the age of 26, something that didn't happen before.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I want very much to save what works and is good about the Affordable Care Act.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we've got to get costs down.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've got to provide additional help to small businesses so that they can afford to provide health insurance.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But if we repeal it, as Donald has proposed, and start over again, all of those benefits I just mentioned are lost to everybody, not just people who get their health insurance on the exchange.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And then we would have to start all over again.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Right now, we are at 90 percent health insurance coverage.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's the highest we've ever been in our country.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, your time is up.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I want us to get to 100 percent, but get costs down and keep quality up.

speaker: COOPER
text: Mr. Trump, you have two minutes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It is such a great question and it's maybe the question I get almost more than anything else, outside of defense.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Obamacare is a disaster.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We all know it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's going up at numbers that nobody's ever seen worldwide.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Nobody's ever seen numbers like this for health care.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's only getting worse.

speaker: TRUMP
text: In '17, it implodes by itself.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Their method of fixing it is to go back and ask Congress for more money, more and more money.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have right now almost $20 trillion in debt.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Obamacare will never work.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's very bad, very bad health insurance.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Far too expensive.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And not only expensive for the person that has it, unbelievably expensive for our country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's going to be one of the biggest line items very shortly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to repeal it and replace it with something absolutely much less expensive and something that works, where your plan can actually be tailored.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to get rid of the lines around the state, artificial lines, where we stop insurance companies from coming in and competing, because they want -- and President Obama and whoever was working on it -- they want to leave those lines, because that gives the insurance companies essentially monopolies.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We want competition.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You will have the finest health care plan there is.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She wants to go to a single-payer plan, which would be a disaster, somewhat similar to Canada.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And if you haven't noticed the Canadians, when they need a big operation, when something happens, they come into the United States in many cases because their system is so slow.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's catastrophic in certain ways.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But she wants to go to single payer, which means the government basically rules everything.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Hillary Clinton has been after this for years.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Obamacare was the first step.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Obamacare is a total disaster.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And not only are your rates going up by numbers that nobody's ever believed, but your deductibles are going up, so that unless you get hit by a truck, you're never going to be able to use it.

speaker: COOPER
text: Mr. Trump, your time...

speaker: TRUMP
text: It is a disastrous plan, and it has to be repealed and replaced.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, let me follow up with you.

speaker: COOPER
text: Your husband called Obamacare, quote, "the craziest thing in the world," saying that small-business owners are getting killed as premiums double, coverage is cut in half.

speaker: COOPER
text: Was he mistaken or was the mistake simply telling the truth?

speaker: CLINTON
text: No, I mean, he clarified what he meant.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And it's very clear.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Look, we are in a situation in our country where if we were to start all over again, we might come up with a different system.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we have an employer-based system.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's where the vast majority of people get their health care.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the Affordable Care Act was meant to try to fill the gap between people who were too poor and couldn't put together any resources to afford health care, namely people on Medicaid.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Obviously, Medicare, which is a single-payer system, which takes care of our elderly and does a great job doing it, by the way, and then all of the people who were employed, but people who were working but didn't have the money to afford insurance and didn't have anybody, an employer or anybody else, to help them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That was the slot that the Obamacare approach was to take.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And like I say, 20 million people now have health insurance.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So if we just rip it up and throw it away, what Donald's not telling you is we just turn it back to the insurance companies the way it used to be, and that means the insurance companies...

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton...

speaker: CLINTON
text: get to do pretty much whatever they want, including saying, look, I'm sorry, you've got diabetes, you had cancer, your child has asthma...

speaker: COOPER
text: Your time is up.

speaker: CLINTON
text: you may not be able to have insurance because you can't afford it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So let's fix what's broken about it, but let's not throw it away and give it all back to the insurance companies and the drug companies.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's not going to work.

speaker: COOPER
text: Mr. Trump, let me follow up on this.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I just want -- just one thing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: First of all, Hillary, everything's broken about it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Everything.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Number two, Bernie Sanders said that Hillary Clinton has very bad judgment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: This is a perfect example of it, trying to save Obamacare, which is a disaster.

speaker: COOPER
text: You've said you want to end Obamacare...

speaker: TRUMP
text: By the way...

speaker: COOPER
text: You've said you want to end Obamacare.

speaker: COOPER
text: You've also said you want to make coverage accessible for people with pre-existing conditions.

speaker: COOPER
text: How do you force insurance companies to do that if you're no longer mandating that every American get insurance?

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to be able to.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You're going to have plans...

speaker: COOPER
text: What does that mean?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I'll tell you what it means.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You're going to have plans that are so good, because we're going to have so much competition in the insurance industry.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Once we break out -- once we break out the lines and allow the competition to come...

speaker: COOPER
text: Are you going -- are you going to have a mandate that Americans have to have health insurance?

speaker: TRUMP
text: President Obama -- Anderson, excuse me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: President Obama, by keeping those lines, the boundary lines around each state, it was almost gone until just very toward the end of the passage of Obamacare, which, by the way, was a fraud.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know that, because Jonathan Gruber, the architect of Obamacare, was said -- he said it was a great lie, it was a big lie.

speaker: TRUMP
text: President Obama said you keep your doctor, you keep your plan.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The whole thing was a fraud, and it doesn't work.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But when we get rid of those lines, you will have competition, and we will be able to keep pre-existing, we'll also be able to help people that can't get -- don't have money because we are going to have people protected.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And Republicans feel this way, believe it or not, and strongly this way.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to block grant into the states.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're going to block grant into Medicaid into the states...

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you, Mr. Trump.

speaker: TRUMP
text: so that we will be able to take care of people without the necessary funds to take care of themselves.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you, Mr. Trump.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We now go to Gorbah Hamed with a question for both candidates.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Hi.

speaker: QUESTION
text: There are 3.3 million Muslims in the United States, and I'm one of them.

speaker: QUESTION
text: You've mentioned working with Muslim nations, but with Islamophobia on the rise, how will you help people like me deal with the consequences of being labeled as a threat to the country after the election is over?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump, you're first.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, you're right about Islamophobia, and that's a shame.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But one thing we have to do is we have to make sure that -- because there is a problem.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, whether we like it or not, and we could be very politically correct, but whether we like it or not, there is a problem.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we have to be sure that Muslims come in and report when they see something going on.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When they see hatred going on, they have to report it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As an example, in San Bernardino, many people saw the bombs all over the apartment of the two people that killed 14 and wounded many, many people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Horribly wounded.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They'll never be the same.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Muslims have to report the problems when they see them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And, you know, there's always a reason for everything.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If they don't do that, it's a very difficult situation for our country, because you look at Orlando and you look at San Bernardino and you look at the World Trade Center.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Go outside.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look at Paris.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look at that horrible -- these are radical Islamic terrorists.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she won't even mention the word and nor will President Obama.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He won't use the term "radical Islamic terrorism."

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, to solve a problem, you have to be able to state what the problem is or at least say the name.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She won't say the name and President Obama won't say the name.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But the name is there.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's radical Islamic terror.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And before you solve it, you have to say the name.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, thank you for asking your question.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I've heard this question from a lot of Muslim-Americans across our country, because, unfortunately, there's been a lot of very divisive, dark things said about Muslims.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And even someone like Captain Khan, the young man who sacrificed himself defending our country in the United States Army, has been subject to attack by Donald.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to say just a couple of things.

speaker: CLINTON
text: First, we've had Muslims in America since George Washington.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we've had many successful Muslims.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We just lost a particular well-known one with Muhammad Ali.

speaker: CLINTON
text: My vision of America is an America where everyone has a place, if you're willing to work hard, you do your part, you contribute to the community.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's what America is.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's what we want America to be for our children and our grandchildren.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's also very short-sighted and even dangerous to be engaging in the kind of demagogic rhetoric that Donald has about Muslims.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We need American Muslims to be part of our eyes and ears on our front lines.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've worked with a lot of different Muslim groups around America.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've met with a lot of them, and I've heard how important it is for them to feel that they are wanted and included and part of our country, part of our homeland security, and that's what I want to see.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's also important I intend to defeat ISIS, to do so in a coalition with majority Muslim nations.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Right now, a lot of those nations are hearing what Donald says and wondering, why should we cooperate with the Americans?

speaker: CLINTON
text: And this is a gift to ISIS and the terrorists, violent jihadist terrorists.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We are not at war with Islam.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And it is a mistake and it plays into the hands of the terrorists to act as though we are.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I want a country where citizens like you and your family are just as welcome as anyone else.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump, in December, you said this.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Donald J. Trump is calling for a total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States until our country's representatives can figure out what the hell is going on.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We have no choice.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We have no choice.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Your running mate said this week that the Muslim ban is no longer your position.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Is that correct?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And if it is, was it a mistake to have a religious test?

speaker: TRUMP
text: First of all, Captain Khan is an American hero, and if I were president at that time, he would be alive today, because unlike her, who voted for the war without knowing what she was doing, I would not have had our people in Iraq.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Iraq was disaster.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So he would have been alive today.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The Muslim ban is something that in some form has morphed into a extreme vetting from certain areas of the world.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Hillary Clinton wants to allow hundreds of thousands -- excuse me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Excuse me..

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And why did it morph into that?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: No, did you -- no, answer the question.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Do you still believe...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why don't you interrupt her?

speaker: TRUMP
text: You interrupt me all the time.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why don't you interrupt her?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Would you please explain whether or not the Muslim ban still stands?

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's called extreme vetting.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We are going to areas like Syria where they're coming in by the tens of thousands because of Barack Obama.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And Hillary Clinton wants to allow a 550 percent increase over Obama.

speaker: TRUMP
text: People are coming into our country like we have no idea who they are, where they are from, what their feelings about our country is, and she wants 550 percent more.

speaker: TRUMP
text: This is going to be the great Trojan horse of all time.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have enough problems in this country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I believe in building safe zones.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I believe in having other people pay for them, as an example, the Gulf states, who are not carrying their weight, but they have nothing but money, and take care of people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I don't want to have, with all the problems this country has and all of the problems that you see going on, hundreds of thousands of people coming in from Syria when we know nothing about them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We know nothing about their values and we know nothing about their love for our country.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And, Secretary Clinton, let me ask you about that, because you have asked for an increase from 10,000 to 65,000 Syrian refugees.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We know you want tougher vetting.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: That's not a perfect system.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: So why take the risk of having those refugees come into the country?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, first of all, I will not let anyone into our country that I think poses a risk to us.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But there are a lot of refugees, women and children -- think of that picture we all saw of that 4-year-old boy with the blood on his forehead because he'd been bombed by the Russian and Syrian air forces.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There are children suffering in this catastrophic war, largely, I believe, because of Russian aggression.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we need to do our part.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We by no means are carrying anywhere near the load that Europe and others are.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we will have vetting that is as tough as it needs to be from our professionals, our intelligence experts and others.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But it is important for us as a policy, you know, not to say, as Donald has said, we're going to ban people based on a religion.

speaker: CLINTON
text: How do you do that?

speaker: CLINTON
text: We are a country founded on religious freedom and liberty.

speaker: CLINTON
text: How do we do what he has advocated without causing great distress within our own county?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Are we going to have religious tests when people fly into our country?

speaker: CLINTON
text: And how do we expect to be able to implement those?

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I thought that what he said was extremely unwise and even dangerous.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And indeed, you can look at the propaganda on a lot of the terrorists sites, and what Donald Trump says about Muslims is used to recruit fighters, because they want to create a war between us.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the final thing I would say, this is the 10th or 12th time that he's denied being for the war in Iraq.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have it on tape.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The entire press corps has looked at it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's been debunked, but it never stops him from saying whatever he wants to say.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's not been debunked.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, please...

speaker: TRUMP
text: That has not been debunked.

speaker: CLINTON
text: go to HillaryClinton.com and you can see it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I was against -- I was against the war in Iraq.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Has not been debunked.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And you voted for it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And you shouldn't have.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I just want to say...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: There's been lots of fact-checking on that.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I'd like to move on to an online question...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Excuse me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She just went about 25 seconds over her time.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: She did not.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Could I just respond to this, please?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Very quickly, please.

speaker: TRUMP
