text: Hillary Clinton, in terms of having people come into our country, we have many criminal illegal aliens.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When we want to send them back to their country, their country says we don't want them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: In some cases, they're murderers, drug lords, drug problems.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they don't want them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And Hillary Clinton, when she was secretary of state, said that's OK, we can't force it into their country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Let me tell you, I'm going to force them right back into their country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're murderers and some very bad people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I will tell you very strongly, when Bernie Sanders said she had bad judgment, she has really bad judgment, because we are letting people into this country that are going to cause problems and crime like you've never seen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're also letting drugs pour through our southern border at a record clip.

speaker: TRUMP
text: At a record clip.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it shouldn't be allowed to happen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: ICE just endorsed me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They've never endorsed a presidential candidate.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The Border Patrol agents, 16,500, just recently endorsed me, and they endorsed me because I understand the border.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She doesn't.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She wants amnesty for everybody.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Come right in.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Come right over.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's a horrible thing she's doing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's got bad judgment, and honestly, so bad that she should never be president of the United States.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That I can tell you.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you, Mr. Trump.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I want to move on.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: This next question from the public through the Bipartisan Open Debate Coalition's online forum, where Americans submitted questions that generated millions of votes.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: This question involves WikiLeaks release of purported excerpts of Secretary Clinton's paid speeches, which she has refused to release, and one line in particular, in which you, Secretary Clinton, purportedly say you need both a public and private position on certain issues.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: So, Tu (ph), from Virginia asks, is it OK for politicians to be two-faced?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Is it acceptable for a politician to have a private stance on issues?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, your two minutes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, right.

speaker: CLINTON
text: As I recall, that was something I said about Abraham Lincoln after having seen the wonderful Steven Spielberg movie called "Lincoln."

speaker: CLINTON
text: It was a master class watching President Lincoln get the Congress to approve the 13th Amendment.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It was principled, and it was strategic.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I was making the point that it is hard sometimes to get the Congress to do what you want to do and you have to keep working at it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, yes, President Lincoln was trying to convince some people, he used some arguments, convincing other people, he used other arguments.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That was a great -- I thought a great display of presidential leadership.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But, you know, let's talk about what's really going on here, Martha, because our intelligence community just came out and said in the last few days that the Kremlin, meaning Putin and the Russian government, are directing the attacks, the hacking on American accounts to influence our election.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And WikiLeaks is part of that, as are other sites where the Russians hack information, we don't even know if it's accurate information, and then they put it out.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have never in the history of our country been in a situation where an adversary, a foreign power, is working so hard to influence the outcome of the election.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And believe me, they're not doing it to get me elected.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They're doing it to try to influence the election for Donald Trump.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now, maybe because he has praised Putin, maybe because he says he agrees with a lot of what Putin wants to do, maybe because he wants to do business in Moscow, I don't know the reasons.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we deserve answers.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we should demand that Donald release all of his tax returns so that people can see what are the entanglements and the financial relationships that he has...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We're going to get to that later.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, you're out of time.

speaker: CLINTON
text: with the Russians and other foreign powers.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I think I should respond, because -- so ridiculous.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look, now she's blaming -- she got caught in a total lie.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Her papers went out to all her friends at the banks, Goldman Sachs and everybody else, and she said things -- WikiLeaks that just came out.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she lied.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now she's blaming the lie on the late, great Abraham Lincoln.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's one that I haven't...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: TRUMP
text: OK, Honest Abe, Honest Abe never lied.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's the good thing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's the big difference between Abraham Lincoln and you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's a big, big difference.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're talking about some difference.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But as far as other elements of what she was saying, I don't know Putin.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think it would be great if we got along with Russia because we could fight ISIS together, as an example.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I don't know Putin.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I notice, anytime anything wrong happens, they like to say the Russians are -- she doesn't know if it's the Russians doing the hacking.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Maybe there is no hacking.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But they always blame Russia.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And the reason they blame Russia because they think they're trying to tarnish me with Russia.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I know nothing about Russia.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I know -- I know about Russia, but I know nothing about the inner workings of Russia.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't deal there.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have no businesses there.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have no loans from Russia.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have a very, very great balance sheet, so great that when I did the Old Post Office on Pennsylvania Avenue, the United States government, because of my balance sheet, which they actually know very well, chose me to do the Old Post Office, between the White House and Congress, chose me to do the Old Post Office.

speaker: TRUMP
text: One of the primary area things, in fact, perhaps the primary thing was balance sheet.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I have no loans with Russia.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You could go to the United States government, and they would probably tell you that, because they know my sheet very well in order to get that development I had to have.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, the taxes are a very simple thing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As soon as I have -- first of all, I pay hundreds of millions of dollars in taxes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Many of her friends took bigger deductions.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Warren Buffett took a massive deduction.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Soros, who's a friend of hers, took a massive deduction.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Many of the people that are giving her all this money that she can do many more commercials than me gave her -- took massive deductions.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I pay hundreds of millions of dollars in taxes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But -- but as soon as my routine audit is finished, I'll release my returns.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'll be very proud to.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're actually quite great.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you, Mr. Trump.

speaker: COOPER
text: We want to turn, actually, to the topic of taxes.

speaker: COOPER
text: We have a question from Spencer Maass.

speaker: COOPER
text: Spencer?

speaker: QUESTION
text: Good evening.

speaker: QUESTION
text: My question is, what specific tax provisions will you change to ensure the wealthiest Americans pay their fair share in taxes?

speaker: COOPER
text: Mr. Trump, you have two minutes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, one thing I'd do is get rid of carried interest.

speaker: TRUMP
text: One of the greatest provisions for people like me, to be honest with you, I give up a lot when I run, because I knock out the tax code.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she could have done this years ago, by the way.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's a United States -- she was a United States senator.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She complains that Donald Trump took advantage of the tax code.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, why didn't she change it?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why didn't you change it when you were a senator?

speaker: TRUMP
text: The reason you didn't is that all your friends take the same advantage that I do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You have provisions in the tax code that, frankly, we could change.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But you wouldn't change it, because all of these people gave you the money so you can take negative ads on Donald Trump.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But -- and I say that about a lot of things.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know, I've heard Hillary complaining about so many different things over the years.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I wish you would have done this.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But she's been there for 30 years she's been doing this stuff.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She never changed.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she never will change.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She never will change.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're getting rid of carried interest provisions.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm lowering taxes actually, because I think it's so important for corporations, because we have corporations leaving -- massive corporations and little ones, little ones can't form.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're getting rid of regulations which goes hand in hand with the lowering of the taxes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But we're bringing the tax rate down from 35 percent to 15 percent.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're cutting taxes for the middle class.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I will tell you, we are cutting them big league for the middle class.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I will tell you, Hillary Clinton is raising your taxes, folks.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You can look at me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's raising your taxes really high.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And what that's going to do is a disaster for the country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But she is raising your taxes and I'm lowering your taxes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That in itself is a big difference.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We are going to be thriving again.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have no growth in this country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: There's no growth.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If China has a GDP of 7 percent, it's like a national catastrophe.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're down at 1 percent.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that's, like, no growth.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we're going lower, in my opinion.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And a lot of it has to do with the fact that our taxes are so high, just about the highest in the world.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'm bringing them down to one of the lower in the world.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I think it's so important -- one of the most important things we can do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But she is raising everybody's taxes massively.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, you have two minutes.

speaker: COOPER
text: The question was, what specific tax provisions will you change to ensure the wealthiest Americans pay their fair share of taxes?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, everything you've heard just now from Donald is not true.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm sorry I have to keep saying this, but he lives in an alternative reality.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And it is sort of amusing to hear somebody who hasn't paid federal income taxes in maybe 20 years talking about what he's going to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I'll tell you what he's going to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: His plan will give the wealthy and corporations the biggest tax cuts they've ever had, more than the Bush tax cuts by at least a factor of two.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Donald always takes care of Donald and people like Donald, and this would be a massive gift.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, indeed, the way that he talks about his tax cuts would end up raising taxes on middle-class families, millions of middle-class families.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now, here's what I want to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have said nobody who makes less than $250,000 a year -- and that's the vast majority of Americans as you know -- will have their taxes raised, because I think we've got to go where the money is.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the money is with people who have taken advantage of every single break in the tax code.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, yes, when I was a senator, I did vote to close corporate loopholes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I voted to close, I think, one of the loopholes he took advantage of when he claimed a billion-dollar loss that enabled him to avoid paying taxes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to have a tax on people who are making a million dollars.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's called the Buffett rule.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yes, Warren Buffett is the one who's gone out and said somebody like him should not be paying a lower tax rate than his secretary.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to have a surcharge on incomes above $5 million.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to make up for lost times, because I want to invest in you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to invest in hard-working families.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think it's been unfortunate, but it's happened, that since the Great Recession, the gains have all gone to the top.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we need to reverse that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: People like Donald, who paid zero in taxes, zero for our vets, zero for our military, zero for health and education, that is wrong.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you, Secretary.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we're going to make sure that nobody, no corporation, and no individual can get away without paying his fair share to support our country.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you.

speaker: COOPER
text: I want to give you -- Mr. Trump, I want to give you the chance to respond.

speaker: COOPER
text: I just wanted to tell our viewers what she's referring to.

speaker: COOPER
text: In the last month, taxes were the number-one issue on Facebook for the first time in the campaign.

speaker: COOPER
text: The New York Times published three pages of your 1995 tax returns.

speaker: COOPER
text: They show you claimed a $916 million loss, which means you could have avoided paying personal federal income taxes for years.

speaker: COOPER
text: You've said you pay state taxes, employee taxes, real estate taxes, property taxes.

speaker: COOPER
text: You have not answered, though, a simple question.

speaker: COOPER
text: Did you use that $916 million loss to avoid paying personal federal income taxes for years?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Of course I do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Of course I do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And so do all of her donors, or most of her donors.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I know many of her donors.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Her donors took massive tax write-offs.

speaker: COOPER
text: So have you (inaudible) personal federal income tax?

speaker: TRUMP
text: A lot of my -- excuse me, Anderson -- a lot of my write- off was depreciation and other things that Hillary as a senator allowed.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she'll always allow it, because the people that give her all this money, they want it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That's why.

speaker: TRUMP
text: See, I understand the tax code better than anybody that's ever run for president.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Hillary Clinton -- and it's extremely complex -- Hillary Clinton has friends that want all of these provisions, including they want the carried interest provision, which is very important to Wall Street people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But they really want the carried interest provision, which I believe Hillary's leaving.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Very interesting why she's leaving carried interest.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I will tell you that, number one, I pay tremendous numbers of taxes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I absolutely used it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And so did Warren Buffett and so did George Soros and so did many of the other people that Hillary is getting money from.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, I won't mention their names, because they're rich, but they're not famous.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So we won't make them famous.

speaker: COOPER
text: So can you -- can you say how many years you have avoided paying personal federal income taxes?

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, but I pay tax, and I pay federal tax, too.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I have a write-off, a lot of it's depreciation, which is a wonderful charge.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I love depreciation.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know, she's given it to us.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Hey, if she had a problem -- for 30 years she's been doing this, Anderson.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I say it all the time.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She talks about health care.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why didn't she do something about it?

speaker: TRUMP
text: She talks about taxes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why didn't she do something about it?

speaker: TRUMP
text: She doesn't do anything about anything other than talk.

speaker: TRUMP
text: With her, it's all talk and no action.

speaker: COOPER
text: In the past...

speaker: TRUMP
text: And, again, Bernie Sanders, it's really bad judgment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She has made bad judgment not only on taxes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's made bad judgments on Libya, on Syria, on Iraq.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, her and Obama, whether you like it or not, the way they got out of Iraq, the vacuum they've left, that's why ISIS formed in the first place.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They started from that little area, and now they're in 32 different nations, Hillary.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Congratulations.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Great job.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary -- I want you to be able to respond, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, here we go again.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've been in favor of getting rid of carried interest for years, starting when I was a senator from New York.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But that's not the point here.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why didn't you do it?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why didn't you do it?

speaker: COOPER
text: Allow her to respond.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Because I was a senator with a Republican president.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Oh, really?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I will be the president and we will get it done.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's exactly right.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You could have done it, if you were an effective -- if you were an effective senator, you could have done it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If you were an effective senator, you could have done it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But you were not an effective senator.

speaker: COOPER
text: Please allow her to respond.

speaker: COOPER
text: She didn't interrupt you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, under our Constitution, presidents have something called veto power.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Look, he has now said repeatedly, "30 years this and 30 years that."

speaker: CLINTON
text: So let me talk about my 30 years in public service.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm very glad to do so.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Eight million kids every year have health insurance, because when I was first lady I worked with Democrats and Republicans to create the Children's Health Insurance Program.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Hundreds of thousands of kids now have a chance to be adopted because I worked to change our adoption and foster care system.

speaker: CLINTON
text: After 9/11, I went to work with Republican mayor, governor and president to rebuild New York and to get health care for our first responders who were suffering because they had run toward danger and gotten sickened by it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Hundreds of thousands of National Guard and Reserve members have health care because of work that I did, and children have safer medicines because I was able to pass a law that required the dosing to be more carefully done.

speaker: CLINTON
text: When I was secretary of state, I went around the world advocating for our country, but also advocating for women's rights, to make sure that women had a decent chance to have a better life and negotiated a treaty with Russia to lower nuclear weapons.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Four hundred pieces of legislation have my name on it as a sponsor or cosponsor when I was a senator for eight years.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I worked very hard and was very proud to be re-elected in New York by an even bigger margin than I had been elected the first time.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And as president, I will take that work, that bipartisan work, that finding common ground, because you have to be able to get along with people to get things done in Washington.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you, secretary.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've proven that I can, and for 30 years, I've produced results for people.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you, secretary.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We're going to move on to Syria.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Both of you have mentioned that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She said a lot of things that were false.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, I think we should be allowed to maybe...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: No, we can -- no, Mr. Trump, we're going to go on.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: This is about the audience.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Excuse me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because she has been a disaster as a senator.

speaker: TRUMP
text: A disaster.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump, we're going to move on.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: The heart-breaking video of a 5-year-old Syrian boy named Omran sitting in an ambulance after being pulled from the rubble after an air strike in Aleppo focused the world's attention on the horrors of the war in Syria, with 136 million views on Facebook alone.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: But there are much worse images coming out of Aleppo every day now, where in the past few weeks alone, 400 people have been killed, at least 100 of them children.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Just days ago, the State Department called for a war crimes investigation of the Syrian regime of Bashar al-Assad and its ally, Russia, for their bombardment of Aleppo.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: So this next question comes through social media through Facebook.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Diane from Pennsylvania asks, if you were president, what would you do about Syria and the humanitarian crisis in Aleppo?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Isn't it a lot like the Holocaust when the U.S. waited too long before we helped?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, we will begin with your two minutes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, the situation in Syria is catastrophic.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And every day that goes by, we see the results of the regime by Assad in partnership with the Iranians on the ground, the Russians in the air, bombarding places, in particular Aleppo, where there are hundreds of thousands of people, probably about 250,000 still left.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And there is a determined effort by the Russian air force to destroy Aleppo in order to eliminate the last of the Syrian rebels who are really holding out against the Assad regime.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Russia hasn't paid any attention to ISIS.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They're interested in keeping Assad in power.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I, when I was secretary of state, advocated and I advocate today a no-fly zone and safe zones.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We need some leverage with the Russians, because they are not going to come to the negotiating table for a diplomatic resolution, unless there is some leverage over them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we have to work more closely with our partners and allies on the ground.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I want to emphasize that what is at stake here is the ambitions and the aggressiveness of Russia.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Russia has decided that it's all in, in Syria.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And they've also decided who they want to see become president of the United States, too, and it's not me.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've stood up to Russia.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've taken on Putin and others, and I would do that as president.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think wherever we can cooperate with Russia, that's fine.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I did as secretary of state.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's how we got a treaty reducing nuclear weapons.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's how we got the sanctions on Iran that put a lid on the Iranian nuclear program without firing a single shot.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I would go to the negotiating table with more leverage than we have now.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I do support the effort to investigate for crimes, war crimes committed by the Syrians and the Russians and try to hold them accountable.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump?

speaker: TRUMP
text: First of all, she was there as secretary of state with the so-called line in the sand, which...

speaker: CLINTON
text: No, I wasn't.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I was gone.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I hate to interrupt you, but at some point...

speaker: TRUMP
text: OK.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But you were in contact -- excuse me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You were...

speaker: CLINTON
text: At some point, we need to do some fact-checking here.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You were in total contact with the White House, and perhaps, sadly, Obama probably still listened to you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't think he would be listening to you very much anymore.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Obama draws the line in the sand.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It was laughed at all over the world what happened.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, with that being said, she talks tough against Russia.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But our nuclear program has fallen way behind, and they've gone wild with their nuclear program.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Not good.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Our government shouldn't have allowed that to happen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Russia is new in terms of nuclear.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We are old.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're tired.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're exhausted in terms of nuclear.

speaker: TRUMP
text: A very bad thing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, she talks tough, she talks really tough against Putin and against Assad.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She talks in favor of the rebels.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She doesn't even know who the rebels are.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know, every time we take rebels, whether it's in Iraq or anywhere else, we're arming people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And you know what happens?

speaker: TRUMP
text: They end up being worse than the people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look at what she did in Libya with Gadhafi.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Gadhafi's out.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's a mess.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And, by the way, ISIS has a good chunk of their oil.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm sure you probably have heard that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It was a disaster.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because the fact is, almost everything she's done in foreign policy has been a mistake and it's been a disaster.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But if you look at Russia, just take a look at Russia, and look at what they did this week, where I agree, she wasn't there, but possibly she's consulted.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We sign a peace treaty.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Everyone's all excited.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, what Russia did with Assad and, by the way, with Iran, who you made very powerful with the dumbest deal perhaps I've ever seen in the history of deal-making, the Iran deal, with the $150 billion, with the $1.7 billion in cash, which is enough to fill up this room.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But look at that deal.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Iran now and Russia are now against us.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So she wants to fight.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She wants to fight for rebels.

speaker: TRUMP
text: There's only one problem.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You don't even know who the rebels are.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So what's the purpose?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump, Mr. Trump, your two minutes is up.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And one thing I have to say.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Your two minutes is up.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't like Assad at all, but Assad is killing ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Russia is killing ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And Iran is killing ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And those three have now lined up because of our weak foreign policy.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump, let me repeat the question.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: If you were president...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: what would you do about Syria and the humanitarian crisis in Aleppo?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And I want to remind you what your running mate said.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: He said provocations by Russia need to be met with American strength and that if Russia continues to be involved in air strikes along with the Syrian government forces of Assad, the United States of America should be prepared to use military force to strike the military targets of the Assad regime.

speaker: TRUMP
text: OK.

speaker: TRUMP
text: He and I haven't spoken, and I disagree.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I disagree.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You disagree with your running mate?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think you have to knock out ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Right now, Syria is fighting ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have people that want to fight both at the same time.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But Syria is no longer Syria.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Syria is Russia and it's Iran, who she made strong and Kerry and Obama made into a very powerful nation and a very rich nation, very, very quickly, very, very quickly.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I believe we have to get ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to worry about ISIS before we can get too much more involved.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She had a chance to do something with Syria.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They had a chance.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And that was the line.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she didn't.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: What do you think will happen if Aleppo falls?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think Aleppo is a disaster, humanitarian-wise.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: What do you think will happen if it falls?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think that it basically has fallen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: OK?

speaker: TRUMP
text: It basically has fallen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Let me tell you something.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You take a look at Mosul.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The biggest problem I have with the stupidity of our foreign policy, we have Mosul.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They think a lot of the ISIS leaders are in Mosul.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So we have announcements coming out of Washington and coming out of Iraq, we will be attacking Mosul in three weeks or four weeks.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, all of these bad leaders from ISIS are leaving Mosul.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why can't they do it quietly?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why can't they do the attack, make it a sneak attack, and after the attack is made, inform the American public that we've knocked out the leaders, we've had a tremendous success?

speaker: TRUMP
text: People leave.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why do they have to say we're going to be attacking Mosul within the next four to six weeks, which is what they're saying?

speaker: TRUMP
text: How stupid is our country?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: There are sometimes reasons the military does that.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Psychological warfare.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I can't think of any.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I can't think of any.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'm pretty good at it.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: It might be to help get civilians out.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we have General Flynn.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we have -- look, I have 200 generals and admirals who endorsed me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have 21 Congressional Medal of Honor recipients who endorsed me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We talk about it all the time.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They understand, why can't they do something secretively, where they go in and they knock out the leadership?

speaker: TRUMP
text: How -- why would these people stay there?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I've been reading now...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Tell me what your strategy is.

speaker: TRUMP
text: for weeks -- I've been reading now for weeks about Mosul, that it's the harbor of where -- you know, between Raqqa and Mosul, this is where they think the ISIS leaders are.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why would they be saying -- they're not staying there anymore.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're gone.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because everybody's talking about how Iraq, which is us with our leadership, goes in to fight Mosul.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, with these 200 admirals and generals, they can't believe it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: All I say is this.

speaker: TRUMP
text: General George Patton, General Douglas MacArthur are spinning in their grave at the stupidity of what we're doing in the Middle East.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I'm going to go to Secretary Clinton.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, you want Assad to go.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You advocated arming rebels, but it looks like that may be too late for Aleppo.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You talk about diplomatic efforts.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Those have failed.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Cease-fires have failed.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Would you introduce the threat of U.S. military force beyond a no-fly zone against the Assad regime to back up diplomacy?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I would not use American ground forces in Syria.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think that would be a very serious mistake.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I don't think American troops should be holding territory, which is what they would have to do as an occupying force.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I don't think that is a smart strategy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I do think the use of special forces, which we're using, the use of enablers and trainers in Iraq, which has had some positive effects, are very much in our interests, and so I do support what is happening, but let me just...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: But what would you do differently than President Obama is doing?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, Martha, I hope that by the time I -- if I'm fortunate...

speaker: TRUMP
text: Everything.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I hope by the time I am president that we will have pushed ISIS out of Iraq.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I do think that there is a good chance that we can take Mosul.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, you know, Donald says he knows more about ISIS than the generals.

speaker: CLINTON
text: No, he doesn't.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There are a lot of very important planning going on, and some of it is to signal to the Sunnis in the area, as well as Kurdish Peshmerga fighters, that we all need to be in this.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And that takes a lot of planning and preparation.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I would go after Baghdadi.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I would specifically target Baghdadi, because I think our targeting of Al Qaida leaders -- and I was involved in a lot of those operations, highly classified ones -- made a difference.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I think that could help.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I would also consider arming the Kurds.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The Kurds have been our best partners in Syria, as well as Iraq.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I know there's a lot of concern about that in some circles, but I think they should have the equipment they need so that Kurdish and Arab fighters on the ground are the principal way that we take Raqqa after pushing ISIS out of Iraq.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you very much.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We're going to move on...

speaker: TRUMP
text: You know what's funny?

speaker: TRUMP
text: She went over a minute over, and you don't stop her.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When I go one second over, it's like a big deal.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You had many answers.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's really -- it's really very interesting.

speaker: COOPER
text: We've got a question over here from James Carter.

speaker: COOPER
text: Mr. Carter?

speaker: QUESTION
text: My question is, do you believe you can be a devoted president to all the people in the United States?

speaker: COOPER
text: That question begins for Mr. Trump.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Absolutely.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, she calls our people deplorable, a large group, and irredeemable.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I will be a president for all of our people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I'll be a president that will turn our inner cities around and will give strength to people and will give economics to people and will bring jobs back.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because NAFTA, signed by her husband, is perhaps the greatest disaster trade deal in the history of the world.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Not in this country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It stripped us of manufacturing jobs.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We lost our jobs.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We lost our money.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We lost our plants.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It is a disaster.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And now she wants to sign TPP, even though she says now she's for it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She called it the gold standard.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And by the way, at the last debate, she lied, because it turned out that she did say the gold standard and she said she didn't say it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They actually said that she lied.

speaker: TRUMP
text: OK?

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she lied.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But she's lied about a lot of things.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I would be a president for all of the people, African- Americans, the inner cities.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Devastating what's happening to our inner cities.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's been talking about it for years.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As usual, she talks about it, nothing happens.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She doesn't get it done.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Same with the Latino Americans, the Hispanic Americans.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The same exact thing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They talk, they don't get it done.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You go into the inner cities and -- you see it's 45 percent poverty.

speaker: TRUMP
text: African- Americans now 45 percent poverty in the inner cities.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The education is a disaster.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Jobs are essentially nonexistent.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, it's -- you know, and I've been saying at big speeches where I have 20,000 and 30,000 people, what do you have to lose?

speaker: TRUMP
text: It can't get any worse.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she's been talking about the inner cities for 25 years.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Nothing's going to ever happen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Let me tell you, if she's president of the United States, nothing's going to happen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's just going to be talk.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And all of her friends, the taxes we were talking about, and I would just get it by osmosis.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's not doing any me favors.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But by doing all the others' favors, she's doing me favors.

speaker: COOPER
text: Mr. Trump, thank you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I will tell you, she's all talk.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It doesn't get done.

speaker: TRUMP
text: All you have to do is take a look at her Senate run.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Take a look at upstate New York.

speaker: COOPER
text: Your two minutes is up.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, two minutes?

speaker: TRUMP
text: It turned out to be a disaster.

speaker: COOPER
text: You have two minutes, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, 67 percent of the people voted to re-elect me when I ran for my second term, and I was very proud and very humbled by that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Mr. Carter, I have tried my entire life to do what I can to support children and families.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, right out of law school, I went to work for the Children's Defense Fund.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And Donald talks a lot about, you know, the 30 years I've been in public service.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm proud of that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, I started off as a young lawyer working against discrimination against African-American children in schools and in the criminal justice system.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I worked to make sure that kids with disabilities could get a public education, something that I care very much about.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have worked with Latinos -- one of my first jobs in politics was down in south Texas registering Latino citizens to be able to vote.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I have a deep devotion, to use your absolutely correct word, to making sure that an every American feels like he or she has a place in our country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think when you look at the letters that I get, a lot of people are worried that maybe they wouldn't have a place in Donald Trump's America.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They write me, and one woman wrote me about her son, Felix.

speaker: CLINTON
text: She adopted him from Ethiopia when he was a toddler.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He's 10 years old now.

speaker: CLINTON
text: This is the only one country he's ever known.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And he listens to Donald on TV and he said to his mother one day, will he send me back to Ethiopia if he gets elected?

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, children listen to what is being said.

speaker: CLINTON
text: To go back to the very, very first question.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And there's a lot of fear -- in fact, teachers and parents are calling it the Trump effect.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Bullying is up.

speaker: CLINTON
text: A lot of people are feeling, you know, uneasy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: A lot of kids are expressing their concerns.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, first and foremost, I will do everything I can to reach out to everybody.

speaker: COOPER
text: Your time, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Democrats, Republicans, independents, people across our country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: If you don't vote for me, I still want to be your president.

speaker: COOPER
text: Your two minutes is up.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to be the best president I can be for every American.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, your two minutes is up.

speaker: COOPER
text: I want to follow up on something that Donald Trump actually said to you, a comment you made last month.

speaker: COOPER
text: You said that half of Donald Trump's supporters are, quote, "deplorables, racist, sexist, homophobic, xenophobic, Islamophobic."

speaker: COOPER
text: You later said you regretted saying half.

speaker: COOPER
text: You didn't express regret for using the term "deplorables."

speaker: COOPER
text: To Mr. Carter's question, how can you unite a country if you've written off tens of millions of Americans?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, within hours I said that I was sorry about the way I talked about that, because my argument is not with his supporters.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's with him and with the hateful and divisive campaign that he has run, and the inciting of violence at his rallies, and the very brutal kinds of comments about not just women, but all Americans, all kinds of Americans.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And what he has said about African-Americans and Latinos, about Muslims, about POWs, about immigrants, about people with disabilities, he's never apologized for.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so I do think that a lot of the tone and tenor that he has said -- I'm proud of the campaign that Bernie Sanders and I ran.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We ran a campaign based on issues, not insults.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And he is supporting me 100 percent.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Because we talked about what we wanted to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We might have had some differences, and we had a lot of debates...

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you, Secretary.

speaker: TRUMP
text: but we believed that we could make the country better.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I was proud of that.

speaker: COOPER
text: I want to give you a minute to respond.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have a divided nation.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have a very divided nation.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You look at Charlotte.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You look at Baltimore.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You look at the violence that's taking place in the inner cities, Chicago, you take a look at Washington, D.C.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have an increase in murder within our cities, the biggest in 45 years.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have a divided nation, because people like her -- and believe me, she has tremendous hate in her heart.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And when she said deplorables, she meant it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And when she said irredeemable, they're irredeemable, you didn't mention that, but when she said they're irredeemable, to me that might have been even worse.

speaker: COOPER
text: She said some of them are irredeemable.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's got tremendous -- she's got tremendous hatred.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And this country cannot take another four years of Barack Obama, and that's what you're getting with her.

speaker: COOPER
text: Mr. Trump, let me follow up with you.

speaker: COOPER
text: In 2008, you wrote in one of your books that the most important characteristic of a good leader is discipline.

speaker: COOPER
text: You said, if a leader doesn't have it, quote, "he or she won't be one for very long."

speaker: COOPER
text: In the days after the first debate, you sent out a series of tweets from 3 a.m. to 5 a.m., including one that told people to check out a sex tape.

speaker: COOPER
text: Is that the discipline of a good leader?

speaker: TRUMP
text: No, there wasn't check out a sex tape.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It was just take a look at the person that she built up to be this wonderful Girl Scout who was no Girl Scout.

speaker: COOPER
text: You mentioned sex tape.

speaker: TRUMP
text: By the way, just so you understand, when she said 3 o'clock in the morning, take a look at Benghazi.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She said who is going to answer the call at 3 o'clock in the morning?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Guess what?

speaker: TRUMP
text: She didn't answer it, because when Ambassador Stevens...

speaker: COOPER
text: The question is, is that the discipline of a good leader?

speaker: TRUMP
text: 600 -- wait a minute, Anderson, 600 times.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, she said she was awake at 3 o'clock in the morning, and she also sent a tweet out at 3 o'clock in the morning, but I won't even mention that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But she said she'll be awake.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Who's going -- the famous thing, we're going to answer our call at 3 o'clock in the morning.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Guess what happened?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Ambassador Stevens -- Ambassador Stevens sent 600 requests for help.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And the only one she talked to was Sidney Blumenthal, who's her friend and not a good guy, by the way.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So, you know, she shouldn't be talking about that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, tweeting happens to be a modern day form of communication.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, you can like it or not like it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have, between Facebook and Twitter, I have almost 25 million people.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's a very effective way of communication.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So you can put it down, but it is a very effective form of communication.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm not un-proud of it, to be honest with you.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, does Mr. Trump have the discipline to be a good leader?

speaker: CLINTON
text: No.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm shocked to hear that.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, it's not only my opinion.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's the opinion of many others, national security experts, Republicans, former Republican members of Congress.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But it's in part because those of us who have had the great privilege of seeing this job up close and know how difficult it is, and it's not just because I watched my husband take a $300 billion deficit and turn it into a $200 billion surplus, and 23 million new jobs were created, and incomes went up for everybody.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Everybody.

speaker: CLINTON
text: African-American incomes went up 33 percent.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And it's not just because I worked with George W. Bush after 9/11, and I was very proud that when I told him what the city needed, what we needed to recover, he said you've got it, and he never wavered.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He stuck with me.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I have worked and I admire President Obama.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He inherited the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That was a terrible time for our country.

speaker: COOPER
text: We have to move along.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Nine million people lost their jobs.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, we have to...

speaker: CLINTON
text: Five million homes were lost.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, we're moving.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And $13 trillion in family wealth was wiped out.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We are back on the right track.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He would send us back into recession with his tax plans that benefit the wealthiest of Americans.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, we are moving to an audience question.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We're almost out of time.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We have another...

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have the slowest growth since 1929.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We're moving to an audience question.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It is -- our country has the slowest growth and jobs are a disaster.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump, Secretary Clinton, we want to get to the audience.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you very much both of you.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We have another audience question.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Beth Miller has a question for both candidates.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Good evening.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Perhaps the most important aspect of this election is the Supreme Court justice.

speaker: QUESTION
text: What would you prioritize as the most important aspect of selecting a Supreme Court justice?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We begin with your two minutes, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Thank you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, you're right.

speaker: CLINTON
text: This is one of the most important issues in this election.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to appoint Supreme Court justices who understand the way the world really works, who have real-life experience, who have not just been in a big law firm and maybe clerked for a judge and then gotten on the bench, but, you know, maybe they tried some more cases, they actually understand what people are up against.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Because I think the current court has gone in the wrong direction.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so I would want to see the Supreme Court reverse Citizens United and get dark, unaccountable money out of our politics.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Donald doesn't agree with that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I would like the Supreme Court to understand that voting rights are still a big problem in many parts of our country, that we don't always do everything we can to make it possible for people of color and older people and young people to be able to exercise their franchise.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want a Supreme Court that will stick with Roe v. Wade and a woman's right to choose, and I want a Supreme Court that will stick with marriage equality.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now, Donald has put forth the names of some people that he would consider.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And among the ones that he has suggested are people who would reverse Roe v. Wade and reverse marriage equality.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think that would be a terrible mistake and would take us backwards.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want a Supreme Court that doesn't always side with corporate interests.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want a Supreme Court that understands because you're wealthy and you can give more money to something doesn't mean you have any more rights or should have any more rights than anybody else.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I have very clear views about what I want to see to kind of change the balance on the Supreme Court.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I regret deeply that the Senate has not done its job and they have not permitted a vote on the person that President Obama, a highly qualified person, they've not given him a vote to be able to be have the full complement of nine Supreme Court justices.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think that was a dereliction of duty.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I hope that they will see their way to doing it, but if I am so fortunate enough as to be president, I will immediately move to make sure that we fill that, we have nine justices that get to work on behalf of our people.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You're out of time.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Justice Scalia, great judge, died recently.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we have a vacancy.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I am looking to appoint judges very much in the mold of Justice Scalia.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm looking for judges -- and I've actually picked 20 of them so that people would see, highly respected, highly thought of, and actually very beautifully reviewed by just about everybody.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But people that will respect the Constitution of the United States.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I think that this is so important.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Also, the Second Amendment, which is totally under siege by people like Hillary Clinton.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They'll respect the Second Amendment and what it stands for, what it represents.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So important to me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, Hillary mentioned something about contributions just so you understand.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So I will have in my race more than $100 million put in -- of my money, meaning I'm not taking all of this big money from all of these different corporations like she's doing.

speaker: TRUMP
text: What I ask is this.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So I'm putting in more than -- by the time it's finished, I'll have more than $100 million invested.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Pretty much self-funding money.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're raising money for the Republican Party, and we're doing tremendously on the small donations, $61 average or so.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I ask Hillary, why doesn't -- she made $250 million by being in office.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She used the power of her office to make a lot of money.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why isn't she funding, not for $100 million, but why don't you put $10 million or $20 million or $25 million or $30 million into your own campaign?

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's $30 million less for special interests that will tell you exactly what to do and it would really, I think, be a nice sign to the American public.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Why aren't you putting some money in?

speaker: TRUMP
text: You have a lot of it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You've made a lot of it because of the fact that you've been in office.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Made a lot of it while you were secretary of state, actually.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So why aren't you putting money into your own campaign?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm just curious.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you very much.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We're going to get on to one more question.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The question was about the Supreme Court.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I just want to quickly say, I respect the Second Amendment.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I believe there should be comprehensive background checks, and we should close the gun show loophole, and close the online loophole.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We have -- we have one more question, Mrs. Clinton.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to save as many lives as we possibly can.

speaker: COOPER
text: We have one more question from Ken Bone about energy policy.

speaker: COOPER
text: Ken?

speaker: QUESTION
text: What steps will your energy policy take to meet our energy needs, while at the same time remaining environmentally friendly and minimizing job loss for fossil power plant workers?

speaker: COOPER
text: Mr. Trump, two minutes?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Absolutely.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think it's such a great question, because energy is under siege by the Obama administration.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Under absolutely siege.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The EPA, Environmental Protection Agency, is killing these energy companies.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And foreign companies are now coming in buying our -- buying so many of our different plants and then re-jiggering the plant so that they can take care of their oil.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We are killing -- absolutely killing our energy business in this country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now, I'm all for alternative forms of energy, including wind, including solar, et cetera.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But we need much more than wind and solar.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And you look at our miners.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Hillary Clinton wants to put all the miners out of business.

speaker: TRUMP
text: There is a thing called clean coal.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Coal will last for 1,000 years in this country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now we have natural gas and so many other things because of technology.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have unbelievable -- we have found over the last seven years, we have found tremendous wealth right under our feet.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So good.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Especially when you have $20 trillion in debt.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I will bring our energy companies back.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They'll be able to compete.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They'll make money.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They'll pay off our national debt.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They'll pay off our tremendous budget deficits, which are tremendous.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But we are putting our energy companies out of business.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to bring back our workers.

speaker: TRUMP
text: You take a look at what's happening to steel and the cost of steel and China dumping vast amounts of steel all over the United States, which essentially is killing our steelworkers and our steel companies.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to guard our energy companies.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to make it possible.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The EPA is so restrictive that they are putting our energy companies out of business.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And all you have to do is go to a great place like West Virginia or places like Ohio, which is phenomenal, or places like Pennsylvania and you see what they're doing to the people, miners and others in the energy business.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's a disgrace.

speaker: COOPER
text: Your time is up.

speaker: COOPER
text: Thank you.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's an absolute disgrace.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton, two minutes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And actually -- well, that was very interesting.

speaker: CLINTON
text: First of all, China is illegally dumping steel in the United States and Donald Trump is buying it to build his buildings, putting steelworkers and American steel plants out of business.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's something that I fought against as a senator and that I would have a trade prosecutor to make sure that we don't get taken advantage of by China on steel or anything else.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, because it sounds like you're in the business or you're aware of people in the business -- you know that we are now for the first time ever energy-independent.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We are not dependent upon the Middle East.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But the Middle East still controls a lot of the prices.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So the price of oil has been way down.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And that has had a damaging effect on a lot of the oil companies, right?

speaker: CLINTON
text: We are, however, producing a lot of natural gas, which serves as a bridge to more renewable fuels.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think that's an important transition.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've got to remain energy-independent.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It gives us much more power and freedom than to be worried about what goes on in the Middle East.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have enough worries over there without having to worry about that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I have a comprehensive energy policy, but it really does include fighting climate change, because I think that is a serious problem.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I support moving toward more clean, renewable energy as quickly as we can, because I think we can be the 21st century clean energy superpower and create millions of new jobs and businesses.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I also want to be sure that we don't leave people behind.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's why I'm the only candidate from the very beginning of this campaign who had a plan to help us revitalize coal country, because those coal miners and their fathers and their grandfathers, they dug that coal out.

speaker: CLINTON
text: A lot of them lost their lives.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They were injured, but they turned the lights on and they powered their factories.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I don't want to walk away from them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So we've got to do something for them.

speaker: COOPER
text: Secretary Clinton...

speaker: CLINTON
text: But the price of coal is down worldwide.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So we have to look at this comprehensively.

speaker: COOPER
text: Your time is up.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And that's exactly what I have proposed.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I hope you will go to HillaryClinton.com and look at my entire policy.

speaker: COOPER
text: Time is up.

speaker: COOPER
text: We have time for one more...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We have...

speaker: COOPER
text: One more audience question.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We've sneaked in one more question, and it comes from Karl Becker.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Good evening.

speaker: QUESTION
text: My question to both of you is, regardless of the current rhetoric, would either of you name one positive thing that you respect in one another?

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump, would you like to go first?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I certainly will, because I think that's a very fair and important question.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Look, I respect his children.

speaker: CLINTON
text: His children are incredibly able and devoted, and I think that says a lot about Donald.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I don't agree with nearly anything else he says or does, but I do respect that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think that is something that as a mother and a grandmother is very important to me.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I believe that this election has become in part so -- so conflict-oriented, so intense because there's a lot at stake.

speaker: CLINTON
text: This is not an ordinary time, and this is not an ordinary election.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We are going to be choosing a president who will set policy for not just four or eight years, but because of some of the important decisions we have to make here at home and around the world, from the Supreme Court to energy and so much else, and so there is a lot at stake.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's one of the most consequential elections that we've had.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And that's why I've tried to put forth specific policies and plans, trying to get it off of the personal and put it on to what it is I want to do as president.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And that's why I hope people will check on that for themselves so that they can see that, yes, I've spent 30 years, actually maybe a little more, working to help kids and families.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I want to take all that experience to the White House and do that every single day.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Mr. Trump?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I consider her statement about my children to be a very nice compliment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't know if it was meant to be a compliment, but it is a great -- I'm very proud of my children.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And they've done a wonderful job, and they've been wonderful, wonderful kids.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So I consider that a compliment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I will say this about Hillary.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She doesn't quit.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She doesn't give up.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I respect that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I tell it like it is.

speaker: TRUMP
text: She's a fighter.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I disagree with much of what she's fighting for.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I do disagree with her judgment in many cases.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But she does fight hard, and she doesn't quit, and she doesn't give up.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I consider that to be a very good trait.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thanks to both of you.

speaker: COOPER
text: We want to thank both the candidates.

speaker: COOPER
text: We want to thank the university here.

speaker: COOPER
text: This concludes the town hall meeting.

speaker: COOPER
text: Our thanks to the candidates, the commission, Washington University, and to everybody who watched.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Please tune in on October 19th for the final presidential debate that will take place at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Good night, everyone.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Good evening from the Thomas and Mack Center at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas.

speaker: WALLACE
text: I'm Chris Wallace of Fox News, and I welcome you to the third and final of the 2016 presidential debates between Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump.

speaker: WALLACE
text: This debate is sponsored by the Commission on Presidential Debates.

speaker: WALLACE
text: The commission has designed the format: Six roughly 15-minute segments with two-minute answers to the first question, then open discussion for the rest of each segment.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Both campaigns have agreed to those rules.

speaker: WALLACE
text: For the record, I decided the topics and the questions in each topic.

speaker: WALLACE
text: None of those questions has been shared with the commission or the two candidates.

speaker: WALLACE
text: The audience here in the hall has promised to remain silent.

speaker: WALLACE
text: No cheers, boos, or other interruptions so we and you can focus on what the candidates have to say.

speaker: WALLACE
text: No noise, except right now, as we welcome the Democratic nominee for president, Secretary Clinton, and the Republican nominee for president, Mr. Trump.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: WALLACE
text: Secretary Clinton, Mr. Trump, welcome.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Let's get right to it.

speaker: WALLACE
text: The first topic is the Supreme Court.

speaker: WALLACE
text: You both talked briefly about the court in the last debate, but I want to drill down on this, because the next president will almost certainly have at least one appointment and likely or possibly two or three appointments.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Which means that you will, in effect, determine the balance of the court for what could be the next quarter century.

speaker: WALLACE
text: First of all, where do you want to see the court take the country?

speaker: WALLACE
text: And secondly, what's your view on how the Constitution should be interpreted?

speaker: WALLACE
text: Do the founders' words mean what they say or is it a living document to be applied flexibly according to changing circumstances?

speaker: WALLACE
text: In this segment, Secretary Clinton, you go first.

speaker: WALLACE
text: You have two minutes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Thank you very much, Chris.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And thanks to UNLV for hosting us.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, I think when we talk about the Supreme Court, it really raises the central issue in this election, namely, what kind of country are we going to be?

speaker: CLINTON
text: What kind of opportunities will we provide for our citizens?

speaker: CLINTON
text: What kind of rights will Americans have?

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I feel strongly that the Supreme Court needs to stand on the side of the American people, not on the side of the powerful corporations and the wealthy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: For me, that means that we need a Supreme Court that will stand up on behalf of women's rights, on behalf of the rights of the LGBT community, that will stand up and say no to Citizens United, a decision that has undermined the election system in our country because of the way it permits dark, unaccountable money to come into our electoral system.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have major disagreements with my opponent about these issues and others that will be before the Supreme Court.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I feel that at this point in our country's history, it is important that we not reverse marriage equality, that we not reverse Roe v. Wade, that we stand up against Citizens United, we stand up for the rights of people in the workplace, that we stand up and basically say: The Supreme Court should represent all of us.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's how I see the court, and the kind of people that I would be looking to nominate to the court would be in the great tradition of standing up to the powerful, standing up on behalf of our rights as Americans.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I look forward to having that opportunity.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I would hope that the Senate would do its job and confirm the nominee that President Obama has sent to them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's the way the Constitution fundamentally should operate.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The president nominates, and then the Senate advises and consents, or not, but they go forward with the process.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Secretary Clinton, thank you.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Mr. Trump, same question.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Where do you want to see the court take the country?

speaker: WALLACE
text: And how do you believe the Constitution should be interpreted?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, first of all, it's great to be with you, and thank you, everybody.

speaker: TRUMP
text: The Supreme Court: It's what it's all about.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Our country is so, so -- it's just so imperative that we have the right justices.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Something happened recently where Justice Ginsburg made some very, very inappropriate statements toward me and toward a tremendous number of people, many, many millions of people that I represent.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And she was forced to apologize.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And apologize she did.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But these were statements that should never, ever have been made.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We need a Supreme Court that in my opinion is going to uphold the Second Amendment, and all amendments, but the Second Amendment, which is under absolute siege.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I believe if my opponent should win this race, which I truly don't think will happen, we will have a Second Amendment which will be a very, very small replica of what it is right now.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I feel that it's absolutely important that we uphold, because of the fact that it is under such trauma.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I feel that the justices that I am going to appoint -- and I've named 20 of them -- the justices that I'm going to appoint will be pro-life.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They will have a conservative bent.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They will be protecting the Second Amendment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They are great scholars in all cases, and they're people of tremendous respect.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They will interpret the Constitution the way the founders wanted it interpreted.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I believe that's very, very important.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I don't think we should have justices appointed that decide what they want to hear.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's all about the Constitution of -- of -- and so important, the Constitution the way it was meant to be.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And those are the people that I will appoint.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Mr. Trump, thank you.

speaker: WALLACE
text: We now have about 10 minutes for an open discussion.

speaker: WALLACE
text: I want to focus on two issues that, in fact, by the justices that you name could end up changing the existing law of the land.

speaker: WALLACE
text: First is one that you mentioned, Mr. Trump, and that is guns.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Secretary Clinton, you said last year, let me quote, "The Supreme Court is wrong on the Second Amendment."

speaker: WALLACE
text: And now, in fact, in the 2008 Heller case, the court ruled that there is a constitutional right to bear arms, but a right that is reasonably limited.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Those were the words of the Judge Antonin Scalia who wrote the decision.

speaker: WALLACE
text: What's wrong with that?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, first of all, I support the Second Amendment.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I lived in Arkansas for 18 wonderful years.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I represented upstate New York.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I understand and respect the tradition of gun ownership.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It goes back to the founding of our country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I also believe that there can be and must be reasonable regulation.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Because I support the Second Amendment doesn't mean that I want people who shouldn't have guns to be able to threaten you, kill you or members of your family.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so when I think about what we need to do, we have 33,000 people a year who die from guns.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think we need comprehensive background checks, need to close the online loophole, close the gun show loophole.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There's other matters that I think are sensible that are the kind of reforms that would make a difference that are not in any way conflicting with the Second Amendment.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You mentioned the Heller decision.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And what I was saying that you referenced, Chris, was that I disagreed with the way the court applied the Second Amendment in that case, because what the District of Columbia was trying to do was to protect toddlers from guns and so they wanted people with guns to safely store them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the court didn't accept that reasonable regulation, but they've accepted many others.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I see no conflict between saving people's lives and defending the Second Amendment.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Let me bring Mr. Trump in here.

speaker: WALLACE
text: The bipartisan Open Debate Coalition got millions of votes on questions to ask here, and this was, in fact, one of the top questions that they got.

speaker: WALLACE
text: How will you ensure the Second Amendment is protected?

speaker: WALLACE
text: You just heard Secretary Clinton's answer.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Does she persuade you that, while you may disagree on regulation, that, in fact, she supports a Second Amendment right to bear arms?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, the D.C. vs. Heller decision was very strongly -- and she was extremely angry about it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I watched.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, she was very, very angry when upheld.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And Justice Scalia was so involved.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it was a well-crafted decision.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But Hillary was extremely upset, extremely angry.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And people that believe in the Second Amendment and believe in it very strongly were very upset with what she had to say.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Well, let me bring in Secretary Clinton.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Were you extremely upset?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I was upset because, unfortunately, dozens of toddlers injure themselves, even kill people with guns, because, unfortunately, not everyone who has loaded guns in their homes takes appropriate precautions.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But there's no doubt that I respect the Second Amendment, that I also believe there's an individual right to bear arms.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That is not in conflict with sensible, commonsense regulation.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, you know, look, I understand that Donald's been strongly supported by the NRA.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The gun lobby's on his side.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They're running millions of dollars of ads against me.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I regret that, because what I would like to see is for people to come together and say: Of course we're going to protect and defend the Second Amendment.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we're going to do it in a way that tries to save some of these 33,000 lives that we lose every year.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Let me bring Mr. Trump back into this, because, in fact, you oppose any limits on assault weapons, any limits on high- capacity magazines.

speaker: WALLACE
text: You support a national right to carry law.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Why, sir?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, let me just tell you before we go any further.

speaker: TRUMP
text: In Chicago, which has the toughest gun laws in the United States, probably you could say by far, they have more gun violence than any other city.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So we have the toughest laws, and you have tremendous gun violence.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I am a very strong supporter of the Second Amendment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I am -- I don't know if Hillary was saying it in a sarcastic manner, but I'm very proud to have the endorsement of the NRA.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it's the earliest endorsement they've ever given to anybody who ran for president.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So I'm very honored by all of that.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We are going to appoint justices -- this is the best way to help the Second Amendment.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We are going to appoint justices that will feel very strongly about the Second Amendment, that will not do damage to the Second Amendment.

speaker: WALLACE
